English: Studying hard can increase our knowledge.

Amis: na semusu anga sun ta sunatj a vinecikan a pakatjanu kasiw i vukid tua i Taiwang?
English: Have you read the book "Alpine Plants of Taiwan"?

Amis: nasemusuanga ken, aicu a sunatj nanguaq angata susuin.
English: I have read it and it is well worth reading.

Amis: maqati aken a kisedjam tjanusun ta aicu a sunatj?
English: Can I borrow this book from you?

Amis: aicu a sunatj, neka niaken, ljakua kemeljang aken tu izua ni Muakai, maqati a ku sikisedjam sun.
English: I don't have this book, but I know Muakai has it, I can borrow it for you.

Amis: masalu, nu izuanga sukinisedjam, pavayananga tjanuaken.
English: Thank you. If you can borrow it, please bring it to me.

Amis: nanguaq, saka nu makasusuanga sun, pacikeluanga macidilj tjay Muakai.
English: Okay, but if you read it, give it back to Muakai yourself.

Amis: katiaw navaik aken katua ku qali a sematjiyam.
English: Yesterday I went to the store with a friend.
(after a verb of motion indicates movement away from the speaker)

Amis: uri nasaveneli amen ta ziting katua milimilingan a sunatj.
English: We all want dictionaries and storybooks.

Amis: matjatju veneli amen a madrusa, tu tjara ita tua mamaw a ziting.
English: As a result, we both bought an identical dictionary each.

Amis: ljakua namaretimalji a nia vineli ta milimilingan a sunatj.
English: But the storybooks we buy are different.

Amis: naveneli timadju ta “milimilingan ni Andesen”, saka naveneli aken ta “pinasutaladj tjaucikel ni Iso”.
English: He bought Hans Christian Andersen's Fairy Tales and I bought Aesop's Fables.
(used for either sex when the sex is unknown or unimportant)

Amis: maretimalji a nia vineli a sunatj, ljakua nasecengceng tua mamaw a supu na pakiyaw.
English: Although I bought a different book, the price was exactly the same.

Amis: nasaljinga ken tu macaqu a kirimu.
English: I wish I could learn it quickly.

Amis: nu macaquanga ken a venecik, tjalja saljingan aken, a u pinivarung tu patigami tjay kaka i Puljaljuyan i cadja.
English: When I learned how to write, I wanted to write to my brother Puljaljuyan, who was far away.

Amis: vaik timadju a karakuda a sema tjuzuma qinaljan i cadja, ku kinasinglitan.
English: He went to work far away in the field and I miss him.
(used for either sex when the sex is unknown or unimportant)

Amis: inika nakemljang aken tu namakuda timadju tucu a caviljan.
English: I don't know how he's doing this year.
(used for either sex when the sex is unknown or unimportant)

Amis: tucu, namalap aken ta sutigami, namaleva aravac aken.
English: I was very glad to get your letter today.

Amis: katjaisangas a qiljas, azua susinipavai a tjelu a sunatj, ku kinatjengelayan a penuljat.
English: I loved the three books you sent me last month.

Amis: nalemangedanga ken tu nakitjaulanga sun kemasi gaku, saka uri masan sinsianga sun aya.
English: I heard you graduated and are going to be a teacher.

Amis: ulja namaya ken tjanusun, nungidangida saka masan tjalja paravacan a kina tjalja saigu an tua sinsi.
English: I hope to be the best teacher I can be, just like you.

Amis: ljemita tua qadav aken a venecik tua ku niki.
English: I keep a diary every day.

Amis: ljemita tua qadav ku sivecik a ku sineljavakan a pinakakudakuda a pacugan.
English: I write down everything that happens to me every day.

Amis: nu mayatucu aken, maqati a ku sikicaquan a venecik.
English: This way, I can practice writing.

Amis: sa namaqatianan uta, sikapatudur tua ku sikatemezengan.
a ku vinecik pitua niki, liyaw aravac, uri ku kakipaqenetjan nungidangida.
English: The diary contains many memories of my future.
I want to cherish and preserve it.

Amis: azua yiubing namitung ta ljelualuas a kava.
ljemita tu qadav a sematjez ta tigami nua caucau.
English: Delivering mail for people every day.

Amis: ljaki qemudjaqudjalj, ljaki macenglanglaw a kadjunangan.
vaiken a sematjez a tigami nimadju a ljemita tua paljing.
English: He delivered each letter to each household.
(after a verb of motion indicates movement away from the speaker)

Amis: nu namalap tua tigami a caucau, namaleva aravac.
English: The people received the letter and were very happy.

Amis: saka azua yiubing namaleva aravac a pivarung uta.
English: The mailman was also satisfied in his heart.

Amis: vaik a qemaljup a tja vavulungan, qau sa sipaseljavak tua sikataqaljan katua qalialian a qinaljupan.
English: Our elders went hunting and would share their kills with fellow tribesmen and friends.
(after a verb of motion indicates movement away from the speaker)
share (joys, benefits, privileges etc) with others

Amis: nu mangetjez a mara qali a kivala a kemasi cadja, sipatjekacauan tua tjaljasanguaqan a kakanen.
English: When friends from far away come to visit, the host family will bring out the best food.

Amis: nu palisi tua qinaljan, izua maisuisu tua qavay, izua venauaua, izua cemuljuculju tua qacang.
English: Tribes hold rituals, some pound mochi, some make wine, and some slaughter pigs.
be forced to grind grain as a punishment (old)

Amis: namayatucu a nia sikakudanan tinavak a kemasi vavulung.
English: Such a life comes from our traditional habits.

Amis: rukiljavaran a vavulungan tu, “nu zemaing a ceqer, uri qemudjalj; nu zemaing a tjakanga uri qemadaw.” aya.
English: The old man used to say, "Frogs cry for rain, eagles cry for sunshine".

Amis: saka a padjaljian na aicu a kai,
nu masulesulem sa tje langda tu zemaing a ceqer, tjara uri qemudjalj nu katiyatiyaw;
English: If you hear frogs chirping in the evening, it should rain the next day;

Amis: nu kadjamadjaman sa tje langda tu zemaing a tjakanga, tjara uri macenglaw a qadav tucu.
English: If you hear an eagle cry in the morning, it must be a sunny day.

Amis: aicu a kineljangan nakemasi mamiling nua tja vuvu a tineveteveljan tua sineljavakan.
English: This knowledge was accumulated by our ancestors from ancient times.

Amis: palemek tu inika ma paqulid, ljakua nu remaketj mapasusuangata.
English: Occasionally there is distortion, but usually it is accurate.

Amis: tucu, natemulu ti sinsi tjanuamen tu malang tua kulalu.
English: Today, our teacher taught us how to make a flute.

Amis: qinati nua tja vuvu azua tu sipazaing tua senay, picul na qau a sinisanaya.
English: It was invented by our ancestors for playing songs and is made of bamboo.

Amis: nungida saka nanguaq a pakulalu itjen?
English: When can we play the flute?

Amis: ljaki nungida inika makuda a pakulalu.
English: It doesn't matter when you play the flute.

Amis: kusiayanga nu kisiazanga itjen tua sengsengan i vavua uri tjalja nanguaqan.
English: It's especially good when you're not farming.

Amis: ljakua nu izua macay tua kasusu maya pakulalu, ininuaya sepasaliu itjen tua tja palisian.
English: However, if a relative has passed away, it is forbidden to play, otherwise it would be a taboo.

Amis: a nia qinaljan uzai a “qau a tapaw”, uzai a kuvkuv katua ljaljizavan.
English: Our tribe has bamboo huts, barns and watchtowers.

Amis: azua “qau a tapaw”, makaya tu tja sika kitaljipan katua tja sika kililjingan.
English: The bamboo hut can protect us from the wind, rain and sun.

Amis: azua kuvkuv, papizuan tua tjukez a mara kakesain, ulja sikaqeceng nua kulavaw tu cakaven a keman.
English: That barn, used to store grain to keep rats from stealing it.

Amis: azua ljaljizavan, piniqayaw tua qinaljan tu siljizaw tua sigaravagavan nua qalja.
English: The watchtower, which was set up in front of the tribe to observe the movement of the enemy's strange visitors.

Amis: namaya taicu, a niamen a sepayuan a kemasi vavulungan ta sisantapavan.
English: These are the traditional buildings of our Paiwan tribe.
Paiwan, one of the indigenous peoples of Taiwan

Amis: azua i katipul a kadjunangan, a patatideq pita nia qinaljan inika nasepacadja.
English: The place of Chibun, not far from the tribe.
There are stores, a post office and a hospital.

Amis: makaya itjen a sema tiyam a veneli tua nanemanemanga.
English: We can go to the store and buy things.

Amis: maqati uta itjen a sema iubingkiyuku a zemululj ta pakiyaw, malap ta pakiyaw katua pakacu tua tigami.
English: We can also go to the post office to deposit money, collect money and send mail.

Amis: nu saqetju itjen makayanan a sema biuing a pakiqenetj tua kuisang.
English: When we are sick, we can still go to the hospital to see a doctor.

Amis: azazicu a situcuan a liningdjengedjeljan, uri tja sikasarenguaq na tja sikavaljutan.
English: All these modern facilities will make our life more convenient.

Amis: timitja amapuljat i taiwan acaucau, nu pasasupuin apairang katua kacalisian. nu maljetaiday apairang uri izua pimadrusa sakamaya akacalisian.
English: Comparing the total population of Han Chinese and Aborigines in Taiwan, only two out of one hundred are Aborigines.

Amis: tjara izua sepapamaw a kacalisian a nakemaizua ta qinaljan i gadu.
English: About half of the Aboriginal people live in the hill tribes.

Amis: azua zuma a papamaw a kacalisian makalizulizukanga mapuljat.
English: That other (other half) of the Aboriginal people already live in the flatland metropolis.

Amis: tjaliyaw a kasengsenganan i lizuk tua i gadu, djaljepan tu natjuruvu a marakac ta maqacuvucuvung sema lizuk.
English: There are more urban jobs than hill tribes, so that attracts many young people to the flatlands.

Amis: namineseganga tiamadju a kemaizua i lizuk saka masengsengseng, puvaljaw saka pualjakanga.
English: They are settled in the flatlands (urban areas) working, married and have children.
give birth to a child or children

Amis: mavan nu sikatjuruvuanga tucu nua tja kakedrian a payuan sinipualjak i lizuk patju meqaca.
English: That's why there are now many Aboriginal children born and raised in the flatlands (cities).

Amis: ljemita tua cavilj nu itua kemalje alu patju kemalje siva qiljas masalut a nia qinaljan.
English: Every August and September, our tribe holds a Harvest Festival.

Amis: aicu a qadav sinupazangal nua nia qinaljan, saka sinikatevetevelj nua tjara kinacemekemekeljan.
English: This is a particularly important day for our tribe and a time for every family to come together.

Amis: maqepu a mapuljat i zaziyanan, sa kasenay sa ziyan tu sikalevan a masalut tua kinapulami.
English: Everyone gathered on the dance floor, singing and dancing to celebrate the harvest.

Amis: tucu a cavilj natjumaq ti kama i Drangadrang katua kinacemekeljan a mapuljat, saka namakahikuki a kemasi Taipaq.
English: This year, Uncle Rangadrang and his family flew back from Taipei.

Amis: mayatucu a qivu ti kaka i Cingul, “a tiamen i Taipaq, a nia tjalja sepakinemneman, mavan a masalut nua tja qinaljan.”
English: What we miss most in Taipei is the harvest festival in our hometown," said brother Cingul.

Amis: a nia qinaljan uzai a “umaq na sevalitan” a matja ita tu papalisian tua nia kinavuvuan.
English: Our tribe has an Ancestral Spirit House for ancestral worship.

Amis: nu palisi amen tuazua “umaq na sevalitan”, patjavangan tua vasa, saviki, vawa katua vutjulj pipaljing.
English: During the ancestor worship, we put taro, betel nut, wine and meat at the door of the ancestral house.

Amis: napenaqulidangata a parakaljay a semusu tua cemacugan, saka qaqivuin tu keman a mara tja vuvu i makalizeng.
English: The priests will recite the words of the festival and invite the spirits of the ancestors to share.

Amis: a zuma nakiqaqepuan, namatjiatjiak ta lima sa meseljaseljang a semenay tua sikaladaladan, sa kaziyan tua sipapuluqeluqem sa kiqaung tu paseqeljing nua cemas.
English: Other participants hold hands while chanting ritual rhymes and dancing to pray for the blessing of their ancestors.
person skilled in certain types of work

Amis: timitja a payuan, nu matevelj a uqaljay katua vavayan, tu masan itanga, “marevaljaw” aya, saka nu masan tacekeljan anga tiamadju, “puvaljaw” aya itjen.
English: We Paiwanese say that the union of a man and a woman is called "marevaljaw", so the union of a man and a woman into a family is called "puvaljaw".
the family... (when preceded by a family name)

Amis: nu uzai a papuvaljaw i qinaljan, sinane pazangal a pacugan nua kasusu a mapuljat.
English: When someone in the tribe gets married, it's considered a big deal for the whole family.

Amis: a pasavavayan katua pasa uqaljay, uri padjulu tua vutjulj na vavui katua vaqu a vinauwa, sipaljavak tua mareka kasusu a mareka qali.
English: The families of the married couple prepare mountain pig meat and millet wine for their relatives and friends.

Amis: azua sirakeraketj a ’uqaljay a vavayan matatekel ta langalj saka marepaukuz.
English: The groom and bridegroom will drink from each other's cups and give each other wedding gifts.

Amis: qaw temulu a matjaljaljak tjaimadju, sa pakaleva katua mareka tjaqaljaqaljan tjaimadju.
English: The elders will give them a lecture and then the guests will celebrate them.

Amis: tucu a qadav nia kitjaula tua kungkuan.
English: Today is the day we graduate from school.

Amis: na qemaqivu tua matjaljaljak a nia kungkuan tu seman pakicakar tjanuamen.
English: The school asked the elders to organize a Bar Mitzvah for us.

Amis: paqaqayamen amen nua ramaljemaljeng tua penanaq.
English: The elders let us compete in archery.

Amis: azua naqemacuvung tua kicakar a situ, makayanga a kipu ljakaraw.
English: Those students who pass the Bar/Bat Mitzvah are allowed to wear headdresses.

Amis: sikainulian amen nua nia matjaljaljak, qaw papupiculan amen sa tuluan amen tua kisamulja nu karakuda.
English: The elders blessed us, encouraged us and taught us to take things seriously.

Amis: nu lemangda itjen tua ljingaw nua sipakitjaulaula a senay saka paljitaljitain itjen a ljesasaw tua kungkuan, sa tje patagiljanga djaravacanga pitua naljevaquan a djalan tu kinaqatian.
English: As soon as we heard the stainless steel song, we left the school one by one and started to walk towards a new stage of life.
the thing stuck between the teeth
at the foot of the mountain
witchcarft appliance (witch doctor use it for treatment)
peeling the bark of a tree
calling (e.g. calling before feeding the chickens)
dry (e.g., drying clothes in the sun)
pack up (imperatives, as in pack up)
fishing for fish and shrimp by cage
lift off (as in lift off the lid).
burn (as in burning the hair of prey)
marry to a non-ethnic clan member
undercooked (if this piece of meat is raw)
fragile (e.g. this wire is prone to breakage)
in the process of (doing something or happening)

Amis: patagilj anga kitulu, tjumaq ti sinsi i tatuluan, qivu a nia penuvuluvulung, “gacalju! kisukubi! aya.”
English: It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

Amis: pasiqaca amen a qivu ta, “navenala sun sinsi aya amen.”
ka kitulutulu amen, tuluan amen ni sinsi tua supu nua kinacalisianan.
English: In class, the teacher taught us the paiwan language of numbers.

Amis: kilayng amen tjay sinsi a semupu, semenay amen tua sasupuan a senay.
English: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

Amis: liav anga aravac a ku kinacaqu a kinacalisianan.
English: I have learned many paiwan languages.

Amis: piqadav aken a sema kakituluan, piqadav aken a kicaquan tua kinacalisianan, muri ku siqayvu a palangda tjay kina.
English: I go to school every day, I learn the paiwan language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

Amis: a ngadan ni kama ti Karuqu.
a ngadan ni kina ti Paules.
tucu a cavilj tapuluq anga ku cavilj.
macidilj a ku kaka a uqaljay a tjavulung, ti Qipu a ngadan nimadju, tapuluq katu ita a cavilj nimadju a tucu a cavilj.
English: I have a brother, his name is Qipu, he is 11 years old.

Amis: itua taytan a nia supusupuan a kakituluan.
English: We study in the same school.

Amis: tiaken kati kaka i Qipu tjengelay amen a semenay.
English: Both my brother and I like to sing.

Amis: tjengelay aken a ljemanguy, nu i putideq a qadav, tiamen a tacemekeljan vayk amen a maciuciur a ljemanguy.
English: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

Amis: tjengelay aken a kisekeljangan tua adju, makaya amen a maciur a semenay kata ljemanguy.
English: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

Amis: imazi i akav a nia umaq.
man lima a pipenuljatan a nia kinacemekeljan.
English: There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

Amis: a nia kinacemekeljan matjelu amen a marekakakaka.
English: There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

Amis: a ku kinacemekeljan izua it kama, ti kina, tia kaka katua tiaken.
English: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

Amis: kisacu a ku kama, saka qacaqaca aravac a kinalingdjeljan.
English: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

Amis: sirupucemel a ku kina, saka kuljakuljay aravac a kinacavacavan.
English: My mother is thin and she is a doctor.

Amis: nu i tjumaq ti kama kemacalisianan tjanuamen.
English: My father speaks the paiwan language with us at home.

Amis: nu kalja pulavayan tua kaljazulezulan vayk amen a pasa qinaljan.
English: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

Amis: maciur amen katia kaka a kikiav.
English: My brother and sister and I will catch frogs together.

Amis: tjengelay aken aravac tua nia kinacemekeljan.
English: I like our family very much.

Amis: vayk amen a kivangavang kati kina tucu a qadav.
English: I went out with my mother today.

Amis: namalingling a kalevelevan nu kamauqadavan, ika zalangzang ika vucelelj a kinaqadaqadavan, sarunguanguaq a vali.
English: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

Amis: keman amen tua pang itua cauciuci a kadjunangan, cenglaven a nia kinacavacavan , maseljec amen aravac.
English: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.
In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

Amis: kivadaq aken tjay kina, akuzua medjaljar a kalevelevan ku ayain.
English: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

Amis: matucu ti kina, palemek tu muri mangtjez anga raljiz aya.
English: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

Amis: neka nu qurepus i kalevelevan tucu a qezemezemetj, sevacaq anga a vitjuqan.
English: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

Amis: muri pasa umaq anga amen uta.
ka pasa umaumaq i djalan, kiligu aken tua vitjuqan.
English: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

Amis: tu ika mangtjez a raljiz, navenarung aken tua vaykanan a masasav.
English: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

Amis: a nia kakituluan izuwa i tjuljivar ta nia umaq, piqadav aken a djemavac a sema kakituluan, sake djavac uta pasa umaq.
English: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

Amis: inika kudral a nia kakituluan, inika tjuruvu a kitulutulu, namakakeljakeljang amen a masantalj.
English: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

Amis: azua kakedrian a mapuljat namaqepuqepu i kakilaciqan, sa meseljaseljang a benudru, a semanljavaran.
English: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

Amis: a mareka sinsi kiseljang tjanuamen uta kivangavang, aicu a nia kakituluan matu tacemkeljan.
English: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

Amis: piqadav amen a semuap, nia suapan a ljemenguaq aza tatuluan.
English: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

Amis: izua vayk a zemuking tua qezung, izua vayk a semuap.
English: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

Amis: vayk amen uta semuap tua mareka i putuputung tua kakituluan, nia sikarasudj sa nia sikapangapangalj a sengesengan, namaljenguaq a piqadav a nia kakituluan.
English: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

Amis: tatiav, kasiqinaljan aken a na ljemilji tjay vuvu i Ubak.
English: Yesterday, I went to visit my Ubak grandpa in the tribe.

Amis: cuacuay anga amen a ika mecevucevung, singelit anga aken aravac tjaymadju.
English: We haven’t seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

Amis: ka pacun ti vuvu i Ubak tjanuaken, pakanan aken tua siasiak, sake patekeli tua uca.
English: As soon as Ubak grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

Amis: aza talem ni vuvu i Ubak a siasiak qaljemeqem aravac, paqulid tu sanguaq angata.
English: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

Amis: tjengelay aken uta tua uca ni vuvu i Ubak, sanguaq aravac nu tja tekelen.
English: I also like grandpa’s tea, it’s tasted good too.

Amis: ka kincengecengelj, kemsa amen kati vuvu i Muni tua cengelj.
English: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

Amis: namakakaizuazua a kinsa cengelj ni vuvu i Muni, izua ciqav, kuka, ljasiak katua cirat.
English: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

Amis: nu nakincengelj anga itjen, vayk anga sema puljacengan a kiljaceng.
English: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

Amis: malap tu liav ta vurasi, ta vasa katua laukiu ti vuvu i Muni, tua sipakacu tjanuaken a pasa umaq.
English: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

Amis: ku kipusauan tiamadju, sa ku kipazazekati tu mangetezanan aken nu tjayvililj a ljemilji tjayamadju.
English: I said goodbye to them and said I’d see them next time.

Amis: kinacu amen a vuaq nua nia sinsi a sema puqemuzimuzipan, na kitaljizan amen izuwa i sitjumaq tua paljing a veneli tua kipu.
English: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

Amis: ka temdep anga amen izuwa i puqemuzimuzipan, qivu aza nia sinsi: ”aicu i paqayaqayav a mareka qayaqayam, azua i pasalikuz a mareka qatjuvi, vayku a masatalj a kitju talidu aya.”
English: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

Amis: marekutj aken ta qatjuvi, vanasika ika aken a talidu ta qatjuvi.
English: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

Amis: pacun anga aken tua liav aravac a qayaqayam, i vavav tua kasiv tiamadju a kipasasivasivalj a mipereper, izua uta ku pinacunan a ljequ a nataqed itua buang nua kasiv.
English: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

Amis: azua i puqemuzimuzipan izua zau, rigi kata likuljav, inia ke pacun tua mareka qemuzimuzip a kemasicuay, tucu a vauaq a qadav kanapacun anga aken maleva aken aravac.
English: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

Amis: liav aravac a ku pinasiasingan, sa ku papacunan tjay kama kati kina.
English: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

Amis: nu tjayvililj uri kiciur aken tjay kama kati kina a semamaza.
English: Next time I will come with my parents.

Amis: tucu nu sipulavayan a qadav, vayk amen kati kaka i Babay a sema Valangau a kivala tjay kama i Kuliv.
English: This holiday, my sister Baby and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle Kuliv.

Amis: na makavavav amen tua ljiuk a kemasi taipaq a pasa valangan.
English: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

Amis: ka djemaljun amen i valangan, kicacevungen amen a mapupalidringan tua palidring ni kama i Kuliv.
English: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

Amis: azua pupalidringan inika cadja tua umaq ni kama i Kuliv, nu makavavav itjen tua palidring palamu satje djaljun.
English: The station is not far from my uncle’s house, and it’s just a short drive away.

Amis: azua i dudut tua umaq ni kama i Kuliv izua za maljekudral a papaquzipan tua qemuzimuzip, vayk amen a maka tulay a maciur a sema papaquzipan tua qemuzimuzip.
English: There is a big ranch near my uncle’s house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

Amis: ka izua amen i papaquzipan tua qemuzimuzip, kacuin amen ni kama i Kuliv a pakan tua sizi katua tjevavav tua rigi.
English: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

Amis: ka qezemezemetj, vayk amen a maciur a sema lemizukan a keman.
English: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

Amis: azua i lemizukan liav aravac a palidring, vanasika namaka utubay amen a pasa zuwa.
English: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

Amis: ka muri pasa vayk amen, manu cinakav anga utubay, pay pasa amin anga nia makavavav tua basu a vayk izuwa.
English: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

Amis: tucu djemaljun anga amen i taipaq, qadjav tuki namadjumak anga a utubay ni kama i Kuliv.
English: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don’t know if my uncle’s motorcycle has been found.

Amis: ka kakedrian aken imaza i kazangiljan a nia umaq, ka kitulu anga aken, setavat anga amen a mamaza i Akav, imaza amen sakamaya i lizuk a kikavaljuvaljut.
English: When we were young, our family lived in Chiayi. After I started school, we moved to Pingtung and have been living in the city ever since.

Amis: ka semupu anga aken tua sikipakelayan a kakituluan, kitulu aken tu masan italj tua pakata kakudakudan nua kacalisian a kakituluin, silautan tua namakakaizuazua namalavi a kakudakudan nua i taivang a kacalisian.
English: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

Amis: vanasika, tucu a cavilj nu sikalja pulavayan tua kaljazulezulan, muri vayk amen kati kaka i Cemelesay a sema qinaljan a kivavadaq tua vavulungan, navenarung amen tu lemaut tua driniungan nua nia kakudakudan.
English: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

Amis: azua vavulungan alu anga puluq a cavilj, ljakua nu tjapacunan matu i cengeceng a kinacaviljan.
English: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

Amis: ku kivadaqan timadju tu anemanema nu kayan a kacaquin, aza nimadju a Vinuculjan(Pinaiwanan) sulapiq a siqaqivuan, macaqu uta qivu tua Drinkayan, Kinilangan kata Drinipungan.
English: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in Paiwan, as well as Rukai, Hakka and Japanese.

Amis: ka ku kivadaqan anga timadju kemljang anga aken, tu manu kemasi kedrikedri a kicaquan tua [Drinipungan, a cekelj seRukai, au aza itua sengesengan nasekeljang tua tjuruvu aravac a Kilang, vanasika liav a kacaquin a kay nimadju.
English: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Rukai, and he knows many Hakkas at work, so he can speak so many languages.

Amis: nu kivadavadaq amen, aza ramaljemaljeng masan lialiav aravac a pakata kinasicuay a kinljangan tua siqaljupan a sipareqaivuivu.
English: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

Amis: uitu inika amen a makapucug a pipenuljatan, ljakua nia sinipuseqetj anga paseqailjungan a pitua pinilima a ljingas, makaya siumaljanan sa sileqeleq a kisalangda.
English: Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

Amis: ka kakedrianan aken ika aken a nalemaut tua kakudakudan nua ku kinadriungan, pitua ku kinakacalisianan izua za ku siaqan.
English: When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

Amis: nu tjaliav anga ku linaut, patjazua ku kinavarungan tua kinasePaiwanan, na remamur a kinisumaljian, mapuqata uta a simiazuan.
English: The more I know, the more I feel that being a Paiwan is unique and something to be proud of.

Amis: tucu a qadav nu masulesulem, muri sema umaq a ku kaka ti Ljegeay.
English: My younger brother Ljegeay is going home this evening.

Amis: na vayk amen kati vuvu i Sauniav a matatakayan a veneli tua kuka, muri nia kesain a semanguanguaq tua pinadjulu tu kaiven ni Ljegeay a ku kaka.
English: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

Amis: ka cemalivat amen tua temakatakay ta ljaceng, aza sitakatakay a ljaceng liva anan azua namilidji a tjaukaljaceng.
English: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

Amis: na veneli anga amen tua incay, tua qaqilj kata qudidilj a caytav.
English: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

Amis: aza i tjuljivar a temakatakay tua vangalj a rutakatakay qivu a matucu, “aicu a ku pangudral kata qudis qaljemeqem aravac. pay veliu a pupida lja aya!”
English: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

Amis: na veneli amen tua pangudral kata qudis.
ka cemalivat amen tua temakatakay tua vutjulj, aza rutakatakay qivu a matucu, “anema su velin? aicu a kuka a vuaq kakudralan saka na venutjulj, nu taitan tjelu a iday a vatanan.” aya.
English: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

Amis: paka pazangal aravac ti vuvu i Sauniav, pay sa kivadaq tua za rutakatakay tu aki makaya patjamadjuluin.
English: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

Amis: ljakua azua rutakatakay matucu sinipumadjulu anga aravac, inika anga makaya patjamadjuluin aya.
English: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

Amis: azuwa i ljaqedi a rutakatakay matucu a qivu, kelju veliu tua ku ciqav, aicu a ku ciqav kakudrakudralan saka madjulu aya.
English: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

Amis: ka vililj anga veneli anga amen tua kuka sane veli uta tua ciqav, sa satjumaq a kemsa tu tadataran tua djamay.
English: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

Amis: cuay anga kiljaljavaljava, mizemzem anga qadav.
English: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

Amis: na papangtjez tua ljingas a ku kaka ti Ljegeay a matucu, na papintjus aza i pusivitjayan tu inika makaya pulavay, nu tjaivililj anga sipulavayan a qinadavan mana mangtjez anga aken aya.
English: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

Amis: matucu a qivu ti vuvu i Sauniav liav a ku kinsa, pay pukanui a masantalj aya.
English: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

Amis: na cemged amen tua mareka nia vetjek tua nia adjuadju, a kipumangtjez a kipatjinguaq tua napenakakaizuan a kaiven.
English: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

Amis: izua za ku seljaseljang a ti Cumay, ru alim a kemacu ta nemanga.
English: I have a classmate named Cumay, he often forgets to bring things.

Amis: nu sikitulutuluan, kisedjam timadju tua seljaseljang ta sivecivecik, ta siquliqulip katu vavecikan.
English: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

Amis: si kintalj, si kinmusalj, si kintjelulj a nemanga sipasedjasedjam tjaimadju niamen a masantalj.
English: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

Amis: ljakua izua za nakuya a kakudan nimadju, ru kisedjam tua nema sa ika pacikel.
English: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

Amis: ka vililj anga neka anga nu venarung tua pasedjam tu nemanga tjanuamen a pimasantaljan.
English: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

Amis: izua ka itua tu qadav, vayk amen a maciur a masantalj a kivangavang.
English: One day, we all went on an outing together.

Amis: ka i djalan tazua, manu malingav ti Cumay tu masausavan, ljakua namalim timadju a masi qucic.
English: On the way, Cumay wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

Amis: pasa kisedjam timadju tua nia seljaseljang ta qucic, ljakua nia tevelain a masantalj, tu ika aken a nakemacu uta niayain.
English: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn’t bring them either.

Amis: manu patjeljaqaung ti Cumay ka maqutjav, madudu timadju sa mayatucu, aku ika aken a nu pasedjaman tua qucic a masantalj aya!
English: Cumay burst into tears. He said angrily, why don’t everyone lend me toilet paper!

Amis: pasemalavan timadju nua seljaseljang, ayatua ika sun a kitju kacu tua nemanga, sa aza sinipasedjam tjanusun a nemanga, ika sun angata a pacikel ayain!
English: The classmate told him, because you didn’t bring it yourself, and you wouldn’t return the things lent to you!

Amis: ka macepeliv a qadav tua sisa kakituluan, na medjama sa djaljun i kakituluan ti Cumay, sa aza mareka kinisedjasedjam tua seljaseljang ni Cumay a nemanga pacikelen tjanuamen a seljaseljang.
English: The next day at school, Cumay arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

Amis: kipaqaljay tjanuamen a seljaseljang ti Cumay, sa mayatucu timadju kemasi tucu a qadav tjara kitju kacu anga aken tua nemanga aya, maljimalji uta tua tjanumun a ku seljaseljang aicu a sitjaisangasan a nasecalivat anga pukauy mun a pasedjama tua nemanga tjanuaken aya.
English: Cumay apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

Amis: ti kama namasan ruqaljuqaljup i qinaljan.
English: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

Amis: ka kakedrian aken, ti kama kati kama i Kuljelje nu salilim a sivaivaik a sasav, sa namasi takit kata kuang.
English: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

Amis: nu quljan anga, mangtjez anga tiamadju a namasi qinaljup.
English: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

Amis: izua nu vavuy, izua nu lava, izua uta nu namasi padavatan.
English: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

Amis: tiamadju pangaljen aza qinaljup, sa pangapangaljan tua sikataqaljan.
English: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

Amis: nuaya makaljavay aken, tua kiayan tjaikama a qemaljup.
English: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

Amis: matucu ti kama nu ljemtu anga sun ku ciurav anga a kemacu aya.
English: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

Amis: aza i qinaljan a uqaljaqaljay macaqu uta puraung tua sacemel, macaqu tiamadju a puseluc kata puqacev.
English: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

Amis: macaqu aravac ti kama seman puseluc, matucu ti kama, aicu a sidjamedjameq tua padavatan, tjagetjemen a kileqeleq a djinkapan nua sacemel, aicu a sinipuraung tjapizuain itua sinangalivan nua sacemel aya.
English: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

Amis: tua sikitaluan a kiayan tua tjavavulungan a qemaljup, piqdav aken a kicaquan tua seman qaljangetj, ika nacuay aza ku sinan puraung makay anga paqulid a djemameq tua sacemel.
English: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

Amis: ka napacun anga ti kama mayatucu tjanuaken nu tjaivililj tjara sun a masan djuljam tua siqaljupan aya.
English: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

Amis: tucu ljemtu anga aken, ku siniljavac a semevalj aza ku tiveljatan kata vakela, sake vayk a kiciur tjaikama a qemaljup.
English: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

Amis: ka djemaljun amen i qinaljan nia sipangapangalj a semiljeva za nia qadav tua nia sikataqaljan.
English: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

Amis: matucu ti kama, maleva itjen tua papumanguaqan nua tja tjaisangasangas, saka izua sa liav aravac a tja qimang aya.
English: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

Amis: ka kadjaman na gemalju aken a talu gaku.
English: I was late for school this morning.

Amis: ku alimen a ku kaban, ka ma gaku aken.
English: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.
I didn’t bring anything with me.

Amis: miseljan amen ka ta ku ali a pacun tua hon ni madju, ka sumupusupu amen.
English: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

Amis: pinasedjam aken tua sisupisupil, ka ta inpic naku ali ka sikin amen.
English: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

Amis: ivu aniya sinsi tja nuaken “maya sa gemaljuanga midjamau a paceked!”
English: The teacher told me, “Wake up earlier next time and don’t be late again!”

Amis: tji sulja ku ali a ravac a ljak na kacalisia a nguta tji madju.
English: My good friend’s name is sulja, and he is also an paiwan child.

Amis: ku salad a sumupu i djiniljepan.
English: We study together in the djiniljepan tribe.

Amis: lemandandamen tua sinimilingang kemasi tu nija vavulungna si ka makeyamen na kemacalisyanang.
English: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Paiwan proficiently.

Amis: acaaca aken kurakural aken tji silja kerikeri’ sa kuljakuljai a ngauta.
English: I am tall and overweight, while sulja is short and thin.

Amis: ginki tji sulja, tjengelai ya tjimaimanga
English: sulja is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

Amis: undukaidukai a nia gaku a tucu, masanliau a kamuku a ru si pisaipisai.
English: Today was the school’s sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

Amis: izua mavaviljevilj, temukurus tu a mali, zemian kata penana’.
English: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

Amis: na matjani a ken ka mekekelj,saka na pedjamu’ a ku cunganlj.
English: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

Amis: ljakua, ,migacal a ekn sa mekelj a pacusu.
English: But I stood up and continued running forward.

Amis: ka macuvung a ken, na maleva a tjimaimanga.
English: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

Amis: sa ini’ kaken a na tjamakaya, ljkua maleva aken tu ku ina cuvun.
English: Although I didn’t get first place, I’m glad because I completed the race.

Amis: na vaik aken ka tji kama a ljemizau tjai kama i paljan.
English: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

Amis: na mapasae’tju a kula ni kama i paljan.
pasemalau tji kama i paljan tja nuamen aza uma’ nji madju na mabuan a za alju.
English: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

Amis: ka ljemungua’ tji madju makelu a kema si alju.
English: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

Amis: tji kama na kemacu tu a vutjul na ljuan kata saviki aru sipantez tjai kama i paljan.
English: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

Amis: na imilad aken katji kama i paljan i ta tataedan ni madju sa pasemalamalau tja nu ken ta canalivatan ni madju.
English: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

Amis: ka ru vaik anganken zemenger tji kama i paljan tja nuaken na mea’canga sa saua’lai yanga sun aya.
English: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

Amis: nu sarungua’ angang su kula kivalau a matja nuamen ayaken na kipusau tji kama i paljan.
English: I said, “When your foot gets better, come to our house next time and visit us.”

Amis: ka 2022 a cavilje a tja sihu ljemaui tu makayanga akipavecik tua tjia kinacalisianan a ngadan pita nibonsiu.
English: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

Amis: na kiaivuan aken tu na kisamulja cuacuai a tji sulja pakata venecik a pita nibonsiu a kinacalisian a ngadan.
English: I interviewed sulja, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

Amis: na mareaivu amen. tu micevun nu niciu a mata uma’ nji madu.
English: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

Amis: ka tazua, pasemalauvin a ken tu a na kemasinu sa ngada nji madju sa siukai tua matjaljaljak kata inljan nji madju.
English: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

Amis: kivada’ aken nakuya a tja sikivecikan na tjucu aku sun a kiaun tu paumaljin?
English: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

Amis: temevela tji madju, a ljinautjian na vinecikan ini’ ka makaya lemuluai tua ku kinacalisianangn a ngadan mapasaliukamaya liau a napasamli sa sikapedjelian.
English: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Shu Xian Sheng

Amis: na ivu tji sulja a kinacalisianang a sivecikan pa’ulid tu njitjen na ngadan. njitjen na zukuan tja kina cemekeljan atja djmu’ ulja na makaya a tjatjuruvu a caucau a kipavecik tuatja kinacalisianang a ngadan.
English: cemelesai said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

Amis: ka tjiyau vaik amen ka tji vuvu a sema papaveliyan a paveli,na kemacu tji vuvu tu a makara ljacen,sa na seman kakanen a ngauta ta ru sipaveli.
English: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

Amis: tjenglai a caucau tua nji vuvu a siubai, aza silji kata ljameljam mapa veli a ravac, sa tjuruvu a ngautan a caucau tu keman ta kinesa nji vuvu.
English: Everyone loved my grandmother’s stall. Many people bought the chilis and ginger, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

Amis: aza cinavu ka ta pinu ljameljam a kinsa kata pinu makau a vutjulj na vavui salum sa na masiup pa makara caucau sa tjuruvu a na paitui i ta na siubai.
English: The taro buns and ginger rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

Amis: nu kemesakesa tji vuvu tjaken a paveliveli, sa ku pasiaca a zemalazala. tjiamen a na tejmalem ini’ a  katjedukuan kelju kelju veliu.
English: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

Amis: palamu maka paveli a ngamen. tjisun sa na makaya tjen na mayatucu aya tji vuvu a ivu tja nuaken.
English: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, \It’s all thanks to your help.\""

Amis: aicu a njia kinianan a siubaibbai liau angan ku kineljan a pa ka tana kacalisian a djami a kakanen sa na pavavalanga ken tu zelian nu siubaibai.
English: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

Amis: a puvarungan kata tjengelaiyan nji vuvu tua kakaen na kinacalisianan na masi miazuan kata masilevan aken a ravac.
English: Seeing my grandmother’s passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.
the thing stuck between the teeth
at the foot of the mountain
witchcarft appliance (witch doctor use it for treatment)
peeling the bark of a tree
calling (e.g. calling before feeding the chickens)
dry (e.g., drying clothes in the sun)
pack up (imperatives, as in pack up)
fishing for fish and shrimp by cage
lift off (as in lift off the lid).
burn (as in burning the hair of prey)
marry to a non-ethnic clan member
undercooked (if this piece of meat is raw)
fragile (e.g. this wire is prone to breakage)
in the process of (doing something or happening)

Amis: nasuljivat mun. tucu uri temulu ti sinsi tjanumun tua kemuda a qivu ta lami na kacalisiyan.
English: Hello everyone. Today I am going to teach you how to say Paiwan for food.

Amis: pulingalingav mun ta kai ni sinsi?
English: Do you understand what the teacher says?

Amis: sinsi, inika ken a pulingalingav. makaya sun a qivu a kingtalj anga?
English: I don’t understand. Can you repeat it again?

Amis: inika ken a lemangdanda, makaya pasiqaca a pagalju?
English: I can’t hear you, can you speak louder?

Amis: pai pacunu a pasa maza! kisaseljangu tjanuaken a semupu.
English: Look here, please! Repeat after me.

Amis: supu-u a kingtalj anga. pai pasiqaca-u.
English: Read it again. Please speak louder.

Amis: sinsi, malim anga ken a kemacu ta ku inpic.
English: I forgot to bring my pen.

Amis: sinsi, malim anga ken a kemacu ta si’uli’ulip.
English: I forgot to bring my eraser.

Amis: kisedjamu tjai tjaqedjiqedji a su salasaladj.
English: Please borrow erasers from your classmates.

Amis: siputidetideqan anga zikan tua tja kitulu.
tja patjemaza-u a tja kitulu, cevucevungi anga nu tjaivililj.
English: Class dismissed, see you next week.

Amis: aljak aken ni masegseg, ti kui aken.
English: I am masegseg’s son, my name is kui.

Amis: situ aken ni masegseg, ti kui aken.
English: I am a student of tjanubak, my name is kui.
Who is he? He is baru.

Amis: ku kaka timadju, ti camak timadju.
English: He’s my brother, his name is camak.

Amis: ui, ti camak a ngadan nimadju.
ti camak a ngadan nimadju? ini, ti kui a ngadan nimadju.
English: Is his name camak? No, his name is Kui.

Amis: ti pales timadju. ti kina i pales.
English: She’s pales. she’s my aunt pales.

Amis: ku drava timadju, ti muni a ngadan nimadju.
English: She is my friend, her name is muni.

Amis: tapuluq katu drusa a cavilj nimadju.
lima a puluq a cavilj ni kama.

English: How many brothers and sisters do you have?

Amis: izua madrusa tia kaka kata ku kaka a macidjilj.
English: I have two brothers and sisters and one younger brother and sister.

Amis: neka a ku kaka a uqaljay.

English: How many people are in your family?
There are four of us in our family.

Amis: anema a sengsengan ni tjama i kui?
English: What does your uncle Kui do for a living?

Amis: izua a sengsengan ni su kaka?
English: Does your sister have a job?

Amis: ui, paiwan zuku aken a kacalisian.
English: Yes, I am an aboriginal of the Paiwan tribe.

Amis: ui, tiamen a tacekeljan ’aca’aca amen a mapuljat.
English: Yes, we are all very tall.

Amis: kitulutulu anga a su kaka i gakku?
English: Does your sister go to school?

Amis: ui, kitulutulu anga i gakku timadju.
macaqu a kemacalisianan a su kaka?
English: Do your siblings speak the language?
Yes, they speak the ethnic language.
How many brothers and sisters do you have?
I have three brothers and sisters.
Do you live with your parents?

Amis: ui, nakiteveljan aken ta ku matjaljaljak.
English: Yes, I live with my mom and dad.
Do you live with your grandparents?

Amis: ini, inika ken a nakitateveljan tjaimadju.
English: No, I didn’t live with them.

Amis: nakiteveljan aken tjai kama kina kaka a uqaljay.
English: I live with my father, mother and brother.

Amis: nungida vaik sun a sema qinaljan?
English: When are you going back to the tribe?

Amis: nu pulavalavay tua kaljazalanzangan vaik aken sa kamaya.
English: I will go back in the summer.

Amis: tevuta anga a qadav, nazalangzan a kinaqadavan.
English: The sun is coming out, it's very hot.
Is it going to be cold outside?
It's very cold, so wear lots of clothes.

Amis: tucu a vuaq inika vucelelj inika zalangzang, nasulapelj.
English: It's neither cold nor hot today, very comfortable.

Amis: tucu a vengin namakuda a kinaqadavan?
neka nu qerepus i kalevelevan, tevutavuta a qiljas.
English: There were no clouds in the sky; the stars came out.

Amis: tjau meljay a qadav kasawni, maqadav anga, tevutanga a ’uljivangeraw.
English: The rain has just stopped, the sun has come out, the rainbow is coming out.

Amis: namakuda a kinaqadavan izua i tjanusun?
English: What's the weather like where you are?
We're going to have a big storm here.
Good, the sun is coming out.
I have to go to school.

Amis: vucelelj a kinaqadavan, itung ngu a pakaliyav.
English: The weather is very cold, so wear more clothes.

Amis: uri vaik anga ken a sema masasaw.
nusauni palj’aca a qemudjalj, paqenetju anga kemacu ta qausua.
English: It's going to rain heavily, you have to remember to bring an umbrella.
There was thunder just now, and it's supposed to rain later.

Amis: namaya ta naqemudjalj anga, teveteveng a djalan.
English: It seems to have rained and the road is wet.

Amis: naqemudjalj? aku saljeveljever a su kinacavacavan?
English: Is it raining? Why are you all wet?

Amis: qemudjaqudjalj a i sasaw, inika ken a namasi qausua.
English: It's raining outside, so I didn't bring an umbrella.

Amis: kudral a vali, saqetju a ku qulu ta vinalian.
English: The wind is blowing so hard that my head hurts.

Amis: paramur a qadav, malingac a ku qulu ta kinirasian.
English: The sun is so big, it makes me dizzy.

Amis: malim anga ken a kemacu ta ku inpic.
English: I forgot to bring my pen.

Amis: malim anga ken a kemacu ta ku qecap.

Amis: inika ken a nakemacu, vaiki a kiveli.
English: I don't have one either, let's go buy one.

Amis: makaya vaik itjen a kiveli ta inpic?
English: Let's go buy a pen, shall we?

Amis: ui, uri veneli anan aken ta si’uli’ulip.
English: Well, I still have to buy erasers.

Amis: ari vaiki a kiveli ta kenamain?
English: Come on, let's go get some breakfast, shall we?

Amis: caqen, nakeman anga ken i tjumaq.
English: No, I've already eaten at home.

Amis: malim anga ken a semljec ta ku bintu.
English: I forgot to steam my lunchbox.

Amis: malim anga ken a kemacu ta ku bintu.
English: I forgot to bring my lunchbox.

Amis: pai kani a madrua ta ku bintu.
English: Then let's eat my lunch box together!

Amis: uri anema su kanen nu kingcengecengelj?
English: What are you having for lunch?

Amis: keman aken ta cengelj i gakku.

Amis: anema uri su kanen nu kincengelj?
English: What are you having for lunch?

Amis: nakemacu aken ta bintu, kanianga madrusa.

Please help me with the broom.

Amis: ui, ku sipavayan tjanusun aicu a ljaljumay.
English: Okay, here's a broomstick for you.
Can you get me a rag, please?

English: I'm sweeping the floor, you ask Kui to help you.

Amis: qiljaqiljan aicu a kasintan, sau zukinguanan.
English: The floor is dirty, go clean it.

Amis: ui, vaik aken a malap ta zuking.

Amis: mayanan, ini anan aku makasuap tai maza.

Amis: uri vaik aken a karim tjai sinsi.
English: I'm going to see my teacher.

Amis: nu nakemasi gakku sun uri kemudad sun?

Amis: uri vaik amen kata ku salasalad a semenay.
English: I'm going to sing with my friends.

Amis: nu nakemasi gakku timadju uri kemuda?

English: She’s at home, please come in.
May I ask if Ljavaus is at home?
She’s not here, what can I do for you?

Amis: vuvu, ti pales aken suqeljevi a paljing.
English: Grandpa, I’m pales please open the door.

Amis: patagaw, ti pales aken, muri kivangavang aken tjanusun.
English: patagaw, I’m pales, I’ve come to play with you.

Amis: cuacuay anga itjen a inika mecevang.
ui lja! nasinglit aken tjanusun. pai kelju pasalinglingliti.
English: Yeah! I miss you so much. Come on, let’s chat!
Please sit down and have some tea.

Amis: u! sanguaq aravc a nu quciya.
ui! napesanguaq nutjapacunan aicu a kudamunu.
nakemesa anga ti kina ta kaiven, kelju kanu!

Okay, I’ll go wash my hands.

Amis: kanu a pakaliyav, ini sun a ’ali’ali.

Amis: liyav anga ku kinan, mavetu anga ken aravac.
English: I ate a lot, I was very full.

Amis: uri vaik anga ken, ku ljizavau anga sun nutjaivililj.

Amis: salilim anga, vaik anga ken a tjumaq.
ui, nu izua su zikang kelju anga a kivangavang.
English: Okay, come to my house sometime.

Amis: nasuljivat mun. tucu a vuaq uri kemacu ti sinsi tjanumun a sema qinaljan a kivadaq ta vavulungan.
English: Hello everyone, today I’m taking you to the tribe to interview the elders.

Amis: pai pariya! uri kiqaqivuan amen ta vavulungan tua pinayuanan a kai.
English: Okay! We have to speak Paiwanese to the seniors.

Amis: vuvu, mangtjez amen a ljemizav tjanusun.
English: Grandpa, we’ve come to see you.

Amis: na! manu macaqu mun a kemacalisianan a qivu ayau! qa! pai pariyangata!
English: You guys speak Paiwanese! That’s great!

Amis: nasuljivat mun. tucu a vuaq uri kacuin mun ni sinsi a sema puvaquan a masengseng.
English: Hello everyone, today I will take you to work in the millet field.

Amis: kelju samazau a matjatjiljitiljv, pa’enetju anga kemacu ta nuturivecan.
English: Come and line up, remember to bring your tools.

Amis: ui sinsi, nia inalapanga a nia turivecan.
English: Yes, sir, we’ve got our tools.
Not yet, it’s still far away.
You go get the bird catcher.
Okay, I’ll go and catch the birds.

Amis: nasuljivat mun. tucu uri vaik itjen a sema zua itua kakataliduan tua ’emuzi’uzip.
English: Hello everyone, we are going to the zoo today.

Amis: aicu a pariya! aki anema uri tja pakazuanan a sema zua ayau?
English: Awesome! How are we going to get there?

Amis: tjevavav itjen ta basu a sema zua.
matatiljitiljivu, uri padulu-i anga itjen a kiveli ta kipu.
English: Everyone line up, we are ready to buy tickets.

Amis: a i tjaiqayav mareka qayaqayam, a i tjailikuz mareka ’atjuvi, talidu a kisumadju.
English: There are birds in the front and snakes in the back.
It doesn’t matter, then you go and watch the birds.

Amis: nu djemaljun ta icizikang pangtjez-i anga ki’epuan.

Amis: napacun aken ta liyav a ’atjuvi, izua uta liyav a ’aya’ayam.
English: I saw a lot of snakes and a lot of birds.

tjuruvu a cawcau imaza a ljemanguljanguy.

Amis: vacalj a izua zaljum, tjemaza-i sakamaya a ljemanguy.
English: The water is deep there, so we just swim here.

Amis: anema su tjevavavan a sema kiukay?
English: What bus do you take to church?

Amis: pivavaven aken ta zidusia ni kama a sema zua.
nukazumazuman kemuda timadju a sema gakku?

Amis: tjevavav tua napatjatjeketjak a tjatjevavavan timadju a sema kakituluan.
English: He took the subway to school.

Amis: kemuda ti su vuvu nu vaik a kiveli ta ljaceng?
English: How does your grandmother go to the grocery store?

Amis: ki’utubay timadju nu vaik a kiljaceng.
English: She went to the grocery store on a motorcycle.

Amis: uri kemuda sun a vaik a sema Langi?
English: How are you going to get to Orchid Island?

Amis: uri tjevavav aken ta varukur a sema Langi.
English: I want to take a boat to Lanyu.

Amis: uri kemuda timadju a vaik a sema Langi?
English: How did he get to Orchid Island?

Amis: tjevavav ta hikuki a sema Langi timadju.
English: He took a plane to Orchid Island.

English: What bus did he take to Kaohsiung?

Amis: tjevavav ta tjaljasaljiukan a sema Takau timadju.
English: He took the THSR to Kaohsiung.

Amis: natjevavav ta kisia a sema Taitu timadju?
English: Did he take a train to Taitung?

Amis: ui, natjevavav ta kisia a sema Taitu timadju.
English: Yes, he took a train to Taitung.

Amis: natjevavav ta kisia timadju a pasa Taitu?
English: Did he take a train to Taitung?

Amis: ini, natjevavaw timadju tua hikuki a sema Taitu.
English: No, he took a plane to Taitung.

English: Yes, if you go straight ahead, you will see the bus stop.

Amis: nu tjevavav ta basu a pasa gakku aki izua makudakuda a zikan?

Amis: izua ita tukian ki djemaljun i Taiciu.
English: I will be in Taichung for an hour.

Amis: tjara izua a ita a tukian.

English: How long did it take you to come to my house by MRT?

English: Are you free this afternoon? I’d like to visit you, is that okay?

Amis: ui, ku kaljava-u anga i tjumaq.
English: Okay, I’ll wait for you at home.

English: Are you free tomorrow? I’d like to ask you about the legendary story of the Paiwan people.

Amis: nutiav uri vaik aken a magadu, neka ken i tjumaq lja.
English: I’m going to the mountains tomorrow, so I won’t be home.

Amis: naselangda ken tu kemeljang sun aravac tua pakata na sepaiwan a kakudanan, saljinga ken ta kivada tjanusun.
English: I heard that you know a lot about the traditional customs of the Paiwan people, so I would like to ask you something.

Amis: inika liyav aku kingljan, ljakua makaya ken a temevela tua ku kingljang.
English: I don’t know much about it, but I will try to answer as best I can.

Amis: makaya ken a pakavidiu? nu tjaivililj ki tjamadjulu anga sivecik.
English: Can I record the video? It will be easier to record in the future.

Amis: siva a pulu’ saka alu anga a ku cavilj.
pida a su kinacaqu a kai?
macaqu aken ta na seAmis a kata sepiyuma a kai.
English: I can speak Ami and Puyuma.

Amis: napasilevan aken aravac tua ku kinivadaqan tjanusun a vuaq, pai makaya qivu anan sun tua pakata palisi nua qemalju?
English: It’s a pleasure to interview you today, can you talk about the taboo of hunting?

Amis: ui, ka maqacuvucuvung anan aken ru sa gadu aken a qemaljup.
English: Yes. I used to go hunting in the mountains when I was young.

Amis: maljimalji, tucu a vuaq pariya angata a su tinuluan.
English: Thank you, what you taught me today was really great.

Amis: pariaria angata a ku qinaivuan. sinitaucikecikel nua tja sevalitan.
English: All that I say is true, the sayings of my ancestors.

Amis: tja patemazau a tja mare kivavadavadaq, maljimalji a su pinasemalavan.
English: That’s all for today’s interview. Thank you very much for sharing with us.

Amis: uri vaik anga ken, nakiljaljava ken nu tjaivalilj ki tjaliyav anga ku langdaing a milimilingan.
English: I’m going to leave now and look forward to hearing more stories next time.

Amis: nasuljivat sun, anema a uri su velin?
English: Hello, what do you want to buy?
I want to buy a cup.

Amis: nasuljivat sun, anema a uri su velin?

Amis: uri veneli aken tu ita ta talupun.

Yes, how many do you want to buy?

Amis: neka, inika men a paveliveli ta saviki.

How many packs do you want to buy?

All the sweet potatoes are sold out.

Amis: uri veneli aken tu drusa ta djiuq.
English: I want to buy two bottles of oil.

Amis: amin anga a ita i tjanuamen.

Amis: uri nangking a su veliing a qecilu?

Amis: uri veneli aken tu drusa a djaljeng a kucay.

Amis: izua tjelu a djaljengan a tjeza, nisun nay anga a penuljat.
English: There are three left, all for you!

Amis: nu ita i tuvung drusa iday.
drusa a pulu’ katu ita a vatan a pipenuljayan, nu drusa a pulu’ ki pariya.
siva a pulu’  katu lima vatan a imaza.
pai kiveli anan aken tu kedri, padjaljuni tu taiday.
English: I'll buy some more, and make up 100 yuan.

pai paka lima a idayu aken?
aicu pazangal aravac, makaya papemaduluin a pagalju?
English: It's too expensive, can you make it cheaper?

Amis: inika makaya, aicu tjaljamaduluan anga aravac.
English: No, this is already very cheap.

Amis: uri veneli aken ta icu a kua.

English: $30 for the cookies, anything else you need?

Amis: makaya ken a kisedjam ta su paisu?
English: Can I borrow money from you?

English: Yes! How much do you need?

Amis: malim anga ken a kemacu ta ku paisu, makaya ken a kisedjam ta su paisu?
English: I forgot to bring money, can I borrow money from you?

Amis: inika ken a nakemacu ta paisu uta lja!
English: I don't have any money either!

Amis: malim aken a kemacu ta ku paisu, makaya ken a kisedjam ta su paisu.
English: I forgot to bring money, can I borrow money from you?

Amis: caqen, katjaisangas ka nakisedjam sun tjanuaken ta paisu inianan ka su pacikeli.
English: No, you haven't paid me back the money you borrowed last time.

Amis: makaya ken a kisedjam ta su itung?
makaya ken a kisedjam ta su sunat?
pai pasedjami aken ta su tjukitjuku?
English: Can I borrow your bicycle, please?
Okay, but you have to give it back to me tomorrow.

Amis: ’emudja’udjalj anga, inika ken a nacemacu ta qausua, pai pasedjami aken ta su qausua?
English: It's raining, I don't have an umbrella, can you lend me one?

Amis: ita sakamaya a ku qausua, pai tja siqausuan a madrusa!
English: I only have an umbrella, let's stick together!

Amis: aicu sunat mavan a su sinipasedjam tjanuaken ka katjaisangas, ku pacikelau tjanusun.
English: This is the book you borrowed from me last time, I give it back to you.

Amis: nu saljinga anan sun a pacun ta sunat makayanan sun a qivu tjanuaken.
English: You can tell me what else you want to read.

Amis: nungida nga ku pacikelen a su paisu?
English: When do I have to pay you back?

Amis: inika makuda, ’adjavan anga nu izua nga su paisu qivu anga.
English: It's okay, you can talk about it when you have money.

Amis: nungida nga su pacikelen a ku paisu?
English: When are you going to pay me back?
I'll return it to you tomorrow.

Amis: nungida nga su pacikelen a ku sunat?
English: When are you going to return my book?

Amis: aicu a inpic sinipasedjam ni kui tjanusun?
English: Did Kui lend you this pen?

Amis: ui, ku kinisedjam tjaimadju a vuaq.
English: Yes, I borrowed it from him today.

Amis: aicu a inpic su kinisedjam tjai kui?
English: Did you borrow this pen from Kui?
No, this is what mom bought.

Amis: nekanga nu ’atia, sau kisedjamu tjai pales tu kedri ta ’atia.
English: We are out of salt, let's borrow some from Pales.

Amis: sau djaulju ti pales pacikelu aku paisu ayau.
English: Go tell Pales to give me back my money.
How much does she owe you?
I’m going to plant vegetables in the garden.

Amis: liyav a aravac a cemel, venasavasak aken, nusauni uri pazaljum aken.
English: There’s too much grass, I’m cutting it, I’ll have to water it later.

Amis: pai alapan aken ta kawkav kata tjatjukun?
English: Will you get my scythes and hoes, please?
Put it next to the plow rake.

Amis: ku kinavacukan anga, nusauni uri temugut.
English: I just turned over the soil, and so on to sow seeds.

Amis: a su sinitalem a ljaceng makayanga ta kiljasengen?
English: Are your vegetables ready to be harvested?

Amis: makaya nga kilkangrangen a imaza, azua ljaluin inianan ka makaya a kiljaluingen.
English: The cabbage here is ready to be harvested, but the Showa grass there is not yet ready to be harvested.

Amis: wa! manu liyav a su kinali a vurasi?
English: Wow! You dug up so many gourds.

Amis: pai pusaladji aken a pasa ta kubav?
English: Will you help me with the barn?
We are casting nets to catch fish.

Amis: liyav anga djiname’ a ciqaw i tjaretjek.
English: The fish basket has been full of fish.

Amis: nu kaljakemudan a qadav kemuda sun a kiciqaw?
English: How do you usually catch fish?

Amis: mavan a raqas a ku sicekcek ta ciqaw.
English: I shoot fish with a spear.

Amis: macaqu sun a cukau ta tiveljatan kata vakela a ’emaljup?
English: Do you know how to hunt with a bow and arrow?

Amis: mavan a siringaringai a ku sikisacemel, izuanu malap aken tua ta kuang kata kemacu ta vatu.
English: I usually catch my prey with a trap, but occasionally I hunt with a gun and a dog.
This is the road the boar took.

Amis: aicu djekap na vavuy, manasika aicu mavan a papakazuanan a djalan nua vavuy.
English: These are the footprints of the boar, so this is the path the boar took.

Amis: ari tja pacunay a tja ringay, namaya ta nadjemameq anga ta sacemel.
English: Go and see our trap, for it seems that we have caught our prey.

Amis: namayata izua nga se’use’uin na vatu. ari kadjaljavi a semazua.
English: The dog seems to have smelled it. Let’s follow them.

What is that thing you put there?

Amis: azua tjukur, mavan a si’alju’aljup ta vanan.
English: It was a leg-rigged rope trap, and we used it to catch Shankiang.

Amis: maljimalji a papumanguaqan nua tja sevalitan, liyav a tja qadav a vuaq.
English: Thanks to the blessing of our ancestors, we had a great harvest today.

Amis: ui lja, tja siljevan a sema qinaljan!
English: Yeah! Let’s take it back to the tribe and share it!

Amis: tucu a qadav tiaken a nu sirutemulu muri temulu aken tjanumun a masantalj tu kemuda qivu tua qemuzimuzip a penaiwanan.
English: I will teach everyone all kinds of animals in Paiwan language today.

Amis: tucu a qadav tiaken a nu sirutemulu muri temulu aken tjanumun a masantalj tu kemuda qivu tua vangalj a penaiwanan.
