English: Is the post office close to the school?
Yes, it is within walking distance.

Amis: a djemet a kakanan tua tisaba?
English: Is the restaurant close to the station?

Amis: djemavac itjen a palamu satje djemaljun.
English: It only takes five minutes after you walk out of the station.

Amis: a pucug sun tucu a qadav?
pasa vaik aken a kivala tjanusun.
English: I would like to visit you.

Amis: izua ku saliman tucu a qadav, avanai anga nutjaivililj.
English: I am out today. How about another day?

Amis: sa izua su zikang nutiav? nutiav a masukincenglj ku imav anga.
English: Then, are you available tomorrow? I’ll visit you tomorrow afternoon.

Amis: maqati a nutiav, pai ku kiljaljavai anga i tjumaq.
English: Sure, I will wait for you at home.

Amis: a maqati aken a lemuing? uri puvecik aken.
English: Would you mind if  I do the voice recording? I would like to keep a record.
Would you mind if I do the video recording?

Amis: inika ken a bulabulai, inika namapalimasudj a i papunemangamangan uta, mayanan wa!
English: No, I am plain and the warehouse hasn’t been tidied up yet.
Then I will just take photos.

Amis: masalu tua maqati aken a kivadaq tjanusun.
English: Thank you for accepting the interview.
You are welcome. What would you like to know?

Amis: ku kivadaqay anema su sengesengan ta maqacuvucuvung sun?
English: What do you do when you are young?

Amis: kisacu aken tasicuayan, ljakua na taigu anga ken tucu.
English: I was a police officer but I am retired now.
Then, are you working at the moment?

Amis: i gakku aken tucu a kipusengsengan.
a i qinaljan a su aljak auta?
English: Do your kids live in the tribe too?

Amis: ini, i rizuk a ku aljak.
English: No, my kids are all living in the city.
Then, do you live by yourself?

Amis: izua ku paquziquzip a vatu a ita katua qayaqayam a ita, namaya tua ku sikatacemekeljan tiamadju.
English: I also keep a dog and a bird. They are my family.

Amis: izua ku paquziquzipen a ita a ngiyav auta, nu izua qemuziquzip a tja saladj inika tjen a masepelj.
English: I have a cat too. I won’t get bored with the company of my pet.

Amis: pasakivadaq aken tua paatjanu palisi nua qemaljup.
English: I would like to ask you about the taboos of hunting.

Amis: inika liav a ku kinljang, ljakua aza ku inljangan maqati ken sakamaya temevela.
English: I don’t know much about that, but I will tell you everything I know.

Amis: azua nu siqaljuqaljup a sauzayan anema zua a palisi?
English: Do you have any taboos about hunting weapons?

Amis: azua nia siqaljuqaljup a sauzayan inika maqati a vavayan a idjadjas.
English: Our hunting weapons are untouchable to women.

Amis: saka a maqati a vavayan a qemaljup?
English: Then, can women go hunting together?

Amis: nakuya, inika maqati a vavayan a qemaljup.
English: No, women cannot go hunting either.

Amis: Itjing, neka anga nu tja vawa i tjumaq, sau viliyu.
English: Itjing, our home is out of rice wine, please go and buy some.

Amis: izua anan a tjanuita i esan, mayanan a veneli!
English: There is still one bottle left in the kitchen, so there is no need to buy one!

Amis: inika qacuvung a tjanuita, vaiku sakamaya a veneli tu tjanudrusa.
English: One bottle is not enough for me, go and buy two more back.

Amis: veneli aken ta vawa, a paveliveli mun?
English: I am looking for rice wine. Do you have any rice wine?
Yes! How many bottles do you need?

Amis: veneli aken tu tjanudrusa, sana veneli anan ta paday tu tjanuita i lubuk.
English: I want two bottles and a pack of rice.

Amis: izua a paday imaza, anemanan a uri su veliin uta?
English: Here is the rice, what else do you need?

Amis: kinaveneli anan tua qacilu, a izua nan a qacilu?
English: I want some eggs too, do you have some?

Amis: uri veneli aken tua itung uta.
English: I want to buy some clothes.
What kind of clothes do you like?

Amis: uri veneli aken ta itung a hansudi.
English: I want to buy the clothes with short sleeves.

Amis: aicu a qudjidjilj a itung, pakananguaq sun?
a izua anan a zuma a quljav?
izua anan a vuqavuqalj katua cangiangiya a quljav.
English: We have white and blue ones too.

Amis: avanai azua cangiyangiya a ku veliin.
English: Please give me the clothes in blue.

Amis: Puljaljuyan, nakasinusun tasauni? navaik sun a undu?
English: Puljaljuyan, where have you been just now? Did you go exercising?

Amis: ini, navaik aken a pusaladj tjai vuvu a paveli tua ljacung.
English: No, I went grocery shopping for my grandma.

Amis: ai manumaya, izua su zikang nu qazemetj? pangtjezu anga kaiv.
English: No wonder! Are you available at night? Would you like to have a meal with me?

Amis: inika maqati, uri vaik aken a veneli tua itung.
English: No, I want to buy some clothes.
Then, I will go with you.

Amis: navenala sun, pidapida cu a itavatjuan a ljaceng?
English: Hello, how much is this bunch of vegetables?
The vegetables are $20 for a bunch.
How much are these sweet potatoes?

Amis: nu ita tjingtjingan tjelu a puluq.
English: Sweet potatoes are thirty dollars for a pound.

Amis: paveli aken tu drusa vatjuan ta ljaceng katua ita tjingtjingan a vurati numaya.
English: Please give me two bunches of vegetables and a pound of sweet potatoes.

Amis: Cumai, inika ken a paqenetj anga kemacu tua inpic, a maqati a su pasedjaman aken?
English: Cumai, I forgot to bring my pen. Can you lend me one?

Amis: neka nu ku inpic, ni Keljeng cu a inpic.
English: I don’t have one either. This is Keljeng’s.

Amis: sa’a maqati a su pasedjaman aken a palamu? ku pacikelav anga nusauni.
English: Can you lend me the pen for a second? I will return to you immediately.

Amis: masalu, masalu ayau anga numaya ti Keljeng.
English: Thank you and thank Keljeng for me.

Amis: uri pacikel aken tuca drusa a laqulj.
English: I want to return these two books.
No problem and what else do you need?

Amis: uri kisedjam anan aken tua tjelu a laqulj.
English: I would like to borrow these three books.

Amis: ui pai. nu makatjelulj paqenetju a pacikel.
English: Sure and remember to return them after three days.

Amis: inika na su pacikel tua siquliqulip tjanuaken.
English: You haven’t returned me the eraser.

Amis: nauwa, awa nekanga azua ku siquliqulip.
English: Then, why is my eraser missing?

Amis: aigu su sinipasedjam anga tjai Api.
English: Did you lend it to Api?

Amis: inika ken a kemeljang. vaik aken a kivadaq tjaimadju.
English: I don’t know. I will go and ask her.

Amis: ku sipasedjaman anan a ku siquliqulip tjanusun.
English: I will lend you my eraser first.

Amis: Keljeng, a ti Kuljelje a napasedjam tjanusun tuca uba?
English: Keljeng, did Kuljelje lend you this coat?
No, my mom bought it for me.

Amis: pailja mamav ca nu uba kati Kuljelje.
English: Kuljelje’s coat is the same as yours.

Amis: qecengecengel a uba nimadju, maretimalji a quljav na nia uba.
English: His coat is black, so our colors are different.

Amis: Paules, a nakisedjam sun tjai Cumai ta paisu?
English: Paules, did you borrow money from Cumai?

Amis: izua, uri ku cugan timadju tucu a qadav, manu inika ken a paqenetj anga kemacu tua paisu.
English: Yes, I was supposed to return to him today, but I forgot to bring the money.
Then, when will you return the money?
I will return to him tomorrow.

Amis: ui ku qivuavanga numaya ti Cumai.
English: Okay, I will tell Cumai for you.

Amis: azua bisangay tja pudringayan ta qecev, azua padjavatan tja pudringayan ta seluc avanazau ququlidan.
English: It is correct to catch mice through rangay and catch bamboo partridges through qjiulang.

Amis: manumaya, pacevacevak aken! djaljepan inika ken a djemamadjamaq.
English: No wonder! I am mistaken and that’s why I cannot catch any of them.

Amis: ku tuluwai anga sun a mumalj tuazua masanmusalj tu kemuda semanaya.
English: Then I will teach you how to set up these two traps.

Amis: wa! penakaleva aravac! nu pudringay aken nutjaivililj tjara iken a makadjamaq anga.
English: Great! I will be able to catch the prey in the future.

Amis: qaqacan anga ravac alja cemel i vavua, sau alapu ta drukudrukung a ma ubav, itjen a vaik a mavavua.
English: The grass in the fields is too tall. Go to the warehouse to take the sickle and let’s go to the fields.

Amis: izua i ljaqediqedi ta dradra’uyan, nu semaumaqan sun ta ubav isupacuni.
English: It is next to the round basket. You will see it when you enter the warehouse.

Amis: kinemenem itjen a malap, avan a mavuciq sun, radjai aravac a dru’udru’ung.
English: Be careful and don’t get hurt. The sickle is very sharp.

Amis: inika tja djuladjulatan a ku dringay!

English: My trap is under that tree.

Amis: ku pinukeljangan a pimaza, kemeljang aken tu ku pininu a dringay.
English: I make a mark here, so I know where my trap is.

Amis: rumue aicu, tja sikiciqaciqav cu a mapana.
English: This is a fish trap which we put beside the river for fishing.

Amis: neka nu nia rumue, nu kiciqav amen avan a sipanadinadip a izua.
English: We don’t have any fish traps there, so we catch fish with a fishing rod.

Amis: inika napavala a semeljudj tua sipanadinadip, tului anga ken nutjaivililj ui?
English: I have never used a fishing rod before, would you mind teaching me next time?

Amis: ui lja! ari vaiki anga nutjaivililj a panadip.
English: Sure! Let’s go fishing together next time.

Amis: saka ku tuluwai anga nutjaivililj tua seman rumue.
English: I will teach you how to make a fish trap next time.

Amis: milalualuag anga su panadip, tjara izua anga ciqav a namakelai! pakirimu a remakac.
English: Your fishing rod is moving. Isn’t the fish on the hook? Pull it up!

Amis: galjuanan, midradruqai aravac ca vare’ur. tjimazaken a remakac tua panadip, sau sazuau a malap tua ami.
English: Wait, the ship is rolling heavily. I am here to pull the fishing rod and you should go there to grab me the net.

Amis: rakacu a pasa maza alja ciqav, ku pusaladjai anga remakac.
English: Pull the fish to my side and I will help you pull it up.

Amis: aitja nanguaq auta! napakaliav itjen tucu a qadav, namapeljuq anga ca tja purur.
English: Great! It is a bumper crop today with full fish baskets.

Amis: pai cikeli a kirimu sa tja pangapangalji a masantalj.
English: Let’s go back immediately and share it with everyone.

Amis: mayanga kivangavang, kirimu qiladju a sema tua su qiladjan.
English: Stop playing and quickly sit in your seat.

Amis: sikamasan pidalj a qadav tucu ta tapulavayan?
sikamasanlimalj tucu a qadav, pulavay nutuav, ari kivangavangi!
English: It’s Friday today, we have a day off tomorrow. Let’s go out and play together!
Great! Let’s go to the riverside.

Amis: sikamasan pidalj a qadav nutiav ta tapulavayan?
English: What day will it be tomorrow?

Amis: sikamasantjelulj nutiav ta tapulavayan, vaikianga seman mali nu masukincengelj!
English: Tomorrow will be Wednesday. Let’s go play ball tomorrow afternoon!

Amis: anema uri su salima nutiav a kadjamadjaman?
English: What will you be doing tomorrow morning?

Amis: pulavalavay nutiav, uri vaik aken kati kina a sema kiukay.
English: Tomorrow will be Sunday, I will be going to church with my mom.

Amis: pasa mutjaq aken, vaik aken a sema binziyu.
English: I feel like vomiting. I need to go to the restroom.

Amis: sinsi, saketju a ku tjialj, vaik a ken a sema binziyu.
English: Teacher, I have a stomachache. I need to go to the restroom.

Amis: a maqati aken a sema binziyu?
English: May I go wash my hands?

Amis: uri, qemacuvung anga tja kitulu vaiku anga nusauni.
English: It’s almost time for class to end. Wait a little longer.

Amis: sinsi, saqetju a ku qulu, pulavay aken nu numasukincengelj.
English: It’s almost time for class to end. Wait a little longer.
Okay, take care and go home.

Amis: sinsi, uri pulavay aken nu tjaivililj ta sangasangasan na tapulavayan, vaik aken a kipucemel.
English: Teacher, I need to take a sick leave next Monday. I have to see a doctor.

Amis: saqetjuqetju a tjialj nimadju, sa izua timadju i binziyu.
English: She has a stomachache. She’s in the restroom.

Amis: sinsi, saqetjuqetju a liqe ni Puljaljuyan, sa napulavay tucu a qadav.
English: Teacher, Puljaljuyan has a sore throat. She took a sick leave today.

Amis: ti Tjanubak a lja Tjaluigi aken, tapuluq anga ku cavilj tucu.
English: My name is Tjanubak Tjaluigi, and I’m 10 years old.

Amis: ti Tjanubak a lja Tjaluigi a ken.

English: What ethnic group are you from?

Amis: a kacalisian a mareka su sikatacemekeljan?
English: Are all your family members indigenous?

Amis: ui, paiwan zuku amen a tacekeljan.
English: Yes, my whole family is Paiwan.

Amis: a kacalisian a mareka su sikatacemekeljan?
English: Are all your family members indigenous?

Amis: ini, paiwan zuku a ku kama, pairang a ku kina.
English: No, my father is Paiwan, and my mother is Han Taiwanese.

Amis: aljak aken ni Camak a lja Tjaluigi.
English: I am Camak a lja Tjaluig’s child.

Amis: a su kama azua? pida anga cavilj nimadju?
English: Is that your father? How old is he?

Amis: unem a puluq anga cavilj nimadju.
a su kama azua? pida anga cavilj nimadju?
English: Is that your father? How old is he?

Amis: ini, nia ramaljemaljeng timadju i qinaljan, alu a puluq anga cavilj nimadju.
English: No, he is an elder of our tribe. He is 80 years old.

Amis: pida anga cavilj nua su kaka a tjavulung tjanusun a uqaljay?
tapuluq saka alu anga cavilj nua ku kaka a tjavulung tjanuaken a uqaljay.
a liav a cavilj a sikatjavulung tjanusun nua su kaka a uqaljay a tjavulung tjanusun?
English: Is your brother much older than you?

Amis: taiday saka sepatj a puluq a ku kinaqaca.

English: I haven’t seen you in a while. Have you grown taller?

Amis: ui, taiday saka tjelu a puluq anga ku kinaqaca.
ui, tjelu a puluq anga ku kinasadjelung tucu.
vaik aken a sema kakizuanan a kipusalima nua sinsi a kemim tja sinsi.
English: I’m going to the office to see the teacher.

Amis: uri vaik a veneric tua cemel.
English: He’s going to throw away the trash.

Amis: izua i ljaljanguyan timadju, uri malalumalj ta ljemanguy timadju nusauni.
English: He’s at the swimming pool. He’s going to compete in a swimming competition later.

Amis: inu ti Muni? uri malalumalj ta mekelj timadju nusauni.
English: Where is Muni? She’s going to compete in a running competition later.

Amis: izua timadju ta kakateveteveljan, ku vaikav a qivu timadju.
English: She’s in the auditorium. I’ll go call her.
Let’s go to the playground together.

Amis: vaik anan aken a veneli ta ku cengelj, ku kimav anga sun nusauni.
English: I’ll go buy lunch first, and then I’ll meet you later.

Amis: pay ari tja qaluav a tja bintu!
English: Let’s carry the lunch boxes together!

Amis: kimu ta zuma, uri vaik aken a kemim ta sinsi.
English: You find someone else, I’m going to find the teacher.

Amis: Puljaljuyan a uri malalumalj tucu ta cuitjiu?
English: Is Puljaljuyan competing in croquet today?
No, he’s competing in high jump.

Amis: nu undukay tuazua i qadav a izua uri su kicapiljen?
English: Will you compete in the sports day?

Amis: izua, uri kisaseljang aken tua malalumalj ta makelj.
nu undukay tuazua i qadav a izua uri su kicapiljen?
English: Will you compete in the sports day?

Amis: uri kisaseljang aken tua malalumalj na cuitjiu.
uri kemuda itjen nu undukadukay i qadav?
English: What will we do in the sports day?
We will compete in tug of war.

Amis: a uri paveli tjen tua kakanen nu undukadukay?
English: Will we sell food at the sports day?

Amis: ini, uri paveli amen tua tjabulubululj.

English: Congratulations on getting first place! You’re amazing!

Amis: a izua i tjumaq ti vuvu i vavayan?

English: Yes, she’s sleeping in her room.

Amis: a izua i tjumaq ti vuvu i vavayan?
neka, tjau vaik a casav, nu qazemezemetjang kimangetjez.
English: No, she’s not. She just went out and will be back in the evening.

Amis: a izua i tjumaq ti vuvu i uqaljay?
uzai i tjaivavau sau kimu a sema vavau timadju.
English: He’s upstairs. You can go up and find him.

Amis: ti Puljaljuyan, sicuayan anga ku pinacunan tjanusun, na venala sun?
English: It’s Puljaljuyan. I haven’t seen you in a while! How have you been?

Amis: na venala ken! kemim aken tjanusun a maljavar.
English: I’m doing great! I came to chat with you.

Amis: seman djamadjamay i kakesan timadju, ku vaikav a qivu.
English: He’s in the kitchen cooking. Let me go call him.

Amis: na vaik anga semainu ti Muni?
vaikanga sema pukukan a djemekep ta kuka timadju.
English: She went to the chicken coop to catch chickens.

Amis: neka i tjemaq a nu vava a uqaljay, vaik anga sema vavua, tjitjumatjumaqu a kitjekaljava ta mangetjez timadju.
English: Your grandfather is not at home. He’s in the field. Wait for him to come back.

Amis: sicuayan anga ku pinacunan tjanusun, nameqacanga sun.
English: I haven’t seen you in a while. You’ve grown taller.

Amis: maleva ken aravac a pacun tjanusun.
English: It’s so good to see you.

Amis: ku sipavavay aicu a pangudralj tjanumun, pasa zuauanga ta pingsiang.
English: Here’s a pineapple for you. Put it in the refrigerator.

Amis: cuacuayanga inika mangtjengtjez, ku qaqivuav tiamadju a mapuljat ta keman.
English: It’s been a while. Let’s have a meal together.

Amis: maya mavarung, nanguaq a temekel aken ta utja kaljavaljavari a sema pulaulangan.
English: No need to bother. I’ll just have tea. Let’s sit in the living room and chat.

Amis: masalu ta su paiadja, uri vaik anga ken a cemikel.
English: Thank you for your hospitality. I have to go now.

Amis: tjau papacain aicu a kuka, kacuanga cemikel ljenguaquanga keman.
English: This chicken was just freshly killed. Take it home and enjoy it slowly.

Amis: kicun aken tjanusun ta nutiav a masukincengelj ui?
English: Can I make an appointment with you tomorrow afternoon?

Amis: ecevungianga i gakku ui? uri seman iga men.
English: How about meeting at school? We need to shoot a video.

Amis: sazuai i dradraiyanan numaya, uri penaiwanan aken.
English: Then let’s go to the community center. I’ll wear folk costume.

Amis: bulay aravac nu matelak a nia sakura i qinaljan, nu padjaljun anga tuazua pangtjezuanga kemim tjanuaken.
English: The cherry blossoms in our tribe are beautiful when they bloom. Come find me when the flowers bloom!

Amis: nu maitazua ikiljaljava ta kaljaveveanang, kigemaljuanga!
English: That would have to wait until spring. It’s too late, isn’t it?
Then come during our Harvest Festival!
Alright! I’m looking forward to it!

Amis: akuazua lja cemikel sun a sema qinaljan a kikavaljutan.
English: May I ask why you decided to move back to the tribe?
I want to return to teach at the local school.

Amis: akuazua lja inika sun a sema lizuk a temulu?
English: Why not teach in the city?

Amis: ayatua nasengelit aken tua ku qinaljan,na saljinga ken ta pasucikel tua ku picul ta qinaljan auta.
English: Because I miss my hometown and I also want to give back to the tribe.

Amis: macaqu sun aravac a tjemenun, tima na temalu tjanusun?
English: You’re very skilled at weaving, who taught you?

Amis: ku vuvu a vavayan, tjalja macaquan timadju a tjemenun i qinaljan tjanuamen.
English: It was my grandmother, she is the most skilled weaver in our tribe.

Amis: akuazua pasa kitulu sun ta tjemenun?
English: How did you develop an interest in learning weaving?

Amis: nia kakudan a tjemenun,ulja nia sipatatavelak a nia kakudan aya ku kininemeneman.
English: Weaving is a part of our culture, and I want to ensure its continuity.

Amis: macaqu sun aravac, a cuacuay a venawa tu aicu?
English: You’re really talented. Does it take a long time to make?

Amis: ini, kitjara tapulavayan, tja kesain anan a djuadjuai a paday katua paday,sa tja patatauden ata djulis, nu maitazua maqati anga pasa djilungen.
English: No, it only takes about a week. After steaming the sticky rice and white rice, we mix it with yeast powder, and then it can be stored in a jar.

Amis: izua silji katua luciau,tiaken a na temalem.
English: I have chili and lokiy, both grown by myself!

Amis: pida avelian nu cu a masanmusalj?
drusaiday saka lima puluq a penuljat.
tjengelay aken tu aicu a itung, pida a avelian?
English: I like this piece of clothing. How much is it?

Amis: pazangal aravac,a maqati a ljiatekeanan a kavelian?
English: It’s too expensive. Can’t you lower the price a bit?

Amis: inika maqati, masipun aken nu patjaiteku anan.
English: No, if I lower it further, I’ll lose money.

Amis: ui! avanazua a qacengecengal a ku veliyen.
English: Alright then, I’ll take a black piece of clothing.

Amis: tjengelay aken tua aicu a siqunu katua padriyuk.
English: I want this knife and this pot.

Amis: drusa kuzulj a penuljat, tiaken a namalang, kicuacuay a su sicekaukau.
English: It’s a total of 2000 dollars. I handmade these, and they are guaranteed to last a long time.

Amis: ku sipasemalavan tua mareka kuqali tu veneli,a maqati a memadjulu anan.
English: I’ll introduce my friend to buy. Can you give a further discount?
Alright! I’ll give you a 20% discount.

Amis: idu pacunu ta sipaveliveli a itung katua tjalupung.
English: Come and take a look! We sell clothes and hats.

Amis: nu ita itung tjelu a iday saka lima puluq, nu tjelu kuzulj.
English: One piece of clothing is 350 dollars, three pieces for 1000 dollars.

Amis: veneli aken tu ita, pavai aken ta vaquan.
English: I’ll just buy one piece, please give me a new one.

Amis: djavadjavay, pasa veneli aken tua djuadjuay a paday katua vutjulj.
English: Hello, I would like to buy sticky rice and braised pork with maqaw pepper.

Amis: mapuljatanga paday, izua anan a ciniyan a tjanaq,veneli sun?
English: The rice is sold out. I have tana pancakes, would you like to buy them?

Amis: ui, paveli aken tu ita, venelianga ken nu tjaivililj ta paday.
English: Alright, please give me one. I’ll come back next time to buy rice.

Amis: ui, ku pulubulubukay numaya, numaitucu lima puluq.
English: Okay, I’ll pack it in a bag for you. That’ll be 50 dollars.

Amis: patagilj anga kitulu, ljetaladj anga sinsi sema kiusic, qivu a hanciw:“ gacalju! kicungalu !”
English: It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

Amis: a sini tulu na nia sinsi pakata pinaiwanan a semupu
English: In class, the teacher taught us the Paiwan language of numbers.

Amis: timitja kiciuli ta sinsi kisupu, na semenay a men ta semupu a senay.
English: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

Amis: liaw anga u kinasaigu a pinaiwanan.
English: I have learned many Paiwan languages.

Amis: ljemita ta qadaw ma gakku a ken, ljemita ta qadaw kitulutulu tua pinaiwanan, uli kiljavaljang sasi palanda tja kina.
English: I go to school every day, I learn the Paiwan language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

Amis: a ngadan na ku kama ti camak.
a ngadan na ku kina ti savan.
izua ku kaka tjavulung a uqaljay, a ngadan nimadju ti buka, tucu puluq sa ita anga cavilj nimadju.
English: I have a brother, his name is buka, he is 11 years old.

Amis: kitulutulu amen itau mamaw a gaku.
English: We study in the same school.

Amis: tjengelay semenay ken kata tjavulung a kaka uqaljay.
English: Both my brother and I like to sing.

Amis: tjengelay ken a kemavekav, nu pulavay, tiamen taqumaqanan maciuciul vaik a kemavekav.
English: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

Amis: tjengelay ken sekeljang tua atalasi a qali, dikilu amen maciul a semenay kata kemavekav.
English: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

Amis: a nia kinaizuanan imaza i taitu king taren guan a tjuabar mula.

English: There are five people in our family.

Amis: tiamen taqumaqanan izua ma tjelu a siruvetjek.
English: There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

Amis: na matevelj amen kata ku kama, kina, tjavulung a kaka uqaljay kata vavayan.
English: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

Amis: qaca ku kama, kisace a ku kama.
English: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

Amis: kuljay a ku kina. kuisan a ku kina.
English: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

Amis: nu i tjumaq amen ti kama lukayan na men ta pinaiwanan.
English: My father speaks the paiwan language with us at home.

Amis: nu kilavay tua kalja zalangezangan ru vaik amen a sema qinaljan.
English: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

Amis: tiaken kata tjavulung a kaka uaqaljay vavayan ru kaciul a djemekep tua ceqel.
English: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

Amis: tjengelay a ken tua u taqumaqanan.
English: I like our family very much.

Amis: nu saunay uli vaik amen kivanvan kati kina.
English: I went out with my mother today.

Amis: nu maqadaw cangiangia a kalevelevan, ika ljaljeqel ika semezam tauta, sudjusy a vali.
English: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

Amis: na qemiladj amen itua zaleman kemakan ta pang, aza teljare na qadaw pazarezar itua kacavacavan, semeljec aravac.
English: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.
In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

Amis: ku kivadaqan ti kina, akumaya qudjidjilj a kalevelevan.
English: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

Amis: aya ti kina, masa uli mangetjez anga buhu.
English: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

Amis: nuqezemetj neka qerepus i kalevelevan, tjevutanga vitjuqan.
English: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

Amis: uli vaik anga men matjumaq tauta.
a si vaikan matjumaq a djalan, kipenetj aken tua vitjuqan.
English: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

Amis: ulja ika mangetjez a buhu, sa vaik anan na ken ljisasaw a kivanvan.
English: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

Amis: a ku gaku i gidi tua nia umaq, ljemita ta qadaw djemavadjavac aken a magaku, djemavac matjumaq tauta.
English: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

Amis: ika qaca nia gaku, mapulju a situ, makakeljang a mapuljat.
English: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

Amis: mapuljat a qaqunuan rumaqepu i unduzin, maciul a kivanvan ta bulu, maciul a pakatateveravera.
English: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

Amis: a mareka sinsi kiciul tjanuamen a kivanvan, tauta, a gaku matu na mirazek a cemekemekelj.
English: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

Amis: nu ljemita qadaw semuap amen, aza kiusic tja paka suapen a palimasudj.
English: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

Amis: izua djemuas ta qezung, izua vaik a semuap ta kalavan.
English: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

Amis: nuaya tiamen nia suapen a i gaku mareka putuputung, maqaqepu mareka pusaladj, nu ljemita qadaw aza i gaku na siki.
English: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

Amis: katiaw, na vaik aken i qinaljan a paljilji ta ku vuvu uqaljay.
English: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

Amis: sicuayan anga tja sincevuan, singelit aken tjaimadju.
English: We haven't seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

Amis: ti vuvu uqaljay ka pacun tjanuaken, pakanan na ken tua suyka, patekelang na ken ta ucia.
English: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

Amis: a talem ni vuvu uqaljay a suyka qaljemeqem, sanguaq aravac.
English: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

Amis: tjengelay aken temekel ta ni vuvu uqaljay a ucia tauta, nutja tekelen sanguaq uta.
English: I also like grandpa's tea, it's tasted good too.

Amis: ka hilu, na maciul aken kati vuvu vavayan keman ta kincengelj.
English: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

Amis: ti vuvu vavayan a kinsa cengelj liaw djamay, izua ciqaw, izua vuyu, izua siak, izuanan dingding.
English: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

Amis: nu pakakan ta cengelj, uli vaik amen mapuljacengan kiaya tua ljaceng.
English: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

Amis: na malap ti vuvu vavayan tu liaw ta vurasi, vasa, kata lakiu pavay tjanuaken, sipakacu a matjumaq.
English: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

Amis: vaik aken kipusau tjamadju, patjumalj nu tjaivililj uli vaik anan a paljilji tjamadju.
English: I said goodbye to them and said I'd see them next time.

Amis: kasauny kacuing amen na nia sinsi maqaqaquzipan, i paljing amen kilasudj a venely ta kipu.
English: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

Amis: ka ljitaladj ta qaqaquzipan, aya ti sinsi:“ aza i sangas pakata qayaqayam, aza i likuz pakata kanaqatjuvian, kitimun a patjatjauvaik a pacun ta talidu.”
English: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

Amis: malekutj a ken tua qatjuvi, sika ini pacun na ken ta kanaqatjuvian.
English: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

Amis: na pacung a ken ta liaw a qayaqayam, tiamadju i tua kasiw pavavaw a minlayalayap, izuanan pinacunan a ljequ na taqed itua na kasiw a belung.
English: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

Amis: aza qaqaquzipan izua zung, unma kata tjakakudralan a ngiangiyaw, kasicuayan inianan pacung ta namitucu a dubuc, kasauny ku pacunan maleva racac.
English: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

Amis: liaw a u sinasin, uli sipapacung ta u kama kati kina.
English: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

Amis: nu tjaivililj uli kiciul a ken tja kama kina maciul a semamaza.
English: Next time I will come with my parents.

Amis: tucu kilavay, uli vaik amen kata tjavulung a kaka vavayan ma taitu paljilji ta djisan.
English: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle.

Amis: uli ljivavaw men ta kisiya kemasi taihuk ma taitu.
English: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

Amis: djemaljung i taitu, ti djisan emungeting ta haiya mangetjez i tisiaba kicevung tjanuamen.
English: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

Amis: aza disiaba demut ta umaq ni djisan, ika cuay a ungeting djemaljung.
English: The station is not far from my uncle's house, and it's just a short drive away.

Amis: i dudut ta umaq ni djisan izua qacaqaca a papagungan, maciuciul amen padjidingsia mata papagungan.
English: There is a big ranch near my uncle's house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

Amis: ka i papagungan, ti djisan kacuing amen pakan ta sizi kata kiqadraqadr tua unma.
English: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

Amis: ka masulem, maciul amen ma hici a keman.
English: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

Amis: aza hici liaw a zidusia, avanasika pautubay men a mazua.
English: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

Amis: ka uli vaikanga men, sedjumak tu na macakaw a nia utubay, sa vaikanga men ljivavaw ta basu.
English: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

Amis: tucu uli vaikanga men sema taihuk, qadjaw kidjinumak anga a utubay ni djisan.
English: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don't know if my uncle's motorcycle has been found.

Amis: ka qaqunuan a nia umaq i tjuabar, ka magaku anga, patjavat a sema taihuk. imazamaza i hici a sikac.
English: When we were young, our family lived in tjuabar. After I started school, we moved to Taipei and have been living in the city ever since.

Amis: ka temakesi anga ta daigaku, na peniliq a ken tua ita pakata na kacalisian bunka a kituluan, pualang anga za kacalisian tu izua maretimaljimalji na talidu a bunka i taiwan.
English: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

Amis: manasika, tucu a cavilj nu pakilavay tua kaljazalangezangan, uli vaik amen kata u kaka uqaljay sema qinaljan, kivadaq ta ramaljemaljeng, saljinga tu kemeljang tua nimitja zuku a bunka.
English: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

Amis: aza ramaljeng alu puluq anga cavilj, ljakua nu tja pacunan matu tjaukaramaljeng.
English: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

Amis: u kivadaqan timadju macaqu tua pida kai. tauliq ravac nu lukai timadju ta pinaiwanan, saigu a lukai ta na muqami a kai tauta.
English: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in Paiwan, as well as Japanese and Pangcah.

Amis: manu ka qaqunuan timadju na kitulu ta pinaiwanan, a cekelj amizuku, sa za sengsengan nimadju makakeljan kata tjuluvu a ripung caucau, avansika liaw kinasiagu a kai.
English: I asked him to find out that he learned Paiwan languages when he was a child, his wife is an Pangcah, and he knows many Japenese at work, so he can speak so many languages.

Amis: ka kitjaucikel amen, aza ramaljeng na tjemaucikel tu liaw pakata qemaljup a kakudan.
English: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

Amis: kumalji ika men maqati a sepualang kiselangda, ljakua na emaya men ta itua lima dingwa a remuing, maqati mumalj kigalju a kilangeda.
English: Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

Amis: ka qaqunuan ika pualang tua pasa niaken zuku a bunka, pakata kacalisian angata ken izua keri a siaqan.
English: When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

Amis: ka tjaivililj liaw anga pinualang, u kinemenemen tiaken paiwanzuku a caucau, na pakisumalji angata, pacengceng si ilasian uta.
English: The more I know, the more I feel that being a paiwan is unique and something to be proud of.

Amis: nusauny masulem, uli sema tjumaq anga tjakeri a kaka uqaljay.
English: My younger brother is going home this evening.

Amis: tiaken vuvu a vavayan vaik maiciba veneli ta vuyu, padjulu a kemesa ta sanguanguaq a kaiven sipakan ta u kaka tjakeri a uqaljay.
English: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

Amis: na cemalivat amen tua paveliveli ta ljaceng, aza sipaveliveli liaw na nasasanguaq a ljaceng.
English: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

Amis: na venely amen ta ingcay, qaqilj kata daikung.
English: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

Amis: aza i gidi a paveliveli ta kudamunu a tawki qivu:“ a ku pangudralj kata qudis qaljemeqem. veliu tu keri pay!”
English: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

Amis: na veneli amen ta pangudralj kata qudis.
ka cemalivat amen ta paveliveli tua vutjulj, aza tawki qivu anema su velin? kasauny a vuyu kudral tu qalev, nu ita tjelu taidai a paisu.
English: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

Amis: paka pazangal ti vuvu vavayan, kivadaqan a tawki tuki maqati a pumadjuluing.
English: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

Amis: ljakua aya tawki madjulu anga, dikinay anga kiluvadan.
English: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

Amis: aza i tjuljivar a tawki qivu, idu veliu ta ku ciqaw, a ku ciqaw kudral tu madjulu.
English: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

Amis: kavililjanga venely a men ta vuyu kata ciqaw tauta, sema tjumaq kemesa ta tacukui a djamay.
English: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

Amis: kemaljava cuayanga, masulem anga a kalevelevan.
English: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

Amis: ti kaka tjakeri a uqaljay padingwa mangetjez a qivu, papintjus tu ika semekez anga i sividay, nu tjaivililj a niciubi mana dikilu a mangetjez.
English: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

Amis: aya ti vuvu vavayan liaw a kinesanga, qaqivu a mapuljat kaciruri a keman!
English: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

Amis: na djemaulj a men ta marekasusu kata qalialian, maciul paselingulj a keman.
English: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

Amis: izua u dukiusi ti kapi, timadju ru draudraw kemacu ta nemanga.
English: I have a classmate named Kapi, he often forgets to bring things.

Amis: ka kitulutul amen, na kisedjam timadju ta na dukiusi a inpic, siquliqulip kata qadupu.
English: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

Amis: puita, pudrusa, putjelu, aza salasaladj pukaui a pasedjam ta nemanga tjaimadju.
English: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

Amis: izua damidami a kakudan nimadju, ru kisedjam ta nemanga sa ika pacikel anga.
English: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

Amis: kavililjanga a mapuljat ika sa pasedjam ta nemanga tjaimadju.
English: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

Amis: izua tu ita qadaw, na maciul amen vaik a kivanvan.
English: One day, we all went on an outing together.

Amis: ka i kadjalanan, sa mabinziu ti kapi, ljakua madraudraw kemacu timadju ta sidjuadjuas.
English: On the way, Kapi wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

Amis: na kisedjam timadju ta salasaladj ta sidjuadjuas, ljakua maitucu temevela a mapuljat tjaimadju, ika nakemacu a ken tauta.
English: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn’t bring them either.

Amis: ti kapi qemauqaung ta latjakan, matjalaw timadju qivu, akumaya ika nu pasedjaman na ken ta sidjuadjuas!!
English: Kapi burst into tears. He said angrily, why don’t everyone lend me toilet paper!

Amis: tjumaljang na salasaladj timadju, lja ika sun na rukacut, saka nu pasedjaman sun ta nemanga, ika sun na pacikel.
English: The classmate told him, because you didn’t bring it yourself, and you wouldn’t return the things lent to you!

Amis: kamaljia magaku, medjama sema gaku ti kapi, aza kinisedjam ta salasaladj a nemanga pinacikel anga penuljat ta dukiusi.
English: The next day at school, Kapi arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

Amis: ti kapi kipaqaljay ta dukiusi, sa qivu nu tjaivililj tjara kemacu ta niaken a nemanga, masalu tjanumun ka tjaisangas pukaui a pasedjam ta nemanga tja nuaken.
English: Kapi apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

Amis: a ku kama na i qinaljan a cinunan.
English: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

Amis: ka qaqunuan na ken, ti kama kati djisan nu itua qezemezemetj vaik a ljesasaw, kemacu ta tjakit kata kuwang.
English: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

Amis: numaljia, mangetjez tiamadju a na kemacu ta djinameq a sacemel.
English: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

Amis: nucuayanga vavuy, nucuayanga lava, nuaya izua padjavatan uta.
English: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

Amis: aza sacemel qaluqaluten niamadju i siljitaladj tua qinaljan a paljing, pasleva tua sikataqaljan.
English: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

Amis: sakamaya ru qemevaw a ken tja kama, sa kiciul a qemaljup kati kama.
English: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

Amis: aya ti kama nu meqaca sun, ku su kacuaw anga.
English: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

Amis: a i qinaljan a uqaljaqaljay macaqu a pudringay djemekep ta sacemel, tiamadju saigu cukulu ta veceqel a dringay kata siqezetjan tua qaciljay a dringay.
English: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

Amis: a ku kama saigu a cukulu ta veceqel a dringay, aya ti kama, aicu uli sidringay ta padjavatan, tja kigaljuing a ljemengljeng za na sacemel a djekap, za dringay tja pizuaing ta na sacemel vinaikan a djaljan.
English: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

Amis: ulja dikilu a kilimu kata ramaljeng maciul a qemaljup, nu ljemita qadaw kicaquan a cukulu ta dringay, aza u dringay uli palamu anga paqulid a maqati djemameq tua sacemel.
English: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

Amis: ti ka pacunan na ken qivu tjanuaken, nu tjaivililj tjara masan saiguan sun a cinunan.
English: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

Amis: tucu meqacanga ken, ku sevaljeng a u panaq kata vakela, kiciul ta ku kama vaik a qemaljup.
English: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

Amis: ka sema qinaljan, aza nia djinameq a sacemel uli pasleva tua sikataqaljan.
English: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

Amis: aya ti kama, masalu aravac tana qemati a sinipagaugaw. pavayan itjen tu liaw ta sacemel a manguaqan.
English: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

Amis: ta kadjaman gemalju aken a ma tatakisian.
English: I was late for school this morning.

Amis: tazua vayke sema tatakesiyan, ini paqenedjanga aken a masi qabang.
English: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

Amis: ini ken na kemacu ta nanemangau.
English: I didn’t bring anything with me.

Amis: a kitulutulu tazua, maciyul a pacun ta kadup aken kata dukiwsi.
English: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

Amis: a semekiseking tazua, pasedjaman aken ta inpic kata sisumasumang na dukiwsi.
English: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

Amis: kakivuin aken na sinsi, “nu djavililj gacaljuanga kilimu, maya gemalj anga!”
English: The teacher told me, “Wake up earlier next time and don’t be late again!”
My good friend’s name is kadrw, and he is also an Paiwan child.

Amis: na maciyul a men a kisupu i kaaluwan.
English: We study together in the kaaluwan tribe.

Amis: djaluljes amen a maciyul kilangda ta djawcikel a milimilimgan na lamaljeng, macaqu amen qivu ta pinaywanan.
English: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Paiwan proficiently.

Amis: ljavavaw aken sa mekaca, ti kadrw maliljay sa kedrikedri.
English: I am tall and overweight, while kadrw is short and thin.

Amis: lu talivakan ti kadraw, djengelay a men djay madju a mapuljat.
English: kadrw is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

Amis: ungdukay na i gaku tu sa qadaw, maljeliyav a kamuku sinipa malalumaljan na gaku.
English: Today was the school’s sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

Amis: izua malalakac ta calis, sema kula a benulu, mekelj, dremaiyan, katua penana.
English: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

Amis: tazua a mekelj aken, sekulilj aken, pedjamu tu liyav a cungal.
English: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

Amis: ljakua migacalj aken, sa pazulunge a mekelj a pasasangas.
English: But I stood up and continued running forward.

Amis: maleva cawcaw anga a djemaljun aken.
English: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

Amis: nuavan na ini a malap ta sangasangasa. ljaqua maleva ken alavac. ayatua na paudeze anga ken tua kinimalalumaljan.
English: Although I didn’t get first place, I’m glad because I completed the race.

Amis: na paljilji ta ku ama aken ati kama ta tiyiv.
English: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

Amis: na mapasa’edju a kula ni ama.
djmaljan amen ni madjuna, makapalaq tu ita beleng a na umaq a ’aljiv.
English: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

Amis: a ljemengungu ta ’aljiv na umaq ti madju, makelu anga kemasi ta umaq na ’aljiv.
English: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

Amis: na kemacu ti kama ta na gung a vudjulj ‘ata saviki sipavay djay ama.
English: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

Amis: i ’umaan a mazazepezep a ken ati ama.liyav a milimilinga sini djawcikel ni madju.
English: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

Amis: a muri vayika anga ken, zemengel ti ama tu mekacanga ken, mapavalit tu djasawqaljay tu.
English: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

Amis: ’evu ken, “nu menguwa anga su kula ama, keljuanga ta nia umaq kivangavang nu djayvililj tu.”
English: I said, “When your foot gets better, come to our house next time and visit us.”

Amis: i ta drusa kuzulj sa drusa pulu sa drusa cavilj, na kaygi anga a asihu a pita mibungsiw na kacalisiyan ta ngadan makayanga pasa ita ngadan nua kinacalisianan.
English: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

Amis: na humung aken ta cuacuayanga kilevuci pasa ta sihu a pita mibusuw pizuwanan ta “pasa ita ngadan na kinacalisian’’ i qinalja a maacuvucuvung. lja savan ti camaq.
English: I interviewed camaq, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

Amis: tucu a sisekesekez a qadaw na pinedjan aken ati madju tu mazuwa ta umaq nimadj a humung.
English: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

Amis: a humung tazuw, pasemalaven aken ni madju tu pinakasinuan a ngadan ni madju, utanga kacuin aken a pakeljang ta tacekeljan ni madju, ta qinaljan ni madju.
English: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

Amis: ku kivadaan ti madju a kumaya ki temezeng pasupavalit ta ngadan, nakuya sipavecikana a kakudanan ta sicuayan.
English: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

Amis: kakivuin aken ni madju, ayatua na sipavecikan ta ciniwkukan ini a mapacengceng a pkeljangn ta ngadan ni madju, azuma cawcaw maytucu anan a qivu “ca sinsi” ut manasika sidjawljan tu paseliyaw tua penapedjeli.
English: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him “Cha Xian Sheng”, which resulted in many jokes being made.

Amis: lja savan ti camaq kivu, “a tja kaulidan a ngadan nu kinakacalisiyan a sivecikan ta ngadan mavan na djaljemedjem, aza ku ngadan sikaqeljangan tu anema men nu zukan, ljanema men a djumaan, nidjen a kinapatalevanan i kacawan. puzangalan tu makaya maljeliav azukan a cawcaw kipakim ta su kiningadangan.”
English: camaq kivu said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

Amis: ta tiyav ti aken kati vuvu avavayan vayke a ma icipa ta papaveliyanan, na kemacu ti vuvu avavayan ta liyav a namakakayzuazua a sinitalem a lacing, utanga sikipualan ta na kacalisiyan a kakanen sipakan tua mapuljat.
English: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

Amis: na djengelay a mapuljat ta ni vuvu a papaveliyanan, a kamangulj ata luni maljeleav a cawcaw veneli, maljeleav a cawcaw mangedjez a keman ta sinanljaceng ni madju.
English: Everyone loved my grandmother’s stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

Amis: sanguwa alavac a kines ni madju a lukuce kata djuadjuay a kinsa. izuanan a siljatu ta vavuy pinasazuan ta daykung kata tjana, aza saluman masiljudje ta maljeliyav a kaljakalja. mangdjez a mapuljat sa madjuljul ita niamen a papaveliyan.
English: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

Amis: nu kemesakesa ta nemanga ti vuvu, i djuljival aken a djemawdjaulj ta kaljakalja. i djuljival a ken a mezangal a djemawdjaw, “a ljaceng savtde a niya sinitalem, ini a pinizuanan ta kahiliyuan a si vevuan, veliyu a kilalimu lja!”
English: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

Amis: a nia nemanga ma veli a kilimu, kivuta vuvu, “masa izuwa sun a paqeljing.”
English: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, “It’s all thanks to your help.”

Amis: aicua a kinipusengsenganan, izua ku kinituluan paka ta kacalisiyan a zazumuk katuwa sikeljangan ta kakanen a kakudan, mayanga izua nga kinakeljangan ta kipusngesngan ita papavelian aza luljayan.
English: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

Amis: pacunan ti vuvu djengelay alavaca tua semicuacuayan a kakanen, djevalungan aken ta samamaljian a acianan atuwa puzangalan.
English: Seeing my grandmother’s passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

Amis: kemasi zuwa anga, aicu a na mapaseqeljing sa kavaljut a caucau mavadevad anga a sema pulingetj i tjagaraus aya.
English: The people fled to Mt. Dawu with lard as a torch, and from there the surviving clans slowly spread out to different parts of the country.

Amis: aicu a tja ngadan a paiwan zuku aya sini papu ngadan anga na ripung tja nu itjen ta mangetjez tia madju.
English: Paiwan is a name commonly used during the Japanese rule era.

Amis: aza mare timaljimalji a tja kinai zuwanan a kadjunangan mare timaljimalji uta a tja kakudan.
English: There are also differences in cultural expressions depending on the area of residence.

Amis: pumaljeveq pumasalut itjen a paiwan zuku, ljakua a se ravar a caucau ika pukakudan ta maljeveq,
English: The common Paiwan ceremonies are the Harvest Festival and the Five Years' Festival, but the Paiwan belonging to the Laval group are the only community that does not hold the Five Years' Festival.

Amis: kimaya maalap ta kakudan nua se drekay a caucau.
English: Because of the strong cultural influence of the neighboring Rukai people

Amis: a se vangecul a caucau na kipuljaqediqedi ta ami zuku kata pairang, a se paqaluqalu a qinaljan na setevelj uta ta ami zuku kata piyuma zuku a caucau,
English: Paiwan living in Manjhou Township with the Han and Amis ethnic groups

Amis: masepu sakamaya tu kedri ta kakudan na muqami, kemasi ta sikavan ta siitungan makeljan tu ita tu drusa tu namasasepusepu anga tu namadjadjaludjalu anga a kakudan nia madju.
English: The ethnic groups in Taitung, who live in close proximity to the Amis and the Peinan, have also been influenced by their culture, as can be seen in their clothing.

Amis: a pinu paiwan zukuwan a caucau i taiwan tucu uri padjaljun tu malje tapuluq a kudravan a supu, titjen a pinu ngadanan tu kacalisiyan malje tapuluq saka unem a zukuwan,
English: Currently, there are nearly 100,000 Paiwanese in Taiwan, ranking second among the 16 ethnic groups in Taiwan.

Amis: izuwa ta sika masan musalj a tja kinatjuruvuwan a paiwan zuku. pituwa pinu se akavan a caucau, pasa djemaljun ta malje lima kudrav a supu, i pasa pinu se taituwan pasa padjaljun ta malje drusa kudrav a supu,
English: Pingtung County has the most 50,000 people, followed by 20,000 in Taitung County.

Amis: i pasa pinu se taituwan pasa padjaljun ta malje drusa kudrav a supu,
English: Kaohsiung City, nearly 8,000 people in the third place

Amis: a i pasa maza i pinu se akavan matja pitju a rarasudjan ta qinaljan, izuwa pinu se tjimuran, pinu se makazayazayan, pinu se kulaljucan, pinu se tjaljakavusan, pinu se tjuwaqauan, pinu se tjuwaqaciljay, pinu se sinvaudjan,
English: The Paiwan in Pingtung County on the west coast are mainly located in seven townships: Sandimen Township, Majia Township, Taiwu Township, Laiyi Township, Chunri Township, Shizi Township, and Mudan Township.

Amis: izuwa na setevelj ta se lizuk a mavekelj i pinu se vangculan,
English: Some of them are Manchurian villagers living in the flatland townships.

Amis: izuwanan a i pasa kacedas a i kadraruran, i qaljungic, i kaqaluwan, i tjavalji, kata i pangluy, tjalja tjuruvuan a i pinu se akavan a caucau ta tja sikataqaljan,
English: In addition, on the east coast, centered on Taitung County, there are five districts in Taitung City, namely, Xinyuanli, Darren Township, Jinfeng Township, Taimali Township and Dawu Township.

Amis: a pimaza i pinu se akavan tjalja tjuruvuan a caucau i pinu se tjaljakavusan.
English: The population is mainly concentrated in Pingtung County, with the population of Zhiyi Township taking the top spot.

Amis: a tjauciel nua ramaljemaljeng na masan tavak anga a tja sikataqaljan a palalivulj ta i kacedas ta i kaledep,
English: In the oral history of the Paiwan West Bank tribe

Amis: kumalji a namakuda a kinavavav a kinaseljekuya na djalan i pasa tjagaraus,
English: Recognizing that the East and West Coast peoples have been traveling, moving and intermarrying very frequently since ancient times

Amis: inika sikaqeceng ta pareka senglitan ta padjadjaluwan.
English: The towering Dawu Mountain and the long and difficult ancient coastal road cannot stop the clan from seeking relatives and thinking of their hometown!

Amis: a i taiwan a kacalisuyan a seljuseljudjen a ljavaran mavan azua a AUSTRALIAN a kai, tjalja tjaljiqacan a pinaljavakan i pulingetj i kacauwan aya ta kana na sedjalju ta ljavek a kadjunangan semeljuseljudj ta icu a ljavaran aya.
English: The language spoken by the indigenous people of Taiwan belongs to the Nanshima language family, the most widely distributed oceanic people in the world.

Amis: tjalja zayazayan a i taiwan ta qinaljan a semeljuselju ta icu a ljavaran a AUSTRALIAN, sinan pazangal aravac itjen nia madju a kipuvaruvarung ta remasudj ta ljavaran a hakasi.
English: Taiwan is the northernmost part of the South Island language family, and the language occupies a very special position in the entire South Island language family.

Amis: a ngadan na qemuzimuzip, a ngadan na cemel a cemuvucuvuq, a parutavak a vukai i ta senay, liyav aravac a rinamaljemaljengan a kakaiyan aya, aicu a tja ljavaran a kacalisiyan makeljang tu kemasi sicuay a vinqacan ta tia qinaljan,
English: Ancient words are often found in the flora and fauna of the ancient South Island languages or in the vocabulary of ancient songs.

Amis: avan nu sika namasan paravac aravac itjen i taiwan taicu a AUSTRALIAN a kai.
English: This evidence shows that the language of the southern island of Taiwan is very old.

Amis: aicu a titjen a paiwan zuku a kacalisiyan masan ljiyaliyav a tja pinare timaljimalji a kakaiyan, izua se ravar, se vuculj, se tjakuvukuvulj, se paliljaliljav, se paqaluqalu.
English: Depending on their living environment, the Paiwan can be categorized into the Laval subgroup, the Buchol subgroup, the Daguiwen subgroup, the Bali Zelio subgroup, and the Bakaro subgroup.

Amis: ljakua ta yatalu izua tjemekulj tu drusa puluq saka izua a maseljuseljudj a ljavaran i taiwan
English: Research has shown that there are more than 20 South Island languages spoken in Taiwan.

Amis: tjuruvu aravac a caucau a masalu tu kiniveqacan itjen nua tia madju a AUSTRALIAN a caucau aya.
English: Therefore, more and more linguists believe that Taiwan is one of the "ancestral homes" of the entire South Island people.

Amis: ta sicuwayan a pinaljavakan nu maretimaljimalji a qinaljan na mapenetj a tja kakudangan tu patje inuinu a veqeveq. izuwa a qaqaljupan , a qaqumain, a pana kata veljeluwan, izuwa a kaqinaljanan,
English: In the past, the traditional domains of the tribes included hunting grounds, forest lands, cultivated lands, valley and river lands, and tribal habitations.

Amis: nu tjeqalja a ramaljemaljeng pakazua sakamaya ta tjara nia madjumadju a kadjunangan,
English: And when the tribes come and go. And when the tribes come and go.

Amis: pinaka nakuya aravac a tjemekulj a djemavac ta kadjunangan nua zuma nua qaliqali aya. a sisa vavuwa djalan a sivaik a qemaljup a djalan ika tjen a djemulat a paqeteleng ta kadjunangan nua se tjumalji a qaljan.
English: The routes and paths are based on the boundaries of the tribe's own traditional territory and cannot be crossed.

Amis: a pare paqaljaqaljay ta paljaljaqediyan katua qaliqali namasan pazangal a ravac,
English: And our people are very strict about enforcing the boundaries of the land.

Amis: a tjaucikel nua ramaljemaljeng ika tjen a menacidicidiljan a makazuwa ta paljaljaqediyan nua qinaljan a qemuma aya,
English: In the old days, Zang Shou was the strictest form of punishment for enforcing the rites of the land.

Amis: izua nu ljekuyain itjen nu ljemeten itjen na tjumalji a qaljan, tja sipaqaqeciqeci a qemulu ta sicuayan a kadjunagnan aya ramaljemaljeng.
English: For our people, land is the life of the tribe.

Amis: aya tuwa pinaru nasi a pasa pazangalan ta vavaletan nua kadjunangan a piqinaljan, avan auta nu tatagiljan na rivuan na tjara qinaljan
English: Disputes between tribes over living space often occur and even lead to tribal wars.

Amis: sa avan a zuwa siyayaya nua vavuluvulungan a tja sikavaljut nu kipusengesengan itjen amin a pinu nitjenan a kadjunangan a tja kasengesengan nakuya patjekulj aya!
English: Therefore, the environment in which we live and work is only on the tribal land that belongs to us!

Amis: a kinaqinaljanan na titjen a kacalisiyan ika makeljan anga tu kemasingida a pinatagiljan a vinqacan tu pidanga cavilj a paqulid.
English: The old sites of Native American tribes are almost always old and ancient tribes, with no known date of creation.

Amis: amin a tjaucikel na ramaljemaljeng tu ljaima na venqac ta qinaljan, tu tima tja mazazangiljan a na cemiyur, a zuma a na makakudakudan a ljavaran ika tjen a kemeljang anga.
English: It's not known who the founding family and the leader's family are, but it's still known in the oral accounts.

Amis: nu djemaljun itjen i qinaljan a sapay nua tjaumaq pinaru semangatj ta upu asinan tarivarivatjan,
English: When you walk into the tribe, you'll see rows and rows of neatly arranged houses.

Amis: aza calisi a kadjunangan matu tjaljetjalj nu tja tjavangen a kemasi zaya patje lauz a qinaljan, pukacasavan a umaumaq anga,
English: Since the tribal terrain is on a sloping hill, the houses are arranged in a staircase style down the hill, and each house has an outside yard.

Amis: nu nanguanguaq a sicegedan na tja maca matjavang a tja kinaqinaljanan nu izua itjen ta tjavatjavan a nase paljevari ta qinaljan.
English: If you have a good eye, you can see all the houses from the vantage point.

Amis: a tja kinai zuwanan a tja qaqumain a kacalisiyan izuwa i pasa ljaveljave kata i pasa vukid,
English: The terrain where the people live and farm can be divided into mountains and plains.

Amis: aza tja liyav a tja qinaljan a i kacalisiyan cauwan na kacalisiyan amen aya itjen nu qivu itjen.
a tja sinan umaq a tja qaqumain a kakaizuwanan nua tja quziquzipen a malaing tu puqacangan tu varevar i calisilisi sakamaya.
English: The tribes of the Paiwan people also lived on the slopes, building houses, cultivating farmland and raising livestock.

Amis: sa nu pangtjez num a paljilji ta nia qinaljan sa nu pacun ta nia sikavaljutan ta nia kadjunangan sa nu pulingalingav tu namakuda a nia kinaqinaljanan.
English: If you have the opportunity to actually visit a Paiwan tribe, you will be able to appreciate the living environment of the traditional Paiwan people!

Amis: a siquman na ramaljemaljeng ta sicuwayan izuwa tjemevetjev kata mavacuk sa natja ljamain a kinavacukan a tjinevetjevan a gade,
English: The tribal people have tjemevetjev and mavacuk for traditional farming methods.

Amis: sa temugut tu san puvaquan qemusul tu san puvasan sa talemi ta vasa ta vurati ta paketjav kata padai a makaumaq,
English: Farming method in which branches and weeds cut down after land preparation are burned and directly used as organic fertilizer for the land.

Amis: nu izuwa sinagnatjan a inupuwan taleman ta puk, ta qarizang, ta pudai, ta tjingkui.
English: We grow millet, taro, sweet potatoes, peanuts, and a little dry rice as our main crops, and tree peas, long beans, corn, pumpkins, and other indirect crops.

Amis: vaqu a na masan pazangal ta qinuman, sini pukeljang tu patagilj tu qemacuvung ta kina tacaviljan.
English: However, millet is the most important crop, and it is clearly a spring and fall crop.

Amis: liyav aravac a tja pinalisi tua vaqu nu temugut itjen kitimitim,
English: It has many taboos, such as the Seed Sowing Ritual, which is a ritual of abstaining from speaking.

Amis: paradjama a ramaljemaljeng a mavavua tu ika secevung ta timaimanga tu ika secevung tua qayaqayam,
English: The old man would go out early to avoid the crowds and the early birds.

Amis: nu maka tugut ika makaya padudur ta sengesengan i vavuwa, cemikel itjen a maumqa. nu kivaqu itjen ika makaya a semiqunu tja gecesen a lemima.
English: When you finish sowing, you can't do any other work and go straight home. Harvesting can't be done with a knife, but only by hand.

Amis: maumalj a i kacauwan seman pazangal anga itjen ta kipaisu,
English: In recent years, due to the transformation of society from an agrarian society to an economic society, there has been an increase in the number of people living in rural areas.

Amis: vaik anga a lemizukan a kakedriyan a maqacuvucuvung sa mavekelj anga a keman ta kinikavecengel nua ramaljemaljeng .
English: A large number of tribal laborers have gone out to earn a living, and as a result, much of the traditional agriculture of the tribes has been lost.

Amis: tucutucu a sika drusa tjelu a cavilj maudalj a temalem ta kuhi, aza masan paisu a kuhi. aicu a na cemikel a mecemecemel a mequcalj a tja quma, tja cikelen anga a tja quma a semukasiv a semuvaudj patja secikel a masan qaqumain a tja kakunangan.
English: In the past two to three years, the tribes have been promoting coffee cultivation, which has helped to revitalize the land.

Amis: ta sicuayan aicu a kipusalimliman ta temaqaljaqaljan a pinapare timaljimalji a sengesengan a sirarasudjan ta tja qinaljan ta tja sikataqaljan;
English: The traditional social division of labor can be divided into the following roles.

Amis: izua cemiyuciyur a kipuvaruvarung a mazazangiljan kata marevetjevetjek, sa izua a parakalay, izua a kalaingan, izua a sikataqaljan, izua a rarakacan, izua a pulingav kata liguligu,
English: Leaders and other kin, priests, speakers, civilians, warriors, witches, mediums.

Amis: sa aicu a kisan sasekauljan auta ta i tjumaq ta tja sikasaliyalim izuwa pinaparangzan ta lemuiluv ta veqeveq,

izuwa pinadjadjasan ta qaqaljupan, izuwa pinapukadjunangan ta qumaq, izua uta kiciyur ta marevetjevetjek nu venesng, a pacun tu tima patjekulj ta kakudan tua seman itung ta vencikan a ika djaljemedjem tu sikava, kumalji nu ka situngan nu ka saseljudjen pinu kakudan a penuljat.
English: Warfare, hunting, cultivating land, management, use of patterns on clothing or articles of use or artifacts, etc.

Amis: aicu a namapiliq tu kipusaliman ta temaqaljaqaljan a kalaingan, piniliq nua taqaljaqaljan tu tjalja puvarungan, tu na ljemeceg a kakudan, tu namaka tjeljevecekadan ta mazazangiljan katua sikataqaljan ,
English: In the case of a spokesman, the entire village participates in the election of a representative elected by the commoners.

Amis: kinilautan anga na taqaljaqaljan a kakaiyan tu ika ljemakedras ta tima imanga,
English: According to the result of our long-term observation, we have selected from among the middle-aged people those who are exemplary in their behavior and work.

Amis: a kaparumalj na semalu, a sitjaucikelan tu lonamasevec tu naljemequlid tu naparuarut a kakudan a kakaiyan, avan na zuwa a maqati a maalang tu kalaingan na taqaljaqaljan!
English: An expert in speaking terms, genealogy, and oral histories of tribal history!

Amis: ta sicuayan neka nu tja kadjunangan a taqaljaqaljan, nu tja mazazangiljan a penuljat.
English: The lands of the former In Tribe are owned by mazazangiljan

Amis: nu na qemuma itjen nu izua tja kinikavecengelan pacunan tu namakuda a tja kinilami sa kuletjan tu namakudakuda a sipakazelju ta mazazangiljan,
English: Crops grown on arable land are taxed according to their yield.

Amis: nu izua tja tjinepanan kiyalap tu kedri, nu izua tja inalap a kemasi vukid a sacemel, izua a tja kakudan uta tu pavadis ta tja vusam ta tja sikasaliyalim.
English: There are tax systems for fish caught in rivers and for animals hunted in forests.

Amis: namakapasusu aravac a tja sikataqaljan tja sinikarasudj a pinenetjan a kakudan tua pavadis,
English: The tribesmen are very observant of the hunting rituals established by the tribe.

Amis: na mapenetj a makaya tja sipavadis ta mazazangiljan a tja kakudralan a sacemel izua a likuljav, a cumay, a sizi, a takec, a vavuy, a venan.
English: Large game animals such as clouded leopards, black bears, mountain goats, mountain kiang, mountain hogs, deer, etc., hunted

Amis: paka tua sipupida qemalac na cinunan a tja sikeljakeljang tu namakudakuda kinakudralan ta inalap a sacemel nia madju,
English: The hunter calls out the number of times he has to report the size of his clan's kill.

Amis: a na maitucu a pavadis ta mazazangiljan nu padjaljun anga ta masalut sa namaqepuqepu a kinvavavava a uqaljaqaljay sisenay ta semanqimang tu namakudakuda a kina uqaljayan nia madju.
English: So that we can report our successes at the Harvest Festival.

Amis: a kakudan ta pavadis a nu sacemel a qulu, a tjapalj, a tengu a drupiljai na venan tja sipavadis ta mazazangiljan.
English: Therefore, the hunters have to offer the head and hind legs, antlers, and whips of the animal to the mazazangiljan, commonly known as pavadis, according to the rules of the respective tribes, and the hunters have to pay the head and hind legs, antlers, and whips of the animal to the mazazangiljan.

Amis: nu tja inalap a kemasizua ta kadjunangan a izua maljiyan a pinadjadjasan na mazazangiljan, tja sivai sakamaya a qulu a patje drengelan ta mazazangiljan sa tja pudjadjalani ta kavutjuljan aya.
English: The game was taken from the hunting grounds of the feudal administrators, then mazazangiljan still got the head of the animal together with the neck part and a large piece of good lean meat.

Amis: izua nu makaqarut ta kakudan amin anga a semiyav a namasan ni cinunan, gata a puzangalan nimadju ika sa makiluvad!
English: Often, the hunter only gets a mouthful of soup at the end of the share, but he is still most proud of it and doesn't feel any hard work at all!

Amis: izua senay nua nia ramaljemaljeng a pinu se kulaljucan kata i pinu se tjaljakavusan a patjara ljiva upu i cuitik rinagelan tu milingan aya,
English: When the elders of Tae Mo and Lai Yi sing the old tunes, they have a common memory of participating in the construction of waterways by laying stone slabs and stacking stone walls.

Amis: aza na secapilj a tja sikataqaljan ta ljemiva ta emupu ta seman djalan ta zaljum i cuitik.
ta ripunganan a na paljavak tja nu itjen, seman djalan ta zaljum tu sidjiqes ta kaisiya na i pasamaza i ruqaciljai kata i buriyu.
English: During the Japanese rule era, underground water collection corridors were built for the irrigation needs of Wanlong Farm and Dachongying Farm in Xinpi Township, Pingtung County.

Amis: nasemutalad ta gade a seman djaljan ta zaljum,
English: Erfeng Canal is an underground reservoir

Amis: pinatagilj a kipusengsengan na ripung a pasusangas tu siva pulu saka izua cavilj. na kemali tu matja drusa vacavacalj tu sizululj ta zaljum, a matjaita i pasamaza i ljingpin a matjaita i pasamaza i dralekelek,
English: In 1923 and 1925, the Japanese installed a catchment gallery in the main stream of Linbian Creek and one in Lili Creek, a tributary of Linbian Creek.

Amis: pizua ta pasalauz nu ljelauz a zaljum, pinakiyamavan a kinamalangan nua kadjunangan,
English: By the principle of "water flows downhill".

Amis: na pakatalad ta kadjunangan a limaiday saka alu a pulu kaka drusa a kinaladruqan na pakeciyuan,

sa drusaitai saka pitju a puluq saka drusa a sinan paqaqizing ta zaljum a pasaladruqan, sa drusa kuzulj saka limaiday saka alu a puluq saka drusa a kinaladruqan a siniupu sa ljivai tu pakazuanan na zaljum,
English: 272 m of pressure culverts and 2,582 m of open nullahs

Amis: sa makaya anga a sidjiqes ta quma nua i pasaljaveljav, ta seman djalan ta zaljum i cuitik, pinakicapilj itjen a kacalisiyan a i demet a qinaljan.
English: When Erfeng Canal was constructed, all the nearby Paiwan tribes participated in its construction.

Amis: aicu a djilung rarukuzan saseqetjan na ramaljemaljeng ta na metad a drinasi a lami,
English: The urn is a very important vessel for storing dry food in our traditional life.

Amis: namaya taicu a vaqu, taicu a aradj, taicu a rindraridr.
English: e.g.: millet, dried taro, dried groundnut shreds

Amis: tja zazululjan ta tja tjinatjan a zaljum, ta yatalu tjematjan itjen sakamaya ta zaljum tu tja siseljudj ta kemesa ta tekelen.
English: It was also a vessel for holding water, as the tribes of the past had to draw water for use in their homes.

Amis: saka makaya uta a djilung a tja djaungan ta vutjulj ta tjinpana a tja vavan!
English: It is also needed for curing meat and fish, and for making wine!

Amis: tja sinan paravac aravac uta nu pecekelj itjen tja silisilisi ta mazazangiljan a dredretan.
English: What's more, it's one of the wedding ceremony items

Amis: masan liyaliyav a pinapare timaljimalji a ngadan na djilung,
English: Our urns are known by different names

Amis: izua saljav a tjalja kudralan kata saljasaljv a tja papulamiyan, izua djupeneq a pualu a kepel, pulima a kepel, putjelu a kepel a pasakudral aya tua nu venavaw itjen avan a tja sikeljan tu namakuda pasaliv sa qacuvung a tja si vucung ta tja qaljaqalja, namaya uta tja sidjaungan.
English: There are large and medium-sized tanks for dry food, as well as capacity for curing meat and brewing wine.

Amis: izua a ngaci a matu umaumaq na cirat, a pakeciya a djeljeseljesem a quljav,
English: For example, there are different sizes of urns, such as eight urns, five urns, three urns, and other ceramic bottles and screw-shaped bottles.

Amis: a dredretan a silisilisi, a pangasiljan a na parutjingkui a kinamalangan, a vuti a kalingkingking a ljingav,
English: There are also green ceramic pots, ceramic pots for weddings, pumpkin pots, and ceramic pots with a soft sound.

Amis: a liljualjuas a kedrikedri a na tjemengelay!
English: Last but not least, a cute little ceramic pot!

Amis: aicu a vaqu tja sinan pazangal aravac a kacaljisiyan,
English: The millet culture of the Paiwan people has deep cultural connotations!

Amis: inika amin a kinapazangalan ta kisumavan ta kikavecenglan nu qemuma itjen, pinukakudan aravac auta a tja sivucungan ta vaqu.
English: Apart from the fact that millet itself is not easy to pick, the millet cake made from millet is an important part of the Rituals of Life.

Amis: nu maleva itjen ta pinualjakan, ta semankinsa, ta mansivitay, ta masalut, ta sipucekelj, a tja sinanparavac ta tia sineljavakan ta tia kinai kacauwanan, venucung itjen sakamaya ta mareka tja kaka ta vaqu.
English: It is required for birth ceremonies, newborn ceremonies, men's marching ceremonies, harvest festivals, and important occasions of weddings.

Amis: aicu a ginurus nu seman kinsa itjen, nu na pualjak itjen tja sivucung ta mareka tja kaka nu qemepuqepu itjen, tja sikipucemecemelj a vavayavayan uta, semiyav ta pinupukan tu sikiseljec aya vavuluvulungan.
English: Rolling the ingredients of the millet cake into dumplings is the most luxurious treat for a newborn baby, a party for relatives and friends, or for a pregnant woman during her menstrual period.

Amis: a ginurus malaing tu anema tja djumaken tu sipaluveluvan,
English: Usually the base of the soup is tree bean soup.

Amis: tja ljaljules a pinuvutjuljan, aza madjulu a madjumak.
English: And it can be filled with different ingredients, with pork being the most common filling.

English: For the elderly who have a weak dental bite, we will pack the bee pupa.

Amis: nu izua tja kakedriyan i tjumaq tjalja tjengelayan tja madju ta pinukurusatuan sa pataudi ta tjalav/paketjav.
English: During the fishing season, we will pack the fish stuffing, sometimes we can change the flavor and add brown sugar and peanut stuffing.

Amis: sarunguaq sa madjulu a seman kakanen ta ginurus liyav a sedaljepan!
English: Round and round, Miu Miu is a master of mixing and matching!

Amis: masan liyaliyav a sinipatavelak tja nu itjen a caquan na ramaljemaljeng, aicu a tjemenun ikatjen a pulingalingav anga tu na kemasi inu a patagilj a caquan na vavuluvulungan,
English: Weaving is one of the many traditional wisdom crystals of the Paiwan ancestors.

Amis: gata izua ta tjaucikel na ramaljemaljeng tu nitjen a kakudan sa tjemenun.
English: The date of organization is not known.

Amis: na semamalji aravac a caquan na sicuayan a caucau, pizua itjen taicu a tjinenun a itung a ljavuy a sikasaigu a remasudj ta alay a papare timaljimaljii ta quljav sa maalang a vinciken,
English: The ljavui princess costume is a masterpiece of Paiwan weaving, which is not only delicate but also different from other traditional costumes.

Amis: aku ika kudresul a saiguan na ramaljemaljeng,
English: It was a real eye-opener for many experts.

Amis: kumalji a sinan puvarung a remasurasudj ta vecik a mareka sinsi na paljecul a vinarungan nu pacun.
English: Everyone knows the pattern of the clothes and the color and texture of the fabric.

Amis: tja kakudan a kacalisiyan, aicu a vincikan, aicu a situngan nuka quljav anga izua tja parepaqaljaqaljay a taqinaljanaljanan.
English: Especially the bright red, orange, and tangerine colors, all of which are indicative of tribal order, and which the tribesmen must be careful to use.

Amis: a natemaljar a quljav a qudjidjilj, a vurarurav, a vincikan, izua tja kakudan nu semeljudj itjen.
English: In the village of Laiyi our princesses get married by wearing embroidered ljavui princess dresses in red-orange color with patterns

Amis: titjen a pinusetjaljakavusan nu pecekelj a tja vusam a tja sikasaliyalim a masitjumaq na kiyalalang ta ljavuy, tjerequdjidjilj a kava pinaru ibuk a vincikan sa papukuni ta tjinenunan,
English: It also has a wider waistband to match the shorter design of the top.

Amis: sa pinusiyatjan ta vincikan uta, maljiyan tu bulay a kinamalangan!
English: So it's very bright and eye-catching!
The princesses are dressed in their princess costumes.

Amis: a vecik na ljaima ima maretimaljimalji, nu nakialalang a mareka tja vusam a tja sikasaliyalim sekeljang tu ljaima sivaivaik. ikatjen na macigav!
English: The patterns on the clothes tell the history of each family! There is no ambiguity at all!

Amis: kubav nu aya itjen tja papulamiyan tja papupatjezan a kacalisiyan.
English: A barn, as the name suggests, is a place for storing grain or other items.

Amis: tja piniljaqediqedi ta tjaumaq i pasulivay ta tja kacasavan, izua tja sinan salang uta i tjumaq i dedep, tu sikasarenguaqan nu limikezalj itjen.
English: Usually the barn is built on the outside of the lookout, but there are also indoor barns for food that can be cooked immediately.

Amis: a kinamalang na kubav matu saubu a neka nu liljing,
English: The barn is shaped like a hat with no brim at the top and is supported by four wooden piles.

Amis: sa qeluzi tu sepatj a qeluz, sapu pakilivia ljemita tu qeluzan tu sirengez ta silautan na kiki.
English: One round perforated slab at the top of each pile to prevent rodents from intruding into the area

Amis: a sikasarenguaq a kipukubav ika seljaljiyak a tja nanemanemanga, serukuz a tja lami,
English: The beauty of a barn is that it makes good use of the space, and any food can go in it!

Amis: a i patekuteku ta kubav makaya tja seqetjan ta saseljudjen ta turiverivecan saka ika maqudjalj uta, sarenguaq uta tja kaqepuqepuan.
English: The space underneath the elevated barn shelves not only holds tools, but is also a great place to cool off and chat, and is also protected from the rain.

Amis: ljemita tu cavilj nu maka kivaqu a tia sikataqaljan a pasusangas ta masalut, tja patjumaqen i kubav a tja lami.
English: Every year a new grain collection is put into the warehouse, and the work of putting it into the warehouse is completed before the Harvest Festival!

Amis: nu kacekeljan sa tjaljiqaca a qinuman, nu namaljenguaq namezangal a kinacaviljan,
English: Some families have large landholdings or need two or three barns to store new millet in case of a large harvest.

Amis: djemaulj itjen ta mareka tjakaka sa pakinrangez nu semeqetj ta vaqu, izua nu drusa nuika tjelu a kubavanan a pinizuanan ta kinivaqu na mazazangiljan.
English: We're gonna bring in a couple of friends and family to help us out.

Amis: pukakudan a semeqetj ta vaqu, izua nu mapalisi ta sicuayan. nu semeqetj ta vaqu tja pasasaven a sitjai sangasan a vaqu,
English: Some tribes have simple ceremonies where the old ones are taken out and cooked or made into wine.

Amis: sa payadedepi a vaquan, a pinasasav a vaqu sanvavain tu tja sikasalut!
English: The vacated space is put into the new

Amis: itjen a paiwan zuku ikatjen a namaya ta ami zuku a pupapapiliq ta cavilj na maqacuvucuvung nu maqepuqepu.
English: The Paiwan do not have a strict age grading system like the Amis.

Amis: gata izua tja kakudan tu seman vuluvulung ta kakedriyan.
English: But there are different rites of passage.

Amis: kemasi tjequlja itjen a caucau patagilj a tja kinai kacauanan aya vavuluvulungan, izuacu a tja kakudan a seman qinati ta caucau;
English: However, the tribe believes that a person's life begins when he or she is born and falls to the ground, and that he or she must go through several growth rituals:

Amis: qemalev, patjumalj ta qadav, patjumalj ta mavavua, seman kinsa, seman aljek, seman vuluvulung.
nu padjaljun ta tapuluq saka drusa nuika tjelu a cavilj a kakedriyan, pavayan na kama nu ika vuvu ta tateljuran (tuki) a pisyusiyucen sa pateveti, papuceqeljap aya ta namai tucu a kakudan.

English: Baskets, large and small, are placed on top of the head and offered in thanksgiving for God's blessings.

Amis: tja sicikel a tjaljayan, a i dradrakuyan/cepeng tja pangapangaljen kata dindusi.

English: At the beginning of the burial, two persons related to the deceased were sent.

Amis: nu pakiseljenguqa itjen peniliq tu madrusa tjademet a tja kaka tu kisan temavelak a semaluvang,
English: At the beginning of the burial, two persons related to the deceased will enter the grave to greet the deceased and then lay him to rest.

Amis: temepu aya ta namai tucu a kakudan.
English: Our people call this placement process temepu. Our people call this placement process temepu.

Amis: nu papigacalj a kemasi tjumaq masepatj a qemalu, nu i cadja a tja caceveljan masasumusumus a tja kaka a kisuvarung ta sisepakavaljay.
