Amis: nu djemaljun i caceveljan paljetekuin anga semaluvan, sa tavelaki nia madju a na kitjaisangas a ljeteku a kitjakaljava a pakiseljenguaq.
English: When everything is in order, he climbs up from the cave and covers the grave before leaving.

Amis: nu makasananguaq ljevavav anga a kemasi luvang. kudresul a na temavelak ta caucau aya,
English: When the deceased's family thanks their relatives for their help after the burial, they make a toast.

Amis: papuljagayan nu ljemagay a nakicapilj ta qemalju, a ginacaljan a tjumaq nimadju,
English: The highest honor is given to those who participate in the placement of the cave, and special thanks are given to those who are nominated among their relatives.

Amis: tja ljagayan a puviljiviljiljan namasan tja pumaljimalji ta kinicapiljan ta kiniqepuqan nua tja kaka.
English: The family of the deceased and the family of the deceased's origin are also honored with a toast!

Amis: izuaza tacemekeljan aya, manu vaik aza kina kata kama a macadja sa ika mangetjez anga,
English: A long time ago, there was a family whose father and mother went far away and never came back.

Amis: sa macidicidilj anga a aljak a tisa muakaikay, sa paquzipi nuazua vetjek na kama i ljaqediqeli aya.
English: He left behind a daughter, Mukaikai, who was raised by her uncle, who lived next door to her.

Amis: malupiq a kisumavan a cekelj nuazua vetjek na kama, nu izua na pazangal a sengesengan sisekaulj nimadju tjai muakaikay,
English: Auntie thinks it's troublesome to take care of Mukaikai, so she leaves all the heavy work to Mukaikai.

Amis: a masani muakaikay a ravaravain a nanemanemanga alapen sasan nimadjui,
English: She took everything that belonged to Mukaikai one by one.

Amis: a umaq a kakanen kumalji nuka itung anga sivai ta aljak nimadju sa lacuti ti muakaikay.
English: I gave my cousin a house to live in, food to eat, and even traditional clothes to wear.

Amis: manu meqaca tisa muakaikay neka nu namaya ta kinabulayan kumalji kina kipumaya ta initungan,
English: Mukai Kai Kai is growing up, and her worn-out clothes can't stop her beauty.

Amis: zuaza maqacuvucuvung a tisa kuljeljeljelje a setjumalji a qaljan na kicakav a paljilji tjai muakaikay, gata secevung ta cekelj na vetjek na kama,
English: In the next village, a young man named Gu Le Le secretly went to see Mukai Kai Kai because he admired her, but his aunt caught him in the act.

Amis: sa paqaqadilji a pakiqepu ta aljak nimadju.
English: So he paired up his daughter with Gululep.

Amis: ta vililj anga semekaulj a matjaljaljak ni muakaikay tjai kening,
English: In the end, Mukaikai's parents sent a ghost servant from afar to bring her something that her parents wanted to give her.

Amis: sapakacui ta nanemanemanga ta pacun ti kening ta sinturudan na kinai zuanan ni muakaikay
English: And the ghost servant saw that the house he lived in was not good, so he made a very tall house for her.

Amis: sisan umaq ta vavavav sa pukalucukuci.
English: And there's a platform to look out from.

Amis: ta mangetjez a paumalj ti kuljeljeljelje maljiyan ta na sanguaq a kini tjakaljava ni muakaikay.
English: When Goulele comes to visit her again, Mukaikai invites him to share a meal with her.

Amis: avan anga azua siya na vavuluvulungan tu nakuya seman vililj ta aljak na pulju aya.
English: That's why we can't look down on orphans, or we'll get what's coming to us.

Amis: caquan na titjen a kacalisiyan a seman lalingedan.
English: The nose flute is a unique musical instrument of the Paiwan tribe.

Amis: djapesen a pakangudjus nu palalingedan, a ljingav nimadju matu senay na qatjuvi a vulung aya,
English: Put it under your nostrils and play it, and the sound is said to be very similar to the low sound of a hundred-paced snake.

Amis: a kinamalangan uta matu qulu na vulung a pungudjungudjus
English: The shape of the nose flute and the protruding part of the nose flute also resemble the head of a hundred-paced snake.

Amis: a milimilingan na ramaljemaljeng sinan pazangal aravac a nasi na vulung, aza lalingedan na paruvulung tja sinan paravaca uta,
English: As the Hundred Pacer Snake is closely related to the origin of the head of the snake in Paiwan traditional stories, the Paiwan people regard the nose flute as a very valuable instrument.

Amis: amin a uqaljaqaljay a mazazangiljan a makaya palalingedan,
English: In the past, it was a musical instrument that only a man with the status of a chief could play.

Amis: nu pakapulju ta sikataqaljan a mazazangiljan tja cavuin ta sas nu palalingedan tu sipaqaljay tu siljaveljav ta vusam ta upu.
English: Wrapped in leaves and blown in honor of the loss of mazazangiljan home.

Amis: ta sicuayan neka nu kakivangavangan neka nu kakidraudravan na maqacuvucuvung i qinaljan, nu masulem maqepuqepu sa senay sa malja ljaveljaveljav.
English: In the past, tribal youths had no entertainment, and nightly gatherings to sing and chant became the main activity for them to communicate emotionally.

Amis: a macaqu a palalingedan a uqaljaqaljay, ui tu kina qusav na vavayavayan.
English: Men who play the nose flute do succeed in catching the eye of the opposite sex, and they win many compliments!

Amis: gata ta yatalu ika kisalu ta palalingedan a vavayavayan nakuya aya,
English: In the past, tribal women were not allowed to play the nose flute, and it was considered taboo.

Amis: si palalumalumalj na uqaljaqaljay a saiguan ta palalingedan,
English: The technique of playing the nose flute is like a man-to-man competition.

Amis: nu saigu a paqulid a djemapes aza ljingav matu malalailaing a pupenicepiceq a pucemikecikem,
English: Paiwan nose flute player says pipe with finger holes 'speaks'
The unperforated one maintains the same tone with it.

Amis: matu vinarungan nua uqaljaqaljay a pinakiacadja a pinaka parutavak a pinaka vukai a pakeljang ta pinivaruvarung a tjengelayan.
English: The lead and the chorus respond to each other, and the low voice is like a man's internalized emotions.

Amis: nu izua a tja sikalevaleva a tja sikaqepuqepu a taqaljaqaljan, dremaiyan itjen sa kamaya.
English: You can see the dances at various ceremonies, events, and welcome guests.

Amis: aicu a dremaiyan inika amin a levalevan nu tja sidraiyaiyan,
nu tja ragaljuin a kinemenem aicu a dremaiyan namasan tja sinan paravacan tua tja puzangalan uta.
English: Dance is technically a form of ritual.

Amis: kemasicua ta sinan vecik tua kini tjaucikelan na dripung ta nitjen a ramaljemaljeng, inika amin nu pucekelj nu maljeveq a sidraiyaiyan na titjen a kacalisiyan,
English: In fact, in the official records of the Japanese rule era, the Paiwan people used to, in addition to weddings and five-year festivals, have a large number of events.

Amis: nuri kipuluqem kipurarakacan, nu seman qimang kisaseljang ta mapalisi a dremaiyan a rarakacan.
English: Some tribes also held head-hunting ceremonies to report their achievements in battle, during which a dance (now known as the Warrior's Dance) was customarily performed.

Amis: gata aza masualap anga a tja kakudan kisaseljang a madraudrav a maulav a senay a ziyan.
English: But with the disappearance of the head-hunting custom, it was gradually forgotten.

Amis: tucu anga tjalja maseljudjan anga a masalut ta tja kakudan,
English: Nowadays, we participate most frequently in the Harvest Festival.

Amis: ljemita tu cavilja a nanagac patje hacigac a tja sikasalusalut, maljavar sa penenetj a tja sikataqaljan ta pinakananguaq a qadav tu tja sikasalut.
English: Each tribe chooses an appropriate day between July and August of each year to hold the

Amis: masalut nu aya itjen sipucavicavilj aya a ramaljemaljeng,
tja sipumaljimalji ta na qemati a cemas tu kinisenayan tu namaljenguaq a tja kinikavecengelan tu pinapupiculan a tja kinatacaviljanan.
English: It mainly means to thank God for His favor, and to thank Him who gives the spring rain and fall harvest.

Amis: sipukeljakeljang uta na ramaljemaljeng tu qemacuvung anga ta kinatacavilj kipatagilj anga ta temugut a venaquan ta cavilj aya.
English: Use Xiaomi as a demarcation for the end or beginning of a year.

Amis: nu masalut dremaiyan sa senay ta sipucavicavilj a taqaljaqaljan a sematjumaq itua tja vusam a mazazangiljan, mapaljang aya itjen ta namay tucu a kakudan.
English: The chief would also treat the whole village to a special dinner in return for the annual tax paid by the clan.

Amis: sa nu qemacuvung anga ta mapaljang venucung a tja mazazangiljan ta taqaljaqaljan ta sinipakazelju a pasatjumaq.
English: The festival is performed with singing and dancing in the courtyard of the square in front of the head of the family's house at the end of the festival, called mapaljang.

Amis: malang ta vincikan a kasiv nu aya itjen tja kakudan a paiwan zuku a kacalisiyan,
English: Carving is the best way to express the culture of the Paiwan people.

Amis: nu pacun itjen ta inalangan inika amin a pinuliman tuki na qedjeljem tuki na masevec a cinurisan a tja pacunan,
English: Therefore, the appreciation of carvings is not only about the beauty and carving techniques.

Amis: aki na mapasusu a kakudan na vavecikan a penuljat.
English: The content of the work can express the culture to be passed on.

Amis: nu malang itjen ta sicuayan, mavan a dringay, a saseljudjen nu qemuma, a kizing, a garuc, a qungcu, a lingadja na parukadjapar, a lingadja a papusiyavan, a langalj katua saseljudjen a malaing tu anema.
English: We commonly use wood carvings for hunting and farming tools, spoons, combs, pipes, chopsticks, plates, saucepans, mugs, and other everyday objects.

Amis: a sialaalang a kasiv izua sekazu, sangkilj, taleng, tjeves, drakes, djaqas aya, tjasan sauzayanen katu siyalangan maseljud ta sisanumaq.
English: Commonly used materials for wood carving include ebony, lacquer, cypress, nanmu, camphor, and jiuxiong, most of which are used in building materials.

Amis: a sauljay tjaliyav a ika vincikan, a nu mazazangiljan a cukes, siyalangan, sasuayan vincikan ta sinan quluqulu ta pinaruvulung,
English: Most of the traditional tribal spirit pillars do not have patterns, but the pillars, beams and canopies of the head of the family's house are carved with human heads and the pattern of a hundred-pacer snake.
The other branches of the family are only pictured as wild animals.

Amis: nu qemacuvung ta vincikan qayamen anan na mazazangiljan tuki na sedaljep tuki na djaljemedjem a vincikan,
English: In the past, carvers had to check the finished work to see if the pattern was suitable.

Amis: sikasiyasiyaq a malang a vavayavayan aya,
English: In addition the woman carves to see the taboo

Amis: sa izua a tja sikining a paqeljing ta siseljudjan ta rarasudjan na vincikan.
English: Therefore, the sculptor is obliged to maintain the social order of the plan.

Amis: makeljang a puzangalan a kiljivak nua tja matjaljaljak nu papungadan tja nuitjen!
titjen a tjara macidicidilj ika amin a tja matjaljaljak a tja vuvu a napuzangal tja nuitjen, aljak itjen vuvu itjen nua tja sikadaqaljan uta.
English: To the clan, every child is a treasure of the family and of the tribe.

Amis: tja tinavelak a ngadan nua tja ramaljemaljeng a kemasi ta tja kina ta tja kama, izua nu papungadanan itjen nua tja vusam nua tja sikasaliyalim uta.
English: We get our names from our father's and mother's ancestors' names, and sometimes the chief gives us names.

Amis: ta sicuayan na semeturud itjen aravac a kacalisiyan, mavekelj a valjut ta saqetjuan a kakedriyan,
English: In the past, due to poor medical care, babies had a high incidence of premature death, so to avoid the taboo, the clan would use some "unlucky" names in naming.

Amis: pizua turi valjut itjen papungadanan tua sinipasuljem a ngadan.
English: Expect your child to grow up without disasters.

Amis: izua nu sinipualjak i vavua, papungadanan ta kinikavecengelan malaing tu vaqu, tu djaudjav aya.
English: Sometimes when a baby is born in a field, it is named according to the crop in the field, or millet or groundnut leaves.

Amis: izua nu cinunan a matjaljaljak sa malap ta sacemel, papungadanan ta cumay ta vavui a aljak tu sikipukeljan tu pusepi.
English: Sometimes children are named after their father's hunting trophies, such as bears and mountain hogs.

Amis: aicu a papungadan kumaya tu tja sanparavacen aravc nu aya itjen mavan tja sikaqepuqepu,
English: "The Naming is the beginning of the history of life. Not only does the whole clan have to come together.

Amis: sikisusingelitan tja sikipakeljan tu izua anga tja pasevaliten ta ramaljemaljeng.
English: I wish the newborns strength and blessings as they grow up, with my love for them and my love for my ancestors.

Amis: avan azua tja sikeljan ta puzangalan ta levan nu kicevengan a sangasangasan na marekatjakaka, satje papuluqemi satje kisenai.
English: That's why your name is so precious. It's a symbol of what your family expects of you.

English: Not only can you practise writing, but you can also practise writing.

Amis: maqati auta pazulju ta ku kiqadiljan.
liyav aravac a ku kakipaqenetjan i ta ku sinisusu a kinaita a qadavan,
English: I have a lot of memories in my diary.
I'll be sure to keep it in good condition.
The letter carrier was dressed in green.

Amis: ljemita tu qadav a sematjez tua tigami nua timaima anga.
English: Delivering mail for people every day.

Amis: penaljing timadju a sematjez ta tigami.
English: He still delivers the letters to each house.
(used for either sex when the sex is unknown or unimportant)

Amis: a timaima anga namapuzangal aravac nu gemaugav ta tigami,
English: The people were very happy to receive the letter.

Amis: aza yubing namaya uta a namasilevan a varung.
English: The letter carrier's heart rejoiced just as much.

Amis: nu namalap a cinunan ta sacemel, pavadis ta mamazangiljan, sa paqarut ta marevetjevetjek sana ljemavak ta taqaljaqaljan.
English: If our people went hunting, they would share the kill with friends and relatives.
share (joys, benefits, privileges etc) with others
The brothers and sisters of the family

Amis: nu izua a nia qaljaqalja a kemasi cadja, sipakikadja a nasanguaq a kakanen.
English: If a guest from afar comes to visit, the host will put out the best food.

Amis: nu izua a pupalisiyan i qinaljan, izua a qemavaqavay, a venavavava, a cemuljuculju tua riri.
English: In the tribal ceremonies, some people make millet cakes, some people make millet wine, and some people kill pigs.

Amis: namaya tucu a nia kakudan a kemasicuay.
English: This is our traditional living custom.
In this case, it's the same.

Amis: natjemaucikel a vavulungan a mayatucu, “nu paiyav a kiyaw, nu paqaqa a tjakanga muri maqadv.” aya.
English: The old man used to say, "Frogs sing to bring down rain, and eagles cry to clear the sky."
And so on and so forth.

Amis: a namasan patarevan naicu a kai,
English: The meaning of this sentence is:

Amis: nu semaqaljaqaljay a zaing nua kiyaw nu masulesulem, nu maljiya tjara qemudjalj aya,
English: If you hear frogs chirping in the evening, it will definitely rain the next day;

Amis: nu semaqaljaqaljay a zaing nua tjakanga nu kadjamadjaman, tjara maqadav tucu a vuaq aya.
English: If you hear an eagle cry in the morning, it must be a sunny day.

Amis: mavancu a pinacalivatan nua tjasevalitan a kemasicuay a caquan.
English: This is the accumulation of the life experience of our ancestors.

Amis: palemek tu inika mapasusu a penuljat, ljakua tjara tjaliyav a mapaqulid.
English: It may not be very reliable, but most of the time it works.

Amis: tucu a qadav tinuluan amen na sinsi a malang ta lalingedan.
English: Today our teacher taught us how to make a nose flute.

Amis: vinqac nua tjasevalitan azua, qau a inalang a kemasengesengan, paka ngudjus a djemapes nu pazaing.
English: It was invented by our ancestors, made of bamboo, and is played by blowing through the nose.
When can I play the nose flute?

Amis: pinukakudan a sipazaingan, sikisudjusudju nua namapaqaljay a uqaljaqaljay nu qezemezemetj.
English: There are certain times to play the nose flute. In the evening, it is appropriate to play the nose flute when a young nobleman is chasing his girlfriend.

Amis: ljakua nu pasakuyakuya a mamazangiljan i qinaljan, tja siciluciluq tua makavaljayan tua tja singelitan.
English: If a funeral is held for the head of the village, we can play the nose flute as a sign of remembrance and respect.

Amis: i tua nia qinaljan, izua qinaciljay a umaq, izua kubav, pukasasavan a masantalj.
English: In our tribe, there were slate houses, barns, and courtyards in front of the houses.

Amis: a qinaciljay a umaq na sarenguaq aravac, nu kaljazalangezangan ika zemulezul, nu kaljaljaljeqelan ika vucelelj.
English: The slate house is very cozy, not too hot and not too cold.

Amis: aza kubav papulamian, maqati a qemeceng tua kiki.
English: Barns are used to store grain and keep rats out.

Amis: a kasasavan masanliyaliyav a pacugan, nia kakaqepuan, nia kakivangavangan, maqati auta drasiyan tua na nemanemanga.
English: The patio has many functions, it is our gathering place, our playground, and it can be used for anything.

Amis: namaya tucu a nia a sinicuayan a umaq na payuanzuku.
English: This is the traditional architecture of our Paiwan tribe.
Paiwan, one of the indigenous peoples of Taiwan

Amis: djemetj i akaw ta nia qinaljan.
English: Pingtung City is very close to our tribe.

Amis: a izua, matjaliyaliyav a siyubay, a iyubingkiyuku katua a biuying.
English: There are many stores, a post office and a hospital.

Amis: madjulu amen a kiveli tua nemanga a semasiyubay.
English: It was very easy for us to go to the store and buy things.

Amis: maqati auta mazua i iyubingkiyuku a semeqetj tua paisu, a malap tua paisu katu semusuq tua tigami.
English: You can also go to the post office to deposit money, collect money and send mail.

Amis: nu saqetju itjen, tja sivaik a semabiuying a kipucemel.
English: If we get sick, we go to the hospital.

Amis: aicu a situcuan a sinan kakemudain, ui angata tu sikamanguaq nua tja sikavaljutan.
English: These modern facilities have indeed made our lives more convenient.

Amis: nu maljutaiday a caucau i taiwan, kimaya izua a madrusa a kacalisiyan.
English: If there are two aborigines out of a hundred people in Taiwan.

Amis: saka kimaya izua a papamav a kamayan i qinaljananan. aza papamav napatjavat anga semalizuk.
English: And about half still live in their original tribes. The other half have moved to the flatlands.

Amis: ayatua a i lizuk tja madjulu ta i yumaq a muri sengesengan.
English: Because it is easier to find job opportunities in the city than in the original tribe.

Amis: mavanusika tja tjuruvu a maqacuvucuvung a vaik a semalizuk.
English: So there are a lot of young people who go to the cities.

Amis: tjalju lizuk anga tiamadju a semanumaq, a kipusengsengan, a pucekelj sa pualjak.
English: They have been settling in the city, working, getting married, and having children.
give birth to a child or children

Amis: tucu, tjuruvu anga aravac a sinipualjak sa meqaca i lizuk a kakedriyan na kacalisiyan.
English: Nowadays, many Aboriginal children are born and raised in the urban areas.

Amis: i tua nia qinaljan, nu sikaalu a qiljas patje sikasiva a qiljas, nu makakivaqu anga, izua a nia masalut a picavilj.
English: In our tribe, the Harvest Festival is held every year between August and September, after the millet harvest.

Amis: na masan pazangal aravac aicu a qadav i tua nia qinaljan. sisaumaumaq, sikaqepuqepu nua titjen a marevetjevetjek a marekakakaka.
English: It's the most important day of the tribe and a time for our family and friends to come together.

Amis: temaqaljaqaljan itjen i kakateveteveljan a semenasenay, a zemiyaziyan, a maleva tua nia kinacaviljan.
English: Everyone celebrated the harvest by singing and dancing on the fairgrounds.

Amis: tucu a cavilj, namakahikuki tia kama i tjivuluan a tacemekeljan a kemasi taipaq.
English: This year Uncle Tjivuluan's family flew back from Taipei.

Amis: mayatucu ti kaka i puljaljuyan, “nu i taipaq amen tjalja semingelitan a tja masalut i qinaljan.”
English: Cousin Puljaljuyan said, "What we miss the most in Taipei is the Harvest Festival in our hometown.

Amis: tua nia sikipaqenetjan, sa patjavang tua nia sevalitan, mavansika nu padjaljun ta sikalima a cavilj, maljeveq a nia sikataqaljan.
English: In order to remember and honor our ancestors, the Ancestral Spirit Ceremony is held every five years in our hometown.

Amis: nu i vuavuaq nu tjaukaljiya, maqepuqepu a maqacuvucuvung i qinaljan, sa vaik a kicacevungan tua nia sevalitan a semagadugadu.
English: At first light that day, all the young men of the tribe gathered together and went to the hill to greet their ancestors.
(after a verb of motion indicates movement away from the speaker)

Amis: nu mangetjez tiamadju, sinipadjuluanga tua qavay, tua vinengel, tua vutjulj, tua vava katu saviki. sa patjavangan a pikiniveqacan.
English: When they returned, millet cakes, rice dumplings, meat, wine and betel nut were prepared for them. The dumplings were placed in the square of the ancestral house.

Amis: nakemasi varung a kisukub a kiqaung aza parakaljay, a nia sikataqaljan matu nakitateveljan amen tua nia sevalitan a semenasenay a zemiyaziyan a mapaljapaljang.
English: The priests were very sincere in their worship and prayers. We, the villagers, sang, danced, and gathered around the festival as if we were meeting with our ancestors.

Amis: a pucekelj tja sinan paravac aravac tua tja kinai kacauwanan a payuanzuku.
English: Getting married is the most important event in our Paiwanese life.
Paiwan, one of the indigenous peoples of Taiwan

Amis: nu izua muri pucekelj a nia sikataqaljan, na masilevan amen a pusaladj a padjulu tua muri sikarakuda nu i vuaq anga.
English: When someone in the tribe gets married, all of us in the village prepare for the day with joy.

Amis: aza sauqaljay namasi tjukez, aza savavayan napadjulu tua sitjakaljavaljava a qavay a vutjulj katua vava tu sivucung ta mareka tjakaka.
English: The groom brings food, the bride's family prepares millet cakes, meat, and wine, and together they host a banquet for the townspeople and family relatives.

Amis: nu napatatekel anga ta vava, pasusuanan uta ta kakudan a marepagaugav tua sinilisi, tu sinipukeljang tua parekiljivak niamadju a palalaut.
English: After the bride and groom have made a toast to each other, it is customary to present them with a gift as a testament to their eternal love.

Amis: aza ramaljemaljeng, temulu sa papaulingav tua kakudan, sa aza nia sikataqaljan masivarung a papupicul tjaiyamadju.
English: The elders gave them advice and exhortations, and the townspeople blessed them with their hearts.
From the bottom of my heart

Amis: muri kitjaula amen tucu a vuaq.
siniceged amen nua gakku tua ramaljemaljeng turi semanvuluvulung tja nu amen.
English: The school invited the Elders to organize a Bar Mitzvah for us.

Amis: kilingavan amen nua ramaljemaljeng tu kemuda a qemuyulj ta kasiv, katu kemuda a tjepana a kigang a kiquzang.
English: The elders tested us on bundling wood and going to the river to catch crabs and shrimp.

Amis: nu natjemekulj anga men tua sinikiqayam papuqarutan amen tua cinapan a vavuy.
English: If we passed the test, we were given roasted mountain pork.
share (joys, benefits, privileges etc) with others

Amis: azua ramaljemaljeng sikiqaung amen ta nia manguaqan, sane papupiculi tu kisamulja tua nia sengsengan.
English: The elders prayed for us and encouraged us to take our work seriously.

Amis: kapatagilj a semenay ta sikitjaulaula a senay, matjatjavilivililj amen a vaik i gakku.
English: When the graduation song is played, we walk out of school one by one.

Amis: “aiyanga lja tjaljak lja tjavuvu! ulja namakisenay nasuljivatj mun i tua nu djalan a patjaivililj anga!” ayain amen nua nia sinsi kata nia matjaljaljak.
English: "Blessings to you all! May you have peace and success in your new life!" The teachers and elders blessed us.

Amis: ti kaka a tjavulung a vavayan
ti kaka a tjavulung a uqaljay
ku kaka a tjaljaljak a uqaljay
ku kaka a tjaljaljak a vavayan

English: the thing stuck between the teeth
at the foot of the mountain
witchcarft appliance (witch doctor use it for treatment)
peeling the bark of a tree
calling (e.g. calling before feeding the chickens)
dry (e.g., drying clothes in the sun)
pack up (imperatives, as in pack up)
fishing for fish and shrimp by cage
lift off (as in lift off the lid).
burn (as in burning the hair of prey)
marry to a non-ethnic clan member
undercooked (if this piece of meat is raw)
fragile (e.g. this wire is prone to breakage)
in the process of (doing something or happening)

Amis: patagilj anga, kitulu mangetjez anga ti sinsi qivu ti pangcang, “gacalji! drequngi!”
English: It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

Amis: pasi qaca men a qivu, “nanguanguaq sun sinsi.”
tazua nu kitulutulu, tuluan a amen ni sinsi ta pinayuanan a sasupuan.
English: In class, the teacher taught us the paiwan language of numbers.

Amis: kiciur a men ta sinsi a semupu, semenay a men ta sasupuan a senay.
English: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

Amis: liyaw a ku kinitulu ta kay a pinayuanan.
English: I have learned many paiwan languages.

Amis: ljemita ta qadaw a ken a sema gaku, ljemita ta qadaw a ken a itulu tua pinayuanan, uri ikay a ken a palangeda tjaikina.
English: I go to school every day, I learn the paiwan language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

Amis: ti sakinu a ngadan na ku kama.
ti kivi a ngadan na ku kina.
izua macidilj a ku kaka tjavulung a uqaljay, ti piya timadju, tapuluq sa ita anga cavilj nimadju.
English: I have a brother, his name is piya, he is 11 years old.

Amis: kitulutulu amen i tua mamaw a gakku.
English: We study in the same school.

Amis: tjengelay aken kati kaka tjavulung a uqaljay a semenay.
English: Both my brother and I like to sing.

Amis: tjengelay aken a ljemangui nu kalja pulavayan maciur a men a tacemekeljan a vaik a ljemanguy.
English: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

Amis: tjengelay aken a kipuqali ta vaquan a qali, maqati amen a maciur a semenay katua ljemanguy.
English: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

Amis: a nia kinaizuanan a tjumaq i tainan.

English: There are five people in our family.

Amis: i tua nia taqumaqanan matjelu a men a mare siruvetjek.
English: There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

Amis: na kitevelj aken tjai kama kina kaka tjavulung a uqaljay kata vavayan.
English: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

Amis: qacaqaca a ku kama, a ku kama. taizing.
English: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

Amis: mariljay a ku kina, a ku kina. kuisang.
English: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

Amis: nu i tjumaq ti kama penayuwanan nu ikai tja nu amen.
English: My father speaks the paiwan language with us at home.

Amis: nu kalja pulavayan vaik a men a maqinaljan.
English: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

Amis: maciyur aken kata ku kaka tjavulung a djemameq ta qubequb.
English: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

Amis: tjengelay aken aravac ta niamen a cemkemkelj.
English: I like our family very much.

Amis: tucu a qadaw vaik aken kati kina ma casaw a kivangavang.
English: I went out with my mother today.

Amis: cangiyangiya ravac a kalevelevan nu maqadadaw inika ljaljeqel inika maculju sarenguaq a vali.
English: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

Amis: keman amen ta minpaw i tjai vavaw ta cemel maqadaw a kinacavacavan sarenguaq angata.
English: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.

Amis: nu pasuvililj tu cengelj mapavalit anga kalevelevan ta qudjidjilj.
English: In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

Amis: ku kivadaqan ti kina aku qudjidjilj a quljaw na kalevelevan.
English: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

Amis: qivu ti kina tjara uri mangetjez anga a buhu aya.
English: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

Amis: neka nu qerepus i kalevelevan nu qezemezemetj minqut anga vitjuqan.
English: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

Amis: ka tjumaumaq aken i djalan iqaung aken ta vitjuqan.
English: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

Amis: ulja inika na mangetjez a buhu, saljinga ken ta vaik a kivangavang.
English: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

Amis: a ku gakku i ljaqedi ta niamen a umaq djemavac aken a ljemitaqadaw a magakku djemavac aken uta sematjumaq.
English: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

Amis: inika kudral a nia gakku inika tjuruvu a situ na makakeljang amen a mapuljat.
English: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

Amis: matevetevelj a kakedryan i undudju meseljang a kivangavang a maljavar.
English: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

Amis: kiseljang uta tiasinsi tjanuamen a kivangavang a gakku namaya ta qaca a tacemekeljan.
English: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

Amis: parimasudj amen a ljemita qadaw sa tja ljenguaqi a parimasudj a tja kakituluan.
English: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

Amis: izua vaik a zemuking ta qezung izua vaik a semuap.
English: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

Amis: parimasudj amen tua putuputung i kgakku na marasurasutj amen a mapuljat a gakku na maparimasutj a ljemita tu qadaw.
English: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

Amis: tatiyaw na vaik aken a paljilji tjai vuvu a uqaljay.
English: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

Amis: cuacuai anga men a inika mecevung singlit aravac aken tjaimadju.
English: We haven’t seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

Amis: kapacun ti vuvu a uqaljay tjanuaken pakanan aken ta kudamunu sa patekelan aken ta utja.
English: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

Amis: qaljemeqem a sinitalem a kudamunu ni vuvu a uqaljay sanguaq angata.
English: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

Amis: tjengelay aken uta ta uciya ni vuvu nu tekelen bulay angata.
English: I also like grandpa’s tea, it’s tasted good too.

Amis: nu vecekadan tu qadaw meseljang aken kati vuvu a vavayan a kemesa tua nia cengel.
English: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

Amis: kemesa ti vuvu tu liyaw angata cengelj izua ciqaw kuka siyak izua luli uta.
English: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

Amis: kana kincengel anga men vaik amen a mapuljacengan a kiljaceng.
English: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

Amis: liyaw a kini vurasi vasa rukiya ni vuvu tu sipakacu tjanuaken a tjumaq.
English: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

Amis: kipusau aken tjayamadju kivalanga ken nu tjaivililj uta ku ayain a ikai.
English: I said goodbye to them and said I’d see them next time.

Amis: kinacu amen ni sinsi a ma kakataliduan ta qemuziquzip i paljing amen a na siyugu a uri veneli ta kipu.
English: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

Amis: ka ljetaladj amen ta kakataliduan ta qemuziquzip kikai ti sinsi, “a i qayaw qayaqayam a i tjai likuz qatjuvi kacidicidilju a talidu a mapuljat.” aya ti sinsi.
English: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

Amis: marekutj aken ta qatjuvi saka ini aken a pacun ta kana qatjuvi.
English: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

Amis: liyaw a ku pinacunan a qayaqayam a minlayalayap ita kasiw a pacacikecikel pacun aken uta ta ljequ a na taqed i taladj ta lala na kasiw.
English: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

Amis: izua zu izua rigi kata likuljaw ita kakataliduan ta qemuziquzip maleva ken ta ku pinacunan tucu a qadaw.
English: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

Amis: liyaw a sasing a ku sinasing tu sipapacun tjai kina kati kama.
English: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

Amis: nutjaivililj uri kicaciyuran tjai kama kati kina a mangtjez.
English: Next time I will come with my parents.

Amis: tucu ka pulavalavai vaik aken kata ku kaka tjavulung a vavayan a ma taitu a paljilji tjai kama i kuliw.
English: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle, kuliw.

Amis: na maka kisiya men a kemasi taihuku a ma taitu.
English: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

Amis: tjemalju a men i taitu unting ti kama i kuliw ta palidring a mangetjez a kicacevung tjanuamen.
English: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

Amis: ini ka cadja ta tapaw ni kama kuliw a hucecan ununting ta palidring palamu djemaljun.
English: The station is not far from my uncle’s house, and it’s just a short drive away.

Amis: izua tjaljeqacaqaca a pugungngan idungdung ta tapaw ni kama kuliw meseljang amen a kididingsiya mapugungan.
English: There is a big ranch near my uncle’s house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

Amis: i pugungngan kacuin amen ni kama kuliw a pakan ta gung kata rigi.
English: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

Amis: ka qezemezemetj meseljang amen a sema lizuk a keman.
English: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

Amis: liyaw a palidring i lizuk saka na kiutubai amen a mazua.
English: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

Amis: ka uri vaik ta zua pacunan tu cinakau anga utubai maka basu anga men a vaik.
English: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

Amis: tucu i taihuku anga men qadjau kimadjumak anga utubai ni kama kuliw.
English: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don’t know if my uncle’s motorcycle has been found.

Amis: kakakedriyan aken i kuskus a niatapaw kapatagilj anga ken a magakku patjavat anga matawing i lizulizuk a nia sikacu.
English: When we were young, our family lived in kuskus. After I started school, we moved to Taoyuan and have been living in the city ever since.

Amis: ka madaigaku anga ken kitulu aken ta kinacalisiyan a bungka sa ku keljang anga ta i taiwan a kacalisiyan izua ngaquaqn namakakaizua a bunka.
English: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

Amis: manasika tucu a cavilj nu kaljapulavayan uri vaik aken kati kaka tjavulung a uqaljai a paljilji ta ramaljemaljeng a uri kiljaljuai ta nimitja a kemacidiljan a bunka.
English: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

Amis: alu anga puluq a cavilj na ramaljemaljeng ljakua nu tja pacunan namaya ta inika vuluvulung.
English: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

Amis: ku kivadaq timadju pida su kinacaqu a kai macaqu aravac a ikai ta pinaiwanan saigu uta ikai ta na tjukuku zipun kilang a kai.
English: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in paiwan, as well as Chinese, Hakka and Japanese.

Amis: ka kivadaq anga ken tjaimadju kemeljang anga aken tu na kemasi kakedriyan kitulu ta zipun a kai a valjaw nimadju pairang i tua karakudakudain nimadju tjuruvu a kineljang a kilang manasika liyaw a kinacaqu a kai.
English: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Chinese, and he knows many Hakkas at work, so he can speak so many languages.

Amis: tazua kakiqaqivuavuan amen liyaw a sini pasemalaw a pakatua qemaljup a saiguan kata kakudan.
English: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

Amis: kumalji inika liyaw a niakeljange ljakua nia pinaka tua dinguwa a paiga maqati a gemalju kiljaluai a kilangeda.
English: Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

Amis: kakakedryan aken neka nu ku kemeljang tua ku bunka masiyaq aken a maciljilj ta ku kinacalisiyanan.
English: When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

Amis: nu cuai anga nu tjaliau a kineljangan paka pakisumalji a kinanguaq kinabulai sedjalep a sikizengel a kinapaiwanan.
English: The more I know, the more I feel that being a Paiwan is unique and something to be proud of.

Amis: tucu a qadaw nu masulem uri mangetjez anga ku kaka tjaljaljak a uqaljai.
English: My younger brother is going home this evening.

Amis: vaik aken kati vuvu a vavayan a semavavelian a veneli ta djurikuku tu sipadjulu a kemesa ta sanguanguaq a kaiven tu sipakan ta ku kaka tjaljaljak a uqaljai.
English: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

Amis: cemalivat amen ta vaveliyan liyaw a vaquan a ljaceng.
English: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

Amis: na veneli amen ta ingcai qaqilj kata daikung.
English: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

Amis: qivu azua i ljaqedi a paveliveli ta kudamunu a tauki, “qaljemeqem aku panguralj kata qudis pai veliu tu kedri aya!”
English: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

Amis: na veneli amen ta panguralj kata qudis.
kacemalivat amen ta vavelian ta vutjulj, qivu a tauki, “anema su velin? tucu a qadaw a kuka kakudralj sa qaluman nu ita tjeluaidai.”
English: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today's chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

Amis: paka pazangal ti vuvu a vavayan kivadaqan a tauki maqati a menadjulu a paveli.
English: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

Amis: ljakua qivu a tauki minamadjulu anga inika maqati a paljateku ta kakavelian.
English: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

Amis: a i ljaqedi a tauki qivu ta idu veliu ta ku ciqaw kudralj saka madjulu.
English: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

Amis: kacuai anga veneli anga men ta kuka kata ciqaw tjumaq sa kemesa tu tja nu ita cekui a djamai.
English: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.
After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

Amis: na palingas aku kaka tjaljaljak a uqaljai na papintjus a ikai ta ini anga maqati a pulavai a puhitayan nu tjaivililj a niciubi maqati anga tjumaq.
English: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn't take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

Amis: ikai ti vuvu a vavayan liyaw anga kinsa qaqivu a mapuljat ta kemanan!
English: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let's eat together!

Amis: na tjemaulj amen ta mareka nia kasusu qali ta meseljang a kaiv.
English: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

Amis: izua ku qali a ti kuliw timadju ru maraurau a kemacu ta nemanga.
English: I have a classmate named kuliw, he often forgets to bring things.

Amis: nu kitulutulu kisedjam ta salasaladja tua sivecivecik siquliqulip kata vavecikan a qadupu.
English: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

Amis: nu puita pudrusa putjelu pasedjaman timadju na zuma.
English: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

Amis: ljakua izua za inika bulai a kakudanan nimadju ru kisedjam sa ini a nga pacikel.
English: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

Amis: nu cuai anga inika nga pasedjam tjaimadju.
English: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

Amis: izua ka ita qadaw vaik amen a mapuljat a kivangavang.
English: One day, we all went on an outing together.

Amis: kaidjalan lingau ti kuliw ta sama kaya ljakua na maraurau a kemacu ta sidjuadjuas.
English: On the way, kuliw wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

Amis: kisedjam timadju ta cilikami tua salasaladj ljakua tevelain tjaimadju namaya ken uta a inika na kemacu.
English: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn’t bring them either.

Amis: qemaung ta latjakan ti kuliw madjalw sa ikaikai aqumaya inika ken a nu pasedjaman ta cilikami aya.
English: kuliw burst into tears. He said angrily, why don’t everyone lend me toilet paper!

Amis: pasemalavan na salasaladj timadju, ayatua inika sun a kemacu nu kisedjam sun inika su pacekel!
English: The classmate told him, because you didn’t bring it yourself, and you wouldn’t return the things lent to you!

Amis: katiyau anga tu qadaw na medjama ti kuliw a magakku pacikelen a kinisedjam a nemanga na salasaladj.
English: The next day at school, kuliw arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

Amis: kipaqaljai ta salasaladj ti kuliw ikai, ta tjara kemacu anga nu tjaivililj ta nemanga timadju masalu uta ta salasaladj ta na selaing a pasedjam ta nemanga tjaimadju.
English: kuliw apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

Amis: a ku kama ru qaljuqaljup i qinaljap.
English: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

Amis: ka kakedriyan aken nu uri vaik a qemaljup nu qezemezemetj ti kama kati kama i kuliw kemacu ta tjakidi kata kuang.
English: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

Amis: nu maljiya mangtjez a na kemacu ta qinaljup tiamadju.
English: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

Amis: izua nu vavui izua nu lava izua nu patavatan uta.
English: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

Amis: i ta sidjaljunan a qinaljan pangaljen niamadju ta sikataqaljan azua qinaljup a sacemel.
English: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

Amis: tjara makavaljai aken sakamaya tjai kama a vaik a qemaljup.
English: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

Amis: ikai ti kama nu meqacanga ken kacuin anga sun aya.
English: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

Amis: saigu uta puringai ta sidjameqan ta sacemel a i qinaljan a uqaljaqaljai saigu tiamadju a semanaya ta pareqel kata kadringayan a ringai.
English: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

Amis: saigu aravac a semanaya ta pareqei a ringai ti kama ikai ti kama aicu sidjamedjameq ta patjavatan tja kigagaljuin a pacun a pinakazuan a tjekap na sacemel tjapizuain i tua pinakazuan a djalan na sacemel a ringai.
English: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

Amis: ayatua sika maqatiyan a djaljaw a kiseljang ta ramaljeng a qemaljup kicaquan aken a ljemita qadaw ta puringai a ku ringai djaljaw a paqulid sa djemameq ta sacemel.
English: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

Amis: kapacun ti kama tja nu aken ikai ta nu tjaivililj tjara tjalja saiguan anga sun aya.
English: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

Amis: maqacuvucuvung anga ken tucu kemavuc aken ta ku panaq kata vakela a kiseljang tjai kama a vaik a qemaljup.
English: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

Amis: nu cemikel a maqinaljan azua qinaljup a sacemel siseljiva tua taqaljaqaljan a caucau.
English: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

Amis: ikai ti kama maleva itjen ta tja sevalitan a na papumanguaqan sa izua mapeljuq a tja sacemel a qinaljup.
English: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

Amis: na sekavililj anga en a sema gaku ka kadjaman.
English: I was late for school this morning.

Amis: na dremaudraw aen, masi kabang a semagaku.
English: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

Amis: neka nu anema a u kinacu.
English: I didn’t bring anything with me.

Amis: matevelj amen, a pacun tua sapitj a kitulutulu.
English: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

Amis: nu sekiseking, pasedjaman aen tua sivecivecik katua siquliqulip nua u salasaladj.
English: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

Amis: aitucuin aen ni sinsi, “nu tjayvililj udamau anga migacalj, mayanga sekavililj!”
English: The teacher told me, “Wake up earlier next time and don’t be late again!”

Amis: ti Kuliu a u kaqaliyan, aljak nua sePaiwan uta timadju.
English: My good friend’s name is Kuliu, and he is also an Paiwan child.

Amis: maciyuciyur amen a kitulu i Tjaqaciljay a qinaljan.
English: We study together in the Tjaqaciljay tribe.

Amis: ru kilangda men tua vuluvulung a menilimilingan, macaqu amen aravac a penaiwanan.
English: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Paiwan proficiently.

Amis: qaca tu kural aen, kedri tu mariljay ti Kuliu.
English: I am tall and overweight, while Kuliu is short and thin.

Amis: tarivak aravac ti Kuliu, tjenglay amen a mapuljat taymadju.
English: Kuliu is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

Amis: malalumalj tua undu nua gaku kasuni a qadaw masanliyaw aravac a sipalalumalj a undu.
English: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

Amis: izua mavavijvilj tua calis, tjemadrek tua buru, mintuluq, zemiyan katua penanaq.
English: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

Amis: na sekulilj aen ka mintuluq aen, na pedjamuq tu qaca ravac a u cungal.
English: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

Amis: ljakua migacalj aen, sa getjem a minntuluq a pasaqayaw.
English: But I stood up and continued running forward.

Amis: ka djemaljun aen tua pautezan, maleva aravac a timaimanga caucau.
English: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

Amis: ljaki inika en a malap tua sangasangasan, ngadan na maleva en aravac, ayatua u qinacuvung a lalumaljen.
English: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

Amis: na vaik amen kati ama kivala tjay ama i Sakinu.
English: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

Amis: na mapasaqetju a kula ni ama i Sakinu.
tjinumaljan amen tu na maberung tu ita berung a qaljiyu.
English: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

Amis: ka ljemelaljelay timadju tua qaliyu na matjani a kemasi tua qaljiyu.
English: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

Amis: na kemacu ti ama tua vutjulj a gung katua saviki tu sipavay tjay ama i Sakinu.
English: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

Amis: masudju amen i qumaqan kati ama i Sakinu, pinaseljavakan aen tu liyaw a milimilingan.
English: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

Amis: ka uri vaik anag en ， kemazala ti ama i Sakinu tu na meqaca ngaen, tu tja vangsar anagen.
English: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

Amis: u ayain tiama i Sakinu: ‘’ nu menguaq anga su kula, pangtjezu anga matjanuamen a kivala。”
English: I said, When your foot gets better

Amis: ka2022a cavilj, na pakaigi a sihu tu maqati anga vecikan a mibunsiu tu na sekacalisiyan a ngadan.
English: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

Amis: u kinivala sa kivadaqi azua cuacuay anga kiqaqav tua sihu tu vecikan a mibusiu tua “na kacalisiyan a ngadan’’ a i qinaljan a ti Kuliu a maqacuvucuvung.
English: I interviewed Kuliu, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

Amis: niapinenetj tucu sisekezan a qadaw tu uri kivalain a semata tjumaq nimadju.
English: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

Amis: ka maljavaljavar amen pinasemalavan aen tua kinasizuan nua ngadan nimadju, pinakeljangan aen tua sikatacemkeljan katua nimadju a qinaljan.
English: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

Amis: “akumaya gemtjem sakamaya tu mumalj tua ngadan, manu nakuya sipavecikan a sicuayan?’’ u ayain a kivadaq.
English: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

Amis: aitucuin aen nimadju, “ayatua a ciniukukan a vecik inika sedjameq tua kaqulidan a ngadan nimadju, a qaliqali “ku siyenseng” ayanan nu qemaqivu tjaymadju”, liyaw ana masan djeli a kay.
English: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Ku Xian Sheng

Amis: ati Kuliu qivu, “a veciken tu na kinacalisiyan a ngadan, kanimitjan angata ngadan. a u ngadan avan nu na sevalit tua nimitja tjarakacalisilisiyan, nimitja cemekeljan, na saljinga itjen tu madjumak a kanimadjuan a ngadan.”
English: Kuliu said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

Amis: na vaik amen kati vuvau a vavayan i papaveliyan a zematjak tua racev, na kemacu tu liyaw a sinitalem a ljaceng, sa sanayai tua na kinacaliiyan a kakanen sa paseljavakan tua caucau a mapuljat.
English: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

Amis: tjenglay a mapuljat tua zinatjakan ni vuvu a vavayan, tjuruvu a veneli tua kamangulj katua ljaqacay, tjuruvu uta mangtjez a keman tua sinadjamay nimadju.
English: Everyone loved my grandmother’s stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

Amis: sanguaq aravac a kinsa nimadju a kuniyaw katua djuadjuay a tjinaljek, djinaung tua aradj a vutjulj nua vavay, madjaulj a tjuruvu a qaljaqalja tua sequan, matjatjavilivilj a caucau matua nia zinatjakan.
English: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

Amis: nu kemesakesa ti vuvu a vavayan, i gidi aen a djemaudjaulj tua qaljaqalja. tjarautjautjau aen i gidi a, “niyamen a sinitalem a ljaceng, na meqca i gadu, pay kirimu a mangtjez a veneli u!”
English: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

Amis: palamu mapuljt a sepaveli a nia racev, maytucu ti vuvu a vavayan, “ayatua ulja izua sun na pusaladj lja.”
English: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, \It’s all thanks to your help.\""

Amis: aicu sengsengan, na matulu anagen tua na cemelanga katua kakanen a kakeljangan, autauta seljavak anga en tua luljayan nua zematjak a paveli.
English: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

Amis: pacun aen tua tjenglayan nivuvu a vavayan ta sicuayan a kakanen, na miyazuan saka mapungadan a u vinarungan.
English: Seeing my grandmother’s passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

Amis: a se ravar, na kemasi vavulung i tjavadran a qinaljan;
English: The Ravar group inhabited tjavadran in ancient times.

Amis: vililjanga tjemavat a sema paridrayan, kavililj anga matjatju kudakuda a pasa cavak a pasa djineljipan.
English: Later, they moved to Dashe, and then to Castle Peak and Anpo,

Amis: a sema sagaran katua sema tjukuvulj a zuma, i tjailjaking a zuma, izua na sema manga uta.
English: Some of them were moved to Devon, Sega or dispersed to Maolin Township.

Amis: qau a se vuculj, na masan musalj a qinaljan anan, mavan a se paumaumaq katua se pavavuavua, a se paumaumaq izua i kavulungan, a na qeminaljan,
English: The Fuchu group is divided into the paumaumaq and the pavuavua. The paumaumaq are those who live in the Dawusan area, while those who migrated from the Dawusan area to the south and east are called pavuavua.

Amis: sa azua na tjemavat a na sema navalj, pasa se paqaluqalu aya itjen, se qalu aya uta, a na sema qaraba, matjaliyaw a qinaljan,
English: Those who moved to the East were also known as Bakalukalu or simply Sikalu.

Amis: matjaliyaw a qinaljan, uzai a se tjakuvukuvulj, uzai a se paliljaliljaw mavan a tjalja navaljan tua i Taiwang.
English: The inhabitants of Hengchun, who moved to the southernmost part of Taiwan, are called Balilalilao.

Amis: a kemasicuay nu qivu tua senema a caucau, mavan a kasizuanan a sipaputarevan, a paru a na kemaizuan i paridrayan, se paridrayan aya;
English: The traditional way of referring to the indigenous people is by the name of the place where they live, such as separidrayan for the Dashe people;

Amis: azua kaizuan i tjukuvulj, se tjukuvukuvulj ayain; izua kemaizua i karadjungan se karadjungan ayain; a izua i kipua, sekipua ayain.
English: Those who lived in Oguemon were called se-tjakuvukuvulj; those who lived in Kakarudo were called se-kaladjungan; those who lived in Koryuko were called se-kipua; those who lived in Manchuria were called se-vangcul, and so on, and others were called according to the names of the tribes in which they lived.

Amis: tucu a tagilj nua papungadan tua se paiwan, kemasi 1630 a cavilj, tuazua azua Ulanda se Baljaka, a na patagilj a sema gadu i qinaljan,
English: The present name Paiwan originated from the Dutch who entered the mountains in about 1630 (the third year of the Dutch occupation of Taiwan) for their vested interests.

Amis: mavan a dindusi a sangasangasan a sema qinaljan, i pasa viri i kavulungan, azua i paiwan a qinaljan, tucu pinapungadanan tu se va-uan aya ngadan nua qinaljan, qau tucu pinacikel anga tu paiwan,
English: Sending missionaries into the aboriginal tribes, the first in southern Taiwan went to the Paiwan tribe in the northern Dawu Shanfang.

Amis: qau tuazua a se Ulanda nu vaik a pacacikel tua tja qinaljan, sa selangada tu mamaw a kai, mamaw a quljau nua kina caucauan, se paiwan aya uta.
English: After that, when the Dutch traveled south and east and met people who spoke the same language and had the same skin color, they called them "Paiwan".

Amis: inika sinilaing ta ngadan nua qinaljan. kemasi tuazuanga, patje mangtjez a pairang, sivecik anga itje tu se paiwan.
English: There was no geographical distinction until the Han Chinese came to Taiwan and came into contact with the Paiwan people, who then translated paiwan as "Paiwan".

Amis: ljakua timitja se paiwan angata itjen, nuqivu itjen se paiwan aya itjen, mavan anga aicu a tagilj nua tja ngadan a se paiwan.
English: However, the Paiwan still pronounce themselves as "Bayiwan" (the first character is not pronounced), and this is how the name "Paiwan" began.

Amis: ita djipun anan tazua, sinupu a kacalisiyan a caucau i taiwan, na djemaljun ta 533610 a caucau aya, aicu a ita 2013 a caviljan a vincikan.
English: According to the census of the Japanese rule era, the total population of Taiwan's aborigines was 533,601.

Amis: sa titjen a se paiwan a caucau na djemaljun ta 95650 ana tjuruvu, tjakedri ta se-qami a caucau,
English: The Paiwan population is 95,065, accounting for about 18% of the total population, second only to the Amis.

Amis: nu tja palaingen a qapulu, a sepawan i akau na djemaljun tua 47290 a caucau,
English: Today it is even clearer, if we look at the population of Paiwan where they are domiciled in Pingtung County, there are 47,000 and 290 people are the most numerous.

Amis: tjalja tjuruvuan tua se-paiwan anga, itjuzuma a ivalangau a sa-paiwan, 16437 a caucau,
English: In Taitung County, there were 16,437 people.

Amis: si pasan musalj a tjuruvuwan, mavan a i takau 7811 a itjen a se paiwan,
English: In Kaohsiung City, there are 7,811 people living in the third place.

Amis: izua uta a na kemaizua itjuzuma a qinaljan uta, na kemaizua i lizuk na tjuruvu auta, tjara djemaljun tua 23527 a caucau.
English: There are 23,527 people living in other counties and metropolitan areas.

Amis: mapacun anga tucu a tja caucau, tjuruvu anga idjiyu a tjemavat a sema lizuk a kemaizua.
English: In recent years, the exodus of ethnic groups has become quite common.

Amis: namatatevetevelj anga tua pairang, izua puvaljau auta ta pairang, tusia mekedri anga a tja caucau.
English: This, together with the frequent intermarriages between the Clansmen and the Han Chinese or other ethnic groups, has led to changes in the increase and decrease of the population of the Clansmen.

Amis: na matjatjukudakuda anga itjen a se paiwan, qau masa tjamapulju tjamapulju anga itjen paiwan.
English: In addition, the natural rate of increase in the population of our ethnic group is also lower than that of the flatlanders.

Amis: a tjalja uzaiyan a pacugan a tja sikavarung, mavan tua mapazulju a nasekakuda sa a pacai,
English: The main reason for this is that the medical profession has deduced that the proportion of deaths from accidents is higher than that from old age.

Amis: tja liyau anga uta namapusaqetjuan atua nasa ramaljengan, tusiya tjamapulju anga tjen a se paiwan.
English: It will also result in a slow increase in population.

Amis: ita 1915 a cavilj, kadjipun-anan tazua, sinupu a tja caucau nua djipun, na djemaljun tua 40459 a caucau.
English: The total population of the Paiwan was 41,459 in 1915.

Amis: patj tucu na cemalivat anga tua 100 a cavilj, titjen a mapuljat a se paiwan, djemaljun tu 95650 a tjuruvuan, na mapazulju tu 53660 a caucau.
English: Today (2015), one hundred years later, the total population is 95,065, an increase of 53,606.

Amis: ljawua nu tja sisupuan, tinaidaian. ljemitacavilj nama pazulju tu 37 a caucau;
English: However, if averaged out, the number will only increase by about 37 per year.

Amis: sa nu tja lje-itain a qiljas nu semupu, matjelu a caucau a nama pazulju. namakeljang tu namekedri aravac a tja caucau a se paiwan.
English: An increase of only three people per month is obviously low.

Amis: sa nu tja palaingan aicu a vecik, mapaqulid angata a itjen a se paiwan mekedrikedri ma kiluvaluvad anga tja(kinalingdjeljan) a caucau,
English: From the above data, it is a fact that the population of our people is small.

English: There are many place names for the tribes of this tribe in Pingtung County. There are ten villages in Sandimen Township, including Sandimen, Saijia, Koushe, Ma'er, Anpo, Qingshan, Qingye, Dalai, and Dewen Dashe.

From the early days of the jonquil industry as the most important economic industry of the Southern Paiwan, in the forested areas of the villages have been planted a large area of jonquil, which is the most important economic industry of the Southern Paiwan.

sa patagilj anga temalem tua maqati a sipaveliveli a qinuman, a maru tjuqulj, kiyasaba, veljevelje, saviki, saizarlu.

Amis: manasika a manges namasan pazangal anga kasizuanan nua sikavaljut nua se paiwan i navalj.

Amis: a qinaljanaljan nua paiwan, natjuruvu a mazazangiljan, qau na patjatju izuazua a kadjunangan katua caucau niamadju, sika nama lingdjelj-nua kina qepuan a kemaizua.
English: The Paiwan tribes in each region have many chiefs, large and small, each owning their own territory and their own people, forming a social group.

Amis: a tja kakudan, nasa matja piida a paljingan, tjara izua mamazangiljan, sa azua na tjuruvu, tunapasu calivat tua malje taidai, a qinaljan izua a mamazangiljan ana djemadjas.
English: Traditionally, small chiefs have only two or three families, while large ones have hundreds of families.

English: Each tribe has a mechanism of governance to engage in common tribal activities and to regulate their personal lives.

Amis: sinan uri tja pasusuan sa nama san kakudanan anga, qau maqatinga malingdjelj a qinaljan.
English: Self-contained legal norms continue the existence of the tribe.

English: The tribe also has a high priest, a medium, an elder, a steward, a commander, and so on.

Amis: mavan cu a sinu pazangal tu caucau anga i qinaljan, mavan tiamadju a na kisan qeluz saka na suljivatj nua qinaljanan.

Amis: nuaya itjen aicua na malingdjelj tua kinakudanan, namatu kakudanan anga, a napatjezuazua ta qinapuluan.

English: An example of this is the "Great Turtle Kingdom", which is the name of this tribe.

Amis: mavan asika maqati tu tja sipadjaljian, na kipu kadjunangan sana pucaucau nakipu sikakudanan, qau samasengsenganen a seman pacugan,
English: It has the territory, the people, the legal system.

Amis: pasusuin a sikudanan nuaya, inika mapakim a tjuruvuan a mavekeljan, na maya anga tua kukka atja qinaljan.
aicua tja sinipatukulj a sengsengan a malingdjelj, mavan tu sinikatja kipaquliqulidan a ki kavecengel, satje kirangez a paseqeljing anga tua tja kadjunangan.
English: The other tribes, though small, likewise claimed to be self-supporting as a nation.

Amis: nua tima-imanga, qau sanama paravac a tja rasudjan i qinaljan.
English: Because of this political entity, the people are committed to the concepts of production and protection of the land, which creates a strong sense of solidarity.

Amis: timitja a paiwan, kemasi kakedriiyan anan, nagemaugau anga tua tjamatjaljaljak, a pazazekatj a temulu tua tja sivaljutan, katua tja caquanan,
English: From an early age, the people have to learn life skills and customs from their parents or elders by word of mouth,

English: rules, etiquette and reverence for heaven and earth.

Amis: a kakedrian a maqacuvucuvung, uri gemaugau a kisan uri masane caucau, a kitulu tu mavacuk, a kikavecengel, a semanturivecan, a kiqaluvuan,
English: As a teenager, he or she is required to undergo a rite of passage, learn to cultivate the land, and learn to handle hunting weapons and fight,

English: rituals and life skills, that is, attending a group life at the youth clubhouse, led and taught by tribal elders.

English: Our youth club is the Youth Life Club.

Amis: kemeljang itjen a kinamangezan nua qinaljan, nakemasi maqacuvucuvung na djaravac anga kitulutuluan, qau izua a nama kiqata a ramaljemaljeng,
English: Tribal adolescent boys and girls are required to participate at home, which gives an idea of the social structure of the tribes.

Amis: a pina parangezan tua qinaljan, sini ka penenetj a seman pacugan, namapadjadjas a liningdjeljan, sika na mairangezan nua qinaljan.
English: From the learning activities of the youth to the exercise of tribal authority, there is a complete system that serves as an essential element of the tribal political context that makes the tribe sound.

Amis: a se paiwan nu uri paseljenguaq tua qinaljan, na penenetj a pakaliyaw tua kakudanan i tua sikavaljutan, mavan anga namasan holicu.
English: The Paiwan have established many rules of life for the sake of social stability of their tribe.

Amis: sa kamamamamavan anga a pasusui nua taqaljaqaljan, sa penenetj anan uta sipasuljeman tana pasaliw a caucau.

English: In the case of hunting, since ancient times, when the tribe moved to a new place of residence, the

Amis: a taqinaljanan sinikilaing tua kinacemkemkeljan, sa penenetjan tua qaqaljupan,
English: The tribes are organized into clans with their own hunting grounds according to the family system.

Amis: sa palemek a zemulju anan ta valjitjuq tu sitavung.

English: Hunting is an important part of the people's livelihood and is therefore highly valued.

Amis: pai a se paiwan nu masengseng tua qinaljupan a sacemel, semangas ta pazekatj a paseljavaljavak.
English: The principle of "sharing" is used in the handling of game by the people.

English: When the hunter returns home from hunting a mountain pig, he must shout from a high place on the outskirts of the tribe, "Oo...ee! Mountain pig! Oh..." to inform the tribe.

aicu a paseljavak tjalja nanguaqan tua tja kakudanan anga, tjaivavaw anan tua kinananguaq tua pinenetj a papasusuan nua hulicu.

English: Cattle are mostly kept in a pastoral manner, where they are left to graze in established areas of the land.

English: In the ancient times, the ethnic people regarded the raising of cattle as unlucky, so there was a custom of forbidding the consumption of beef.

Amis: na cuacuai a pasusu taicu a kakudan, a patje zinangan nua se hullanda a i taiwan.
English: It has been passed down for a long time, until the Dutch occupied Taiwan.

Amis: kasicuayan a i qinaljan neka nu dingki, pai a kemuda a penadjeng tua lami namasan pazangal aravac a sengsengan,

English: Cured meat is ideal for cooking in winter or on rainy days, and is delicious with boiled dried taro.

Amis: ita namasan pazangal a palisian, nu izua qaljaqalja i tjumaq, nu qemaljaqalja tua qaljaqalja i qinaljan tjalja sanguaqan tua kakanen anga aicu a valeng.
English: A dish used to entertain tribal guests during important celebrations or when there are important guests in the family.

Amis: a valeng namasan sikipucemcemel uta nua vavayavayan nu na pualjak.

Amis: aicu a valeng namasan pazangal aravac tua kakanen i pasanavalj tua se paiwan.
English: Cured meat is one of the good ingredients in the traditional cuisine of South Paiwan.

Amis: a kinatevtevljan a dremakiyan ita puvaljavaljaw nua se paiwan a caucau, matu papacucun tua sepi na marka kina a pitarinavan nua marka aljak,
English: Every traditional Paiwan wedding dance circle is a runway show of a mom's dream.

si pakeljakeljang uta tua qiniladjan, ta manguaqan, ta kakudakudan nua kinaqinaljanan,

English: The Paiwan people also emphasize the integrity of their clothing, with head-to-toe attire having its own meaning and function.

English: The main traditional accessory is the glazed bead necklace: a short necklace and a long necklace, each with a colorful glaze pattern.

izua uta cacavu a sicavucavu tua kula, sinicavu tua kula a kemasi tjaiteku tua cungal a kaliljaw.

Amis: a vecik i lima nua vavayavayan sipakeljang tua ligu na manguaqan tua kinavavayanan a patarevan.

Amis: izua uta tarar, masan lialiaw a tarar, izua inalang ta qata, ta kaljipa, ta qaljic na likuljaw, ta aljis na vavui
English: Headdresses: Paiwan headdresses are the most diverse, ranging from glazed beads, shellfish, leopard skins and animal teeth.

Amis: palalj nua qadris, izua uta a , ging, gingpiya, sinikilaing tua qiniladjan nua inacemkeljan a kialalang.
English: and bear-eagle feathers, and even brass, silver, and coins, according to the status of the family.

Amis: izua uta nu babuay nua cemel, vangalj nua kasiw a sinan tarar.
English: It is also common to see headdresses with wreaths of flowers and fruits.

Amis: izua uta a vacvac, a sicuayan a vacvac inalang a sema kakedrikedriyan a qata, kaljipa kata ging, sipakelakelai a pitu calinga,
English: Earrings: Traditional earrings are made of small glazed beads, shells or silver jewelry strung around the ears.

Amis: min a maqacuvucuvung a vavayavayan nu maqati a kialalang tua vacvac, sinipakeljang uta tu tjeges anan a vavayan siniaya a patarevan.
English: It is a unique and exclusive item for unmarried women and a symbol of a woman's chastity.

Amis: izua uta a tjaljaiku, namasan pazangal uta aicu a tjaljaiku tua sikialalang nua vavayavayan,
English: Draped Back Ornament: One of the most important accessories of the traditional costume, the draped back ornament, is a strip of jewelry that hangs down from the back of the headdress.

Amis: sinitedek a pitjailikuz tua tarar a maru quvalj anga, a pakeliljinga, ging kata babulabulayan a qata sinan pakiyalalang.

Amis: a kialalang nua maqacuvucuvung a vavayavayan masan lialiaw aravac, saka martimaljimalji a pinaka tua siravarava a kakudan, napenadjalim sa na temalidu aravac.
English: Paiwan girls are richly adorned, and each decoration has its own function and meaning, making them beautiful and interesting.

Amis: a tja kinaizuanan a sepaiwan, kemasi vavulung na peniliq tua i gadugadu ta i calisilisi a naseljenguaq a namakaljuvung a kadjunangan.
English: Since ancient times, the Paiwan people have chosen to live on gently sloping or small flat areas in the hinterland of large mountains.

Amis: izua pacalivat tua malje tapuluq a paljingan a pasa tua taidai a paljingan maqepuqepu a masan taqinaljanan, inika pinenetja tu pidapida a paljing a taqinaljan.
English: There is no limit to the number of households belonging to a tribe, ranging from a dozen to several hundred.

Amis: a palingulj tua kinaizuanan a qinaljan, temalem tua kavayan a qau kata nauvelem a marka kasiw turi sikiljakevan tua vali tua qalja,
English: The planting of bamboos in the outskirts of tribal settlements or in the territory of settlements as a dense wood or boundary, and as a defense against enemies and wind.

Amis: maqati uta sisan tapaw sisan nanemanemanga tua turivecan i tjumaq.
English: It is also used as a material for building houses and as a tool for making household utensils.

Amis: izua uta a kinacemkeljan a kisumadju a mupu tua qaciljai tuki dremipa tua qau a palingulj tua umaq, tu sika sarenguaqan nua umaq niamadju.
English: Some families build their own stone walls or place bamboo fences around their homes for home security.

Amis: izua a sini upu tua qaciljai, izua a sinidripa tu kasiw ta qau a pi palingulj. qau uri nasuljivatj anga itjen a tjaljuzua.
English: There is a transfer station at the entrance to the Tribe's

Amis: a si sa qinaljan a djalan a itadjadjaljunan tua qinaljan, izua a cacavalj a pinu qaqiladjan tu qaciljai,
English: There is a square with stone chairs for sitting.

Amis: tu qiladjan nua cemalivalivat a caucau, saka nu izua tja palisian i qinaljan, izua nu tjaljumaza uta a palisi.
English: Various tribal rituals are sometimes held here.

Amis: a i sipangtjengtjez i qinaljan, pinu sasekezan a pi tua liljing nua kasiw, maqati itjen a tjaljumaza a semekez, tjemaula anan itjen tua tja kinacu,
English: There are also roadside rest houses at the exits of the tribes, most of which are located in densely shaded areas with trees.

Amis: satje kipavalivali izua tua na kemasi draruk a vali, tjalja sarenguaqan.
English: Pedestrians can take a break from their heavy burdens here and enjoy the wild winds blowing from the mountains.

Amis: nu peniliq tua uri kaizuanan, a sinan tjalja pazangalan, saka izua namasan paravac a kakipapaulingaw,
English: The selection of a new home is very important, so the clan pays special attention to it.

Amis: a kakudan tua uri pukaizuanan mavan a na izua a qumain katua qaljupan, sa naka pazangal a sazuain nua qalja, izua a veljeluan sa i kamakuljikulji a zaljum,
English: The basic elements of a traditional settlement are that it is suitable for farming and hunting, that it is suitable for defense against incoming enemies, and that the streams never run dry,

Amis: na mapateljar tua qadaw, neka nu ljayar a saqetjuan, inika sinan palisian, neka nupaljiq uta, namasukungan sana puqimang azua kadjunangan.
English: It is a place where typhoons are not allowed, where there is plenty of sunshine, where it is not easy to get sick, where it is clean and beautiful, where it is not forbidden, and where there is no evil or evil spirits, but a place of good fortune.

Amis: namaya tuazua a tja qemuti, nu izuanga kinipakiman a peniliq. pai siqaqivu tua pulingaw a semazua a palisi,
English: Once a new location is identified, a tribal psychic is called in to perform the spell.

Amis: ciljiken a temailj a paljiq katu ljayar, sa kiqaung tua qadaw a naqemati tu papucingki azua kadjunangan.
English: After that, they began to collect building materials to purify themselves and to pray for purity.

Amis: kemasi tuazu anga, maqatianga seman tapaw saka saneqinaljan a patje qemacuvung.
English: The building of houses and the establishment of tribes will be carried out until it is completed.

Amis: qau nu karakuda tua sengsengan a seman tapaw a sikataqaljan namare pusalasaladj, neka nuljemaini ta i qinalja;
English: As for the construction of the house, all the clansmen assisted each other with a passionate moral ambition, and no one refused to take part in it.

Amis: neka nuisupusupu tua kinaqadavan, neka nu nakisumalji, sika rasurasudj a patje maqacuvung a seman kaizuanan. a sinika qemacuvung mavan a rasudjan.
English: No one refuses to participate. And no one is counting the pay. No one is excepted, they are all volunteering their time.

Amis: namaita a sikataqaljan, sa izua a rasurasudjan a mare pusalasaladj a qemacuvung tua seman tapaw kata lemingdjelj tua qinaljan masa picul tua mamaw a varung nua taqaljaqaljan.
English: The successful construction of private houses and the establishment of tribes is the result of "joint efforts".

Amis: a sicuayan timitja a senavalj a paiwan, nuri pasakemuda itjen tua nemanga, pasusu itjen sakamaya tua tja kakudanan.
English: In the past, we, the Southern Paiwan, had certain traditions in performing any of the rituals of life.

Amis: tja pitua papuvaljaw, na seminamalji na semanpazangal, aicu a muri namakisenai a pinuvaljavan,
English: Traditional weddings are especially unique and solemn.

Amis: masudju maljavar anan a pitjaisangas, mana maqati a pacuru tua pitjaivililj a sudjuan.
English: A good and happy wedding, it is necessary to complete this hurdle before the grand and joyful wedding ceremony can be carried out.

qau mavan a mapasaladjan a na papungadan tu ti taligu aya. qau azua kalaingan i qumaqan, mavan a ti puljaljuyan a sumumus,

English: The Paiwan family is based on the system of primogeniture, that is, the first child born to a married couple after the establishment of a family.

Amis: a uqaljai a vavayan, avan a pazurung ta kinacemkeljan a pacugan.
English: Whether male or female, it is the concept of succession to the family.

English: The Paiwan attach great importance to the eldest heir, who inherits the family property from his father or mother.

English: It's amazing how detailed it is.

English: The tribe was formed after the clansmen agreed to imitate the way of life of bees and learn to live together. As a result, people of the same family lineage were gathered to live together in the same place, and the number of households gradually increased from a few to many, forming the tribe.

Amis: qau masi tuazuanga mavan a timadju anga a uri cemiur tua sikataqaljaqaljan.
English: Therefore, all Paiwan tribes, regardless of the number of households, were ruled by a chief, who governed the tribe and became the leader of the tribal society.

English: The clan calls this leader, citing the queen bee's name as "mamazangiljan" or "mazazangiljan".

English: The chieftain is the head of the family and the head of the tribe, and the laws of inheritance are exactly the same as in the commoner's family.

English: There are both male and female chiefs in this tribe, which can be said to be a social system of equal rights for men and women. The tribal society can form an institutionalized consensus, and the chiefs have the power to rule and the obligation to protect the people and the land, resulting in the tribe's strong mutual solidarity and unity, which is attributed to the "zangilj".

Amis: tiamen a sepaiwan, tiamen a sepaiwan nu si pualjak a lumamad,sa numasupudek anga,numasupudek anga, uri papungadanen.
English: We Paiwanese, when a baby is born a few days ago.

Amis: nu aya itjen, azua kinacemekeljan niamadju, na kemasi vavulung a kini ngadan antua vuvu a sevalitan.

English: From what happened to the person who was born.

English: For example, a pregnant woman who gives birth to a baby boy during a thunderstorm is named celalaq (thunder);

Amis: izua uta ana pualjak tu uqaljai, sa secevung tua luny, qau papungdanan tu ti “luny”;
English: For example, if a pregnant woman gave birth during an earthquake, the baby boy was named luny (震);

English: And when a pregnant woman who was hiding from an enemy attack suddenly gave birth to a baby girl in the mountains, she was named sinalilj (hidden).

Amis: namayatucu a tja si papungadaaan tua tjaljaljaljaljak, na kemasi tua sineljavakan a kadjunangan tuazua, qau na tjaljuqaca saka liyaw aravac a tja piliqen tu kingadanen,
English: The range of such names, taken from natural phenomena and states of life, is wide and varied.

English: Therefore, there is no need to worry about not having a name for the children of the family from the eldest heir on down.
