English: Therefore, there is no need to worry about not having a name for the children of the family from the eldest heir on down.

Amis: azua namasan kalaingan, nua uqalja nua vavayan, uri na semumus tua ngdan nua vuvu, saka uri ki cusuanan tua ngadan nua tjumaq; qau uri temavelak tua sauzayan niyamadju.
English: In addition to inheriting the names of their ancestors, the eldest heir, male or female, also has the right to inherit the family name and the family property, and therefore the family name of the family lineage has a long history from one generation to the next, and is passed down from generation to generation in the same way as a person's name.

Amis: nutjaivililj, namaya uta nanguaq a sipadjalji tu maru qadaw anga, a vayi vayik neka nu papautezan, sa inika uri maqulip sini aya.
English: The unending movement of the sun symbolizes the continuity of the family name and the immortality of the nation.

Amis: titjen a inavalj a se paiwan, a tja kinaizuanan dungdung tua i vuljavuljaw, tusia mamamau a tja kadjunangan,
English: The geographical location of our Southern Paiwan tribe is relatively close to the Hengchun Peninsula, so the climate is almost the same.

Amis: nuri semantapaw na seman pazangal tua uri sisan tapaw a nemanga, muri temezeng tua vali, tua qudjalj sanasalapelj a iqumaqan.
English: The choice of materials for the construction of the house is more important; sun, rain and wind resistance are necessary conditions.

Amis: tasicuayan a tja tapaw tjaiteku ta djalan, sa inupuan tua qaciljai a penulingetj, tu siqeceqceng tua vali,
English: In the past, the bases of the houses were lower than the road surface, and stone walls were built around them to protect them from being tilted down by the wind.

Amis: sa ini a sevali, ini angfa a maipuq a tapaw, siqeceng tua namaruqu a qaciljai atua zaljum. timitja a senavalj a si san tapaw a zailiu na masan liyau araric.
English: It also prevents mud and sand from crumbling and rainwater from seeping in.

Amis: izua qaciljai; izua kasiu; ravuc; ljavia; qau ata qipu,
English: Building materials range from stone slabs. Timber, thatch, bamboo, earth blocks.

Amis: nu ikasiu peniliq tua tjalja caljeqilan a kasivan, tjalja tjenglayan tua tjeves; cuqu, tu sisan qeluz ata sialangan.
English: Usually, hard wood such as beech and ibis are chosen for the beams and ceilings of a house.

Amis: ana senavalj a tapau, ladruadruq ljakua melava. a qaljiu sa cakevan tua ravuc. izuauta ljavia. nu tja pacunan a sisantapavan maru uqulj na tjukaw.
English: "The shape of the house is rectangular with a deep and wide roof covered with thatch, and the roof is in the shape of a tortoise shell.

Amis: tusika pinungadanan tu 龜甲 aya. sinan pakisumalji aravac a tja sisantapavan tua tjuzuma.
English: Therefore, the form of the Southern Paiwan's house is called the "Turtle-necked House", which has also formed its uniqueness.

Amis: ljakua a se sinvaudjan atua sekuskus namalji auta, a tapau, izua namatjaladruq izua a parutjaljetjaljev.
English: However, the southernmost Mudan and Gosvor tribes also have square shaped houses in addition to rectangular shapes.

Amis: namasili a qaliju i spasaqayau atua ipasalikus, maretimalji ata na setjakuvukuvulj.
English: The roof is pitched on two sides, unlike the Kamehameha roof, which is pitched on four sides.

Amis: aicu a i qumaqan izua kakudanan tu tinideqan. atjaljaqayavan mavan a sinan tiyani.
English: The South Paiwan house is divided into a front room and a back room, separated by a paneled wall, with long, thin benches on either side of the front room for beds.

Amis: pinatideqan tua valji a sangel a ladruadruq, tu sisan qaqerenganan nua nakivala a qaliyaliyan a kasusu. qaw a tjailikuz qaqerengan nua putapau.
English: The front room is a bed for overnight stays for friends and relatives, while the back room is for the master's bed and also houses furniture and the kitchen.

Amis: pinizuanan tua tansu; itakingan auta a kakesan. a ivecekadan tua qumaqan mavan a luvang, atjalja likulikuzan salang anga.
English: In the center of the back room is the inner chamber; next is the barn.

Amis: nu tja susuin a kakudanan a masicuai, pini qumaqan a tja kakesan. lja’a masi patagilj anga itjen a temalem tua padai, tja pasacasaven anga a tja kakesan.
English: The earliest kitchens were located in the houses, but as the rice culture entered the tribes, the tribesmen began to consume rice as well.

Amis: aya tua aicu a padai ini a kanimitjen a lami, natjuzuma. inia maqati a pasaqumaqanen. sinanpalisi aya ramaljemaljeng, tusia pasacasaven anga a kakesan.
English: However, rice is a foreign food culture to the Paiwan, in order to learn our inherent traditional culture, if cooking rice inside the house is a taboo, in order not to violate the traditional culture, so later began to set up a kitchen outside the house.

Amis: timitja a se paiwan, pitua seman tapau nuaya, namasan liaw aravac a tja kakudanan atua palisian. masi kemim tua tja qinaljan tua tja kaizuanan.
English: We, the Southern Paiwan, have many rules and taboos when it comes to building our homes;

Amis: patje semantapau, liau aravac a kakudanan sikiqaungan tua cemas.
English: No matter the choice of land or construction, there must be a ritual to seek God's approval before proceeding.

Amis: qusiyaya anga tucu, neka anga sicuacuayan a tapau, lja’ua izua za masanitalj a kakudanan tu maqati a tja ivauvauljan,
English: Although the traditional form of the house is no longer seen.

Amis: aya tua sicuayan nuri semantapau itjen tjemaljava aya, uri mangtjez aicu a taqaljaqaljan a pusaladj, sa nu maqacuvung pakanan; patekelan. aya tu si isaluwan tua aicu a tjinaljava.
English: However, it is worth mentioning that in the past, there was an interesting culture of inviting neighbors to help in the construction of houses.

Amis: malji anga tucu a zidai,pazeliuliuljan anga a iniqadavan nua caucau, paruzepuz a pakan a pumasalu.
English: This culture has the meaning of mutual assistance and help, which is very different from that of paying wages to workers nowadays.

Amis: tusia nanguanq a tja paqenetjau a nanguanguaq a kakudan a sicuayan anama kakiljivaljivak; maqaqeljiqeljing aya tja varung; sana mapatudur aicu a semicuaiyan a kakudanan.
English: Therefore, the culture of harmony and mutual assistance among tribes is the most important thing for us to learn and to pass on.

Amis: izua a sinan tjaucikel a milimilingan i qinaljan, tutazua a simamiling, izua tjaljavavavan tu gadu anga, na reminkutj sanagemagalj aravac, mavan a i kavulungan a siaya.
English: Our tribe says that in ancient times, there was a high and steep mountain called Dawu Mountain.

Amis: tuazua na minqut a qecilu nua qadaw a drusa, saka vuteqiteqilj a ita, na qudjeredjerelj a ita, manu venuak ta caucau a uqaljai katua vavayan,
English: Then there appeared on the top of the mountain two eggs of the sun, red and white, and two men and women hatched out.

Amis: qau azua uqaljai ti drumetj aya ngadan; azua vavayan ti qeleng ayain. qau, vililj ameqacanga tu masan caucau, saka marepuvaljaw amasan tacekeljan, saka pualjak tu natjuruvu.
English: The man is called Drumetj and the woman is called Qeleng. When they grew up, Drumetj married Qeleng and had many children.

Amis: ljaua namasane paljiq amara aljak, inika marukuz tu masane caucau, izua madrusa sakamaya a uqaljai a nameqaca. qau papungadanan tu ti puljaljuyan a tjavulung; ti valang a tjaljaljak,
English: The older brother is named "Puljaljuyan" and the younger brother is named "Valang". All of them have been carefully nurtured and grown up.

Amis: saka sini kiljivak aravac a papeqaca mavan anga aicu a pinatagiljan nua tja vuvu a sevalitan.
English: This is the legend of the common origin of the ancestors of the Paiwan people who are now living in different places.

Amis: azua ti puljaljuyan, na kilalj i kavulungan a kemaizuan. qau azua ti valang, na kemacu tua vatu, sana vaivaik a karim tua nanguaq a kadjunangan tu uri kaizuanan,
English: "Puljaljuyan stayed at Mt. Dawu, while valang took the spirit dog and went out to look for other Medici places to live.

Amis: nakiljaqui tua gadu, sa pacacikel i cemecemel, vaivaik sa qaljuqalju; kemaizuan sa patjavatjavat.
English: He crossed the mountains and circled around the wilderness, searching for land and hunting.

Amis: azua ti valang, nu djaravac ikadjunangan, izua vatu nimadju a kinacu, qau tjaljutumalji nu kadjungngan sasekez,
English: Having lived in one place and moved away to seek another, he traveled eastward with his dog, and rested at the foot of the mountain.

Amis: manu qemazau azua vatu izua, sa ini anga kaui a migacalj a garavagav, sinika samalji ni valang, tukimakuda.
English: But when it was time to leave, I didn't realize that the dog was going to lie down where it was and didn't want to get up and walk, so "valang" wondered why.

Amis: qau sakinemnem anga ti valang tu, masa uri nanguq a tja kaizuanan aimaza uaya pivarung. qau sa patagilj anga qemizing izua, sa seman qinaljan anga. sa azua kadjunangan i qeceling aya.
English: The "valang" thought that the spirit dog might suggest that this place could be a beautiful place to live, so they opened up this place for the tribe to live together, and the place was called "qeceling".

Amis: sa napuvaljau tjai muakai izua. qau sana kemirimu a vaik a cemikel a semakavulungan a pasemalaw tua kaka ti puljaljuyan tua sinan qinaljanan.
English: At the same time, he took a mua kai as his wife from the tribe, and then quickly returned to Mt.

Amis: tu nanguaq kikemuda? manu sinikaleva aravac nua kaka.
English: He informed his brother 'puljaljuyan' in detail about the opening up of the tribe and sought his brother's consent.

Amis: qau sasikacu tua tjaljayan nua vaqu, katua vurasi, saka satjezi a kipalaying ti valang, a sema qeceling itua sinaneqinaljan ni valang, namirazek aravac.
English: So he followed "valang" to the new tribe and gave his brother crops, millet, and groundnuts to cultivate, so that "valang" prospered and succeeded in the tribe opened by "qeceling";

Amis: na pualjak sana puvuvu anga, qau a vililj anga, na metjuruvu anga caucau, inika uri setjezua a kaizuanan katua qaljupan,
English: However, it was not until later that the same tribal branch was established at "qanapitj" as the population increased and there was not enough land for cultivation and hunting, so they moved to the south.

Amis: qau qemizing a sema navalj, itja qaljapitj saka ljemavekan a tjemavat, a tjalju vuljavuljau.
English: The same situation was repeated in the later generations, which gradually moved southward to live on the Hengchun Peninsula for thousands of generations.

Amis: tazua tjara na pasu calivat anga cavilj a tu maljekuzulj anga sevalitan, sa azua ti puljaljuyan i kavulungan, nametjuruvu anga caucau uta,
English: The Puljaljuyan, the old settlement in Dawusan, has also moved due to the increase in population.

Amis: sana qemizimizing a sema navalj gemaduan asemaqaraba azuma caucau, na kemaledep anan saka ljemavekan a patjavat,
English: Gradually, the mountain line to the south and the coastline to the south shifted.

Amis: sa na patjatju lingedjengdjelj tua qinaljan, katua mazazangiljan. qau samecevucevung tua mara kasusu i vuljavuljau, nu madjaljun anga pulima cavilj ta maljeveq,
English: Each tribe has its own head. Every five years, during the maljeveq ceremonies, they can contact each other and also share the ceremonies with their ancestors.

Amis: uri makaya a matjatjaucikecikel tua kasusu, ayatu tadjalan a kinivuvuan. masa mavan cu a vineqacan katua qinizingan a kemaizua aya tjaucikel.
English: This is an approximation of the migration of our ancestors. Our Paiwan descendants.

Amis: timitja ana tjaivilivili mara vuvu anga, na selangda a pitaladj tua tjavarung tua, tjasinane paravacan a seman pazangal tua i kavulungan a tja gadu.
English: The saying "Dawu Mountain is the sacred mountain of our people" has been passed down to this day.

Amis: inika uri madraudrau. azua maljeveq i qinaljan, mavana a papukining tua tja vuvu a sevalitan, tja qaqivuin a papangetjez satja paseljavaki tua tja palisian;
English: The tribe's five-year festival is to remember the ancestors and to call upon the spirits of the ancestors of all generations to be invited to participate in the rituals.

Amis: satja sizetjak tua qavai tua vava; qau satja kiqaungi tu samuljayar semu paljiq, sasi paljavak itjen tu na suljivatj tuna mirazek; sana manguaq a kinitjukudan.
English: It is a place to receive the delicacies and pray for the purification and expulsion of evil spirits, and to give peace and happiness to the people living there.

Amis: a sicuayan a qinaljan nua se paiwan, namasan pazangal aravac a qiniladjan nua pulingaw,
English: In traditional Paiwan society, mediums are an important asset of tribal culture.

Amis: a pulingaw maqati a padjadjaljudjaljun a tjalju vecekadan tua caucau kata naqemati a cemas kata i selem a marka tja vuvu.
English: Mediums are considered to be psychic beings who are able to connect the Creator in heaven with the ancestral spirits of those who have passed away and the psychic beings in this world.

Amis: a sika na masan pazangal aravac nua marka pulingaw i qinaljan, ayatua a pulingaw paljavak tua kini kacauanan nua macidicidilj a caucau; kemasi tua sipualjak a caucau, a saqetjuan, semu kuya semu paljiq,
English: The role of mediums in the traditional Paiwan society is very important, as mediums participate in the life rituals of each person's life, from the birth of a baby, to the elimination of human diseases, to the elimination of disasters and evils,

Amis: kisenai tua kini kacauanan kata remukuz a pasa selem, neka nu inika kinicapilj a pusaladjan nua marka pulingaw tua kini kacauanan nua timaimanga a caucau.
English: Every aspect of a person's life requires the intervention and assistance of a psychic, from illness, elimination of disasters and evils, to praying for blessings and returning to one's final resting place.

Amis: pai avan a sika namasan pazangal aravac tua sengsengan a peniliq kata temulu tua seman pulingaw;
English: Therefore, the selection and cultivation of mediums is also one of the important tasks in the tribe;

Amis: a patagilj nua peniliq tua pulingaw kemasi tua kinacemkeljan nua kapulingavan a marka vuvu anga a pacun,
English: Apart from the fact that psychic mediums are inherited from women in different generations of the family who have special physical qualities, they are also known as "psychic mediums".

Amis: tu izua a uri namakeljang tu sedjaljep a piliqen a seman pulingaw, izua nu pacun uta a piqinaljan tua uri sedjaljep a kisan pilingaw a vavayavayan a maqacuvucuvung.
English: We will also focus on the girls in the tribe who are suitable for psychic mediumship and select them for cultivating psychic mediums.

Amis: pai azua pinenetj tua uri san pulingaven a vavayavayan, izua pinakisumaljiyan tua si tavakan tu kisan pulingaw,
English: A young girl who has been destined to be a psychic since she was a child has a special nurturing process.

Amis: inika maqati a pumaya a pacacikel i katjuruvuan i ta inika kinatavakan a kadjunangan; sipiliq uta tua kakanen, maru katjaukaizua a padai a kakesain i qinaljan,
English: If the person selected as a medium is not allowed to go in and out of public places or unfamiliar places at will; there are choices in the taking of food.

Amis: inika maqati a pakanan a uri masan pulingaw a caucau tua vinli a kemasi pairang a padai, inika pakanan tua namacai anga kakanen a sacemel.
English: For example, when white rice was first introduced to the tribes, those who were pre-selected as mediums were not allowed to eat white rice bought from the plains, nor were they allowed to eat unfresh mountain produce.

Amis: azua pakitulutuluin ta pulingaw a maqacuvucuvung a vavayan kidjadjaladjalan nu kipusengsengan a pulingaw, sa katavatavak tua nemanema na pulingaw,
English: When working with an Elderly Psychic, the pre-selected girl will be expected to learn and assist, and familiarize herself with the psychic's main instruments, the spirit box and spirit beads.

Amis: a maru kaniputj kata zaqu. ljakua nu vilivililjan anga nuri lemingdjelj a seman pulingaw, pakivadaq anan a sema zaqu tua naqemati acemas kata marka vuvu sakana masalu.
English: However, in order to be recognized as an official tribal spirit medium, the spirit bead in the medium's hand must still be used to ask the Creator God and the Ancestral Spirits for permission to become a spirit medium.

Amis: pai a pulingaw na kipapaulingaw saka namapukakudan aravac a sikudan, puvarung saka kedri aravac a kai, amin a kipusengsengan tua semu kuya tua caucau,
English: A psychic's personal life must be carefully organized, sharp and intelligent, but few words.

Amis: semu siselapai, pucemel, kipasemalaw, kivadaq… a sengsengan. pasekakezeng tua kakudan i qinaljan, sa lingedjelj tua namanguaq a nasuljivatjan a kinaqinaljanan.
English: The usual work is to solve problems, eliminate disasters, heal the sick, psychic, divination and so on, to stabilize the order of tribal life and establish a healthy and peaceful tribal life.

Amis: a tja palisian a paiwan, nakemasi vavulung ,uzai a pulima cavilj saka puita a maljeveq katua puita cavilj sa puita a masalut.
English: Our traditional Paiwan festivals include the Five Years' Festival, which is held every five years, and the Harvest Festival, which is held every year.

Amis: qau azua masalut nuaya itjen, mavan a pumaleva tua tja cemas.
English: The Feast of Harvest is a time to give thanks to our God.

Amis: nakiljivak tjanuitjen tu cinaviljan tua tja qinuman a talem a sini kavecengel. tu namasanzua a lami.
English: Conserving a good harvest of the various crops we grow throughout the year.

Amis: qau mavan a masuvaqu a tjalja seman pazangalan tua palisian.
English: In particular, the main offering is the millet harvest.

Amis: nu masalut itjen, azua ljemita tua paljingan, uri zematjak tua kinilami a vaqu. vasa, vurasi paktjau(vatjau), tu anemanemanga, pitua tjumaq nua mamazangiljan i casau.
English: When the Harvest Festival is held, each household arranges its own harvest of millet, taro, sweet potatoes, and peanuts one by one in the outer court of the headman.

Amis: qau kiqenetjan anan nua mamazangiljan a ljemeitaita, saka siqaqivu anga tua pulingaw a palisi a pumasalu.
English: The headman will count the receipts one by one and then the headman will invite the medium to perform the ritual of thanksgiving.

Amis: sana alapen nua mamazangiljan azua sinan calja (sadja) . sa sisekaulj tu kemsa, sa sipaseljavak tua sikataqaljan a keman.
English: The chiefs then invited the tribesmen to cook the offerings and share them with them, and celebrated the event with songs and dances all night long.

Amis: qau sa ziyaziyan sa senasenai a patjemaljiya. azua sini pakicalja a lami nua sikataqaljan. pizuain tua kubaw nua mamazangiljan a zemululj.
English: After that, the chief would move the tribesmen's contributions to the barn for storage.

Amis: qau nusecevung tua raljiz tua venali sa sikaljekuya na cavilj, alapen anga nua mamazangiljan azua zinululj sa qarutan a paseqeljing tua namapaula, maqatiyanan a sipaseqeljing tua naselapai i qinaljan uta.
English: When the tribe is in distress by natural disasters, the chiefs will use this as food to maintain the tribe's livelihood, or when the tribesmen face changes in their lives, the chiefs will often act to provide immediate relief to keep his people's lives free of worry.

Amis: a tja masalut a paiwan. maqati a tusi padjalji ta kuini nua pairaing.
English: The significance of the Paiwan Harvest Festival is comparable to the New Year's festivities of the Han Chinese community today.

Amis: azua sika na temaliduan, azua tja kaqepuan na penakaleva aravac, azua na semacadja i maljinuqinaljan, uri matjumaq a kipakiayan a masalut i qinaljan.
English: It is also a time when all the foreigners go back to their tribes to celebrate, and it is usually during this time that they see their friends and relatives whom they have not seen for a long time.

Amis: sika nu mecevucevung a marakasusu a mareqalialian. namasusinglitan anga, qau mavan usi kana marekatjenglanglaiyan sika sini marekiljivaljivak.
English: Knowing each other's condition in order to bond with each other.

Amis: nu sika drusa nu qadaw a pumasalut. uri patagilj anga pakivangavang i qinaljan. izua mapapavala a zemurung tua qeluz.
English: The Tribe organizes a variety of activities during the five or six day Harvest Festival.

Amis: izua madradrangel, izua venacaq tua vaqu. izua masi kasiw auta. azua tjalja na semaljingan i qingljan, mavan a dremakian a zemian. natjuruvu a nakitjiak.
English: Examples include: stick pushing, wrist kicking, and shoulder racing for millet or fuelwood;

Amis: kana maqacuvucuvung anga, ka ini anan a puvaljaw uri kiqaqepuan anga izua, azua zemian uri tjasikaleva tua cinaviljan a masalut.
English: In particular, the Big Dance, which is the most anticipated event of the entire tribe, is an important event that all unmarried children must attend.

Amis: saka uzai anan a tjalja penazanglan. mavan a sika mare kipacucunan(kipaljizaljizau) tua maqacuvucuvung, tui timazua na saljaljak.
English: The purpose of the dance was not only to celebrate but also to invite all the unmarried women to dance and to be appreciated by many of the tribesmen.

Amis: tui timazua na samiling a kini ravaan. zemiyaziyan sana senasenai. qau nakipalinguljan avavulungan a iqeneqenetj.
English: The most beautiful women and handsome men are chosen by the chiefs and the most respected elders.

Amis: tuazua izua mazazangiljan a maramapasaladjan a kisan peniliq tua tjalja na kisumalji tua bulayan sa pasevalji tua ljaljak. mavan anga tjalja bulaiyan tuazua cavilj.
English: Afterwards, the Elders will give the chosen beauty and handsome man a muppet on his back. This symbolizes the most beautiful "tribal beauty" of the year.

Amis: atja sikamasalutan a cavilj. pinenetj pitua masuvaqu. ayatua nu pasucalivat itjen tua masuvaqu. muri kaljauraman anga sa muri masan ljazekaran anga.
English: However, the reason why the Harvest Festival is held every year after the millet harvest is over is because of the upcoming drought. It is because of the coming drought.

Amis: uri pazangal sana cuacuai aitje amasulami. mavan usi pinupacuganan a cavilj tu sika sengsengan nua tjaqinaljan. nakuya ini tja pasusui.
English: The tradition of storing the harvested grains and cereals in barns for the long fall and winter seasons should be continued.

Amis: timitja a sepaiwan, kemasi vavulung, izuanga pinenetjan a cavilj tua sipalisian,
English: We Paiwan people have had regular festivals since ancient times.

Amis: pitua tja vuvu a sevalitan katua qadaw naqemati, ka tua cemas ikadjunangan, qau tja pakani patekeli sat ja kiqaungi, aya tja kakudanan,
English: It is customary to offer food and drink to the spirits of ancestors and the gods of heaven and earth, and to pray for blessings.

Amis: azua zematjak a pakan katua kiqaung, mamaw a tja si padjaljian tu palisi aya. a sinu nakuya sazuain a palisi uta.
English: Sacrifices and prayers are known as palisi, and there are many regular spiritual offerings on festivals called palisi-an

Amis: a tja si palisian, masan liaualiaw, qau a tjalja Sinan pazangal, mavana nu lima cavilj puita itjen a palisi tua maljeveq, aicu a maljeveq namasan musalj, azua tjaisangas maljeveq aya; a tjaivililj pusau aya.
English: The most important of these festivals is the quinquennial maljeveq, or "five-year festival," which is divided into a pre-maljeveq and a post-pusawu.

Amis: a maljeveq a tjaljapenazangalan mavan a palisi a kicacevunga tua tjavuvu a tja sevalitan; a pusau, nu tjumaq a cemikel atja cemas, uri palisi ana itjen tu kipusau sa.
English: "Maljeveq" is a festival to welcome the ancestral spirits to the community, and "pusawu" is a festival to send the spirits back.

Amis: nu maljeveq itjen, lemingdjelj itjen ta djuljat katua qapudrung tu si palisi a pakivadaq tua tja qimang kata tjasepi.
English: During the "maljeveq" festival, a "djuljat" cone with a bamboo spear is set up at the tribe's festival site for fortune-telling.

Amis: azu i gadugadu a ti tjagaraus, nu madjaljun tu lima cavilj, saka ljeteku i lauz, sa vaik a sema navalj a lemiuliu tua qinaljana,
English: The main significance of the five-year festival is for the spirits of the Patriarchs of the clan, who live on weekdays in the "tjagaraws" (North Dawu Mountains).

English: South Pai Wan in the ancient times.

English: In the past, when the tribesmen went to the mountains to work in the fields, they always had to walk for one to two hours, so on the way or at a resting place, they would casually pick a leaf and play a song to relieve their labor or to entertain themselves.

It shows the uniqueness of the family, the luck of life, the fame is actually a record, a kind of beauty, the uniqueness, the power, the prestige and the status, which is unparalleled by the commoners.

English: The mountains are full of human corpses. The stench. The hunters can't stand the stench.

Amis: pai iniatemzeng a qemuzimuzip tua vangculan izua, pai sa paka i vangcul ayain anga azua kadjunangan izua.
English: From then on, the name of the place was vangcul (meaning odor), which was translated into Chinese as Manchuria;

Amis: sa a se paiwan papungadan anga uta tua kadjunangan i vuljavuljau, aya ta napacun tu venuliljaljau a vali sana izua a sapui a medjedjek uta, sa papungadani tu ivuljavuljau.
English: The name of the Paiwan place in Hengchun is vuljavuljau because there are floating and fire in the place.

Amis: qau a izua kadjunangan tinevetevelj anga a seman ita, sa papungadan tu i paliljaliljau aya ta pinalinguljan nua ljavek mapacun a liljau nua luduludan, nekanu papautezan, qau sipapungadan anga tu i paliljaliljau.
English: The Hengchun Peninsula is named after the sea on three sides of the peninsula, where the waves are incessant, so it is known as Bo liljau. It is also known as paliljaliljau.

Amis: ljakua azua ljungkiyau a siaya a tjaisangas i ljungkiyau aya ngadan, a tagilj nua i ljungkiyau nase paiwan a kai a papungadan tua ljungkiau aya a kasiw,
English: The ancient name of Hengchun in Chinese is "琅嶠", in fact, it is the native language called ljungkiyau is based on the time when the silver acacia trees flourished all around the Shuangliao harbor.

Amis: sa liau aravac a ljungkiyau a nacemuvuq izua itua kadjunangan, pai papungadan anga tua ljungkiau aya a ngadan nua kadjunangan izua.
English: The clan called the tree ljungkiyau, thus naming the shooting lodge ljungkiyau, and the Chinese translation is "嶠"(漢譯) (the original name of Hengchun).

Amis: a izua kanakadjunangan anga, kanatjakinaizuan a penulingelingetj anga, a gadu, a pana, a qaqaljupan, a vinaikan a qinaljan, tjara patjatju izuazua a ngadan a penuljat.
English: In addition, there are place names in other places, such as mountains, rivers, cultivated land, hunting grounds, and old tribes, regardless of the size of the area where the people live.
Multiple places; multiple points; multiple parties
Place of residence; place of abode
To reach a certain standard; to arrive at
To be in a state of fear; to be afraid
To appoint; to trust; to rely upon
To command; to deliver; to commit
Being in the world; ways of doing things; attitudes towards people
To fight; to engage in war.
Newly founded, newly established; newly developed
To be seated; to be seated (borrowed as a position); to be in rank.
For the purpose of adornment; the manner of putting on a disguise.
To enjoy the coolness of the air; to enjoy the coolness of the air
To recount; to state; to confess; to follow
To atone for a sin; to top off a sin
To place in trust; to control; to put in the palm of one's hand
Heir; at the helm, in charge
With the efforts to obtain the
Separation of families, establishment of separate families
There is success; there is completion; there is molding
The original family; the family; the condition of the home
To meet; to encounter; to experience.
Mutual aid; inviting people to help
To be invited; to benefit; to be seated; to enjoy the
determined, decided, laid down; rule of law
Exemplary, exemplary, exemplary; sampling, imitating, modeling
Inclusion is unlucky, bad and unlucky.
Abundance of food, availability of food
It is the one who has wisdom; the one who has vision
It's lonely and sad; it's lost.
To think, to want; to intend; to expect, to hope
Consider it a pity, a shame.
To chant joyfully; to sing and dance with ease.

Amis: kitului anga, semaumaqan a sinsi, qivu a pancang a mayatucu, “gacalji! kicungali!”
English: It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

Amis: nu kitulutulu amen, tuluan amen ni sinsi tua supu na kinacalisiyanan.
English: In class, the teacher taught us the paiwan language of numbers.

Amis: kitjavililj amen a kitulu tjai sinsi, saka men a semenasenay anga tua senay nua semupu.
English: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

Amis: liyav anga ku kinacaqu a penaiwanan a kai.
English: I have learned many paiwan languages.

Amis: djemedje aken a sema gakku, djemedje aken a kitulu tua pinaiwanan, uri ku sipaladenga tjai kina.
English: I go to school every day, I learn the paiwan language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

Amis: ti Kuljelje a ngadan na ku kama.
ti Sauniyaw a ngadan na ku kina.
tapuluq anga a ku cavilj tucu.
izua za ku kaka a uqaljay a tjavulung, ti Kapi a ngadan, tapuluq anga saka ita a cavilj nimadju.
English: I have a brother, his name is Kapi, he is 11 years old.
We study in the same school.
Both my brother and I like to sing.

Amis: tjengelay aken a emave’av/ljemanguy, nu kaljapulavayan, vaik amen a emave’av/ljemanguy a tacekeljan.
English: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

Amis: tjengelay aken a kipuqali(kipudrava), maqati amen a maciyuciyur a semenay a emave’av(ljemanguy).
English: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.
There are five people in our family.
There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

Amis: izua ti kama/ama, ti kina/ina tiaken, katua ku kaka a tjavulung a uqaljay katua tjavulung a vavayan, namatevetevelj amen a tacekeljan.
English: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

Amis: qacaqaca ti kama, kisacu a ku kama.
English: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

Amis: riljariljay ti kina, kuisang a ku kina.
English: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

Amis: qivuyivu ti kama tua penaiyuanan i tjumaq tjanuamen.
English: My father speaks the paiwan language with us at home.

Amis: nu kaljapulavayan cemikel amen a sema qinaljan.
English: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

Amis: vaik aken katua mareka ku kaka a tjavavulungan a djemekep tua kiav.
English: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

Amis: tjengelay aken aravac tua mareka ku sikatacemekeljan.
English: I like our family very much.

Amis: vaik amen ati kina a kivangavang tucu a qadav.
English: I went out with my mother today.

Amis: namaljenguaq a kalevelevan nu muqadadav, inika ljemaljaqel inika zemulezul, sarenguaq ca vali.
English: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

Amis: kemakan amen ta minpau i cemecemel i azatjan, ipaqadav amen, semeljec aravac.
English: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.
In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

Amis: ku kivadaqan ti kina, akuazua mequdjilj cu a kalevelevan?
English: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

Amis: qivu ti kina, panema ta uri uzazanga a vali aya.
English: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

Amis: nu qazemezemetj neka zua kelebav i kalevelevan, tjevuta anga a vitjuqan.
English: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

Amis: tjumatjumaq amen i djalan, kisaljinga aken ta vitjuqan.
English: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

Amis: saljinga ken tua inika mangtjez a vali, pasa vaivaik anan aken a kivangavang aya ken.
English: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

Amis: i ljaqediqedi tua nia umaq a ku gakku, djemedje aken a djemavac a sema gakku, sa ’u djavac uta a tjumaq.
English: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

Amis: inika tjaljiqacaqaca a nia gakku, inika tjuruvu a mareka vencik, namakakeljakeljang amen a masantalj.
English: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

Amis: namatevetevelj amen i vava’asan, maciyuciyur amen a seman mali, sa’a matjatjauci’eci’el amen uta.
English: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

Amis: kisaseljang tjanuamen a nia sinsi a kivangavang uta, namaya tua tacemekeljan amen i gakku.
English: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

Amis: ljemita tu qadav a semuasuap amen, maljiyan tua namaparimasudj aravac a nia kakituluan.
English: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

Amis: izua vaik a semisic tua qezung, izua vaik a semuap ta zaqetja.
English: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

Amis: nia suapen anan a penalinguljan a nia gakku, mapangapangalj amen tua sengsengan, namapalimasudj a ljemita tu qadav a nia gakku.
English: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

Amis: navaik aken a sema qinaljan a kivala tjaivuvu tatiav.
English: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

Amis: cuacuay anga men a inika mecevucevung, sengelit anga aken tjaimadju.
English: We haven't seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

Amis: tapacunan aken ni vuvu, pakanan aken tua suika, patekelan aken tua utja.
English: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

Amis: qaljemaqem aravac a sinitalem ni vuvu a suika, sanguaq angata.
English: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

Amis: tjengelay aken a temekel tua utja ni vuvu uta, sanguaq aravac.
English: I also like grandpa's tea, it's tasted good too.

Amis: vecekadan nu qadav, kemesa amen kati vuvu tua nia cengelj.
English: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

Amis: nakemesa anga ti vuvu tua masanliyaliav a kinsa, izua ciqav, izua kuka, izua tjingkuy, izua kacikacing/dingding.
English: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

Amis: ta makakincengelj amen, vaik amen a sema puljacengan a ki ljaceng.
English: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

Amis: sikalap aken ni vuvu tua liav a vurati, a vasa katua niniku, kacu-u a tjumaq aya.
English: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

Amis: ku kipusauan tiamadju, sa kinamangtjez anan nu tjaivililj a kivala tjanumun ku ayain.
English: I said goodbye to them and said I'd see them next time.

Amis: tucu a qadav kacuin amen ni sinsi a sema tua zaziljavan tua qemuziquzip, kipacumali amen a veneli tua kipu i paljing.
English: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

Amis: ta tedep amen i puqemuziquzipan, qivu ti sinsi, “aicu a i qayav mareka qayaqayam, azua i vililj mareka qatjuvi, ziljavu a masantalj.”
English: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

Amis: marekutj aken ta qatjuvi, manasika inika navaik a pacun tua mareka qatjuvi.
English: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

Amis: pacun aken tua liav a qayaqayam, minlayalayap i vavav tua kasiv, izua za ljequ i taladje tua kasiv a nataqed uta.
English: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

Amis: izua za zu, unma katua likuljav i puqemuziquzipan, inika napavala pacun tuca mareka qemuziquzip, maleva aken angata tua ku pinacunan tucu a qadav.
English: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

Amis: napasasing aken a pakaliav, sa ku sipapacun tjai kama kati kina.
English: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

Amis: sa’a nu tjaivililj tjara kinakiciyur tjai kama kati kina a sema maza.
English: Next time I will come with my parents.

Amis: tucu a pulavay, vaik a ken katua ku kaka a tjavulung a vavayan a sema akav a kivala tjai kama i Druna.
English: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle.

Amis: maka kisiya amen a kemasi Taihuku a sema Akav.
English: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

Amis: djemaljum amen i Akav, na unting tua haiya ti kama i Druna a kicacevung tjanuamen.
English: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

Amis: inika cemadja a umaq ni kama i Druna tua tisaba, inika cuway i djalan djemaljun anga.
English: The station is not far from my uncle’s house, and it’s just a short drive away.

Amis: izua za i djemet tua umaq a tjaljiqacaqaca a quma ni kama i Druna, vaik amen a semazua a makapalidring.
English: There is a big ranch near my uncle’s house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

Amis: i tua quma, kacuin amen ni kama i Druna a pakan tua sizi katua gung.
English: In the ranch, my uncle Druna took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

Amis: ta masulem, kacuin amen a sema lizuk a keman tua kinsa.
English: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

Amis: liav aravac a pacacikecikel a sidusiya/haiya i kadjalanan, manasika maka utubai amen a sema zua.
English: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

Amis: ta uri vavaik anga men izua, manu cinekav anga nia utubay, saka nia maka basu anga sakamay.
English: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

Amis: nacemikel anga men a sema Taihuku tucu, inika ken a kemeljang tui djinumak anga a utubay ni kama i Druna.
English: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don’t know if my uncle’s motorcycle has been found.

Amis: i Akav a nia umaq ta kakedriyan anan aken, ta sema gakku anga ken, patjavat amen a sema Tauyun, saka izuazua angamen i lizuk a kikavaljut a patjetucu.
English: When we were young, our family lived in Donghe. After I started school, we moved to Taoyuan and have been living in the city ever since.

Amis: makalap anga aken tua taigakku, sa ku kitulu tuazuz masanitalj a patjara nu kacalisian a kakudakudan a tulu, avanazua kemeljang aken tua napenakaizuazua a tja kakudan a kacalisian i Taiwan.
English: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

Amis: manasika, tucu a cavilj a pulavay tua zulezulan, vaik aken katua ku kaka a tjavulung a uqaljay a sema qinaljan a kivadaq tua ramaljemaljeng, pasa kikeljang amen tua nitjen a kakudakudan.
English: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

Amis: aluangapuluq a cavilj ni vuvu, ljakua nu tja pacunan nasa’edriyan anan sakamaya.
English: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

Amis: ku kivadaqan timadju tu anemanema kinacaqu a kai, tauliq aravac a qivu tua penayuanan, macaqu a dremipungan, a dremekaiyan katua penairangan uta.
English: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in Saisiyat, as well as Atayal, Hakka and Japanese.

Amis: ta makakivadaq anga ken tjaimadju, djaljepan ta kakedrian anan timadju, na kitulu tua dremipungan, azua cekelj se drekai zuku, saka pizua tua sengsengan nimadju nasekeljang tua tjuruvu a pairang, manasika liav a kinacaqu a kai nimadju.
English: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Atayal, and he knows many Hakkas at work, so he can speak so many languages.

Amis: itua nia kinaqepuan, liav aravac a sitjaucikecikel tua patjara semicuacuayan a caquan nua qemaljup.
English: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

Amis: ljai inika men a sepualalang, ljakua nia linuing a paka tua dingwa, maqati a nia umaljen anan a kiladenga.
English: Although we could't fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

Amis: ta kakedrian anan aken, inika ken a nakemeljang tua tja kakudan a paiwan, nasemiaq tu kacalisian aken pai.
English: When I was young, I didn't understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

Amis: nu tjaliav a ku kinljangan, tja ljemaui tu Paiwan zuku aken, napakisumalji, sedjaljep tu ku sikipasukuda uta.
English: The more I know, the more I feel that being a Saisiyat is unique and something to be proud of.

Amis: tucu a masulesulem a qadav, uri tjumaq a ku kaka a tjaljaljak a uqaljay.
English: My younger brother is going home this evening.

Amis: vaik aken katua ku vuvu a sema siyubai a veneli ta kuka, padjulu ta sipakaiv tua ku kaka a tjaljaljak a uqaljay.
English: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

Amis: cemalivat amen itua paveliveli ta ljaceng, liav aravac a za namapakaizuazua a nasasanguaq a ljaceng.
English: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

Amis: naveneli amen tua kabula, qaqilj katua taicav.
English: We bought chinese cabbage, yams and carrots.

Amis: maitucu aza paveliveli ta kudamunu a tauki, “qaljemaqem aravac ca u pangudralj katua kutjis. pay veliyu tu kedri!”
English: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

Amis: saka nia veli anga ta pangudralj katua kutjis.
cemalivat amen tua puvutjuljan, qivu a tauki, “anema nu veliin? pacuni cu a u kuka kakudralan saka sasanguaq aravac, nu ita tjeluaiday a avelian.”
English: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

Amis: pazangal cu aya ti vuvu, saka kivadaq ta tauki tui maqati a papemadjuluin.
English: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

Amis: ljakua qivu a tauki, madjulu anga cu, inika maqati anga tja kiluvadan aya.
English: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

Amis: maitucu aza kiljaqediqedi a tauki a qivu, idu veliyu ta ku ciqav, kakudralan sa mamadjuluan.
English: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

Amis: ta vililjanga naveneli anga men ta kuka ta ciqaw, saka nia vaik anga a tjumaq a kemesa tua tahandayan a djamay.
English: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

Amis: cuai amen a kiljaljavaljav, masulem anga.
English: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

Amis: manu pakadinguwa a ku kaka a tjaljaljak a uqaljay, inika maqati anga a pulavai aya i pusivitayan, uri pinutjaivililj anga ku sisatjumaqan aya.
English: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

Amis: na kemesa anga itjen a pakaliav aya ti vuvu, pai tja kanavanga sakamaya a masantalj!
English: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

Amis: nia djauljen anga sakamaya a nia kaka katua nia qali, saka nia atevetevelj a kaiv.
English: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

Amis: izua za ku salasaladj a ti Uljelje, ru draudrav a kemacu tua nemanga nimadju.
English: I have a classmate named Uljelje, he often forgets to bring things.

Amis: nu kitulutulu amen, kisedjam timadju tua salasaladj ta inpic, siquliqulip katua vaveikan a laqulj/zakitju.
English: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

Amis: puita, pudrusa, putjelu, nia pasedjam sakamaya timadja.
English: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

Amis: ljakua, izua za nakuyakuya a sikudakudan nimadju, inika ru pacikel tua kinisedjam a nemanga.
English: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

Amis: ta vililjanga, nekanga nu salasaladj a pasapasedjam tjaimadju.
English: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

Amis: izua tu ita qadav, vaik amen a maciyuciyur a kivangavang.
English: One day, we all went on an outing together.

Amis: ta i djalan amen, manu malingav ti Uljelje, ljakua inika napaqenetj a kemacu tua siidjuadjuas.
English: On the way, Uljelje wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

Amis: saka patjanemain a salasaladj tua sikidjuadjuas, tevelain a mayatucu, inika men a nakemacu uta ayain.
English: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn’t bring them either.

Amis: qemaung anga ti Uljelje tua uwalan. madudu a qivu, awa inika mun a pasedjam tjanuaken tua sikidjuadjuas aya!
English: Uljelje burst into tears. He said angrily, why don’t everyone lend me toilet paper!

Amis: qaqivuin nua salasaladj a mayatucu, ayatua inika sun a nakemacu, saka nu tja pasedjaman sun ta nemanga, inika sun a pacikecikel uta!
English: The classmate told him, because you didn’t bring it yourself, and you wouldn’t return the things lent to you!

Amis: ta maljiya, namedjama anga ti Uljelje i gakku, saka pacikeli a kinisedjam a nemanga tua mareka salasaladj a penuljat.
English: The next day at school, Uljelje arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

Amis: pudjavadjavai tua mareka salasaladj ti Uljelje, saka qivu a mayatucu, kiken a kemacu anga tua ku nemanga nutjaivililj, saka pumaljimalji tua mareka salasaladj tua pinasedjaman tjaimadju a pasusangas anga a qadav.
English: Uljelje  apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.
My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

Amis: ta kakedriyan anan aken, nu qazemezemetj vaik a casav ti kama kati kama i Kapi, nakemacu tua tjakit katua kuang.
English: When I was little, my dad and uncle Kapi would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

Amis: nu maljia, nakemacu anga tua qinaljup a sacemal tiamadju.
English: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

Amis: nucuayanga vavui, nucuayanga lava, panema tua padjavatan uta.
English: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

Amis: pangapangaljen a sacemel i sipangetjez i qinaljan niamadju, sa’a qaluti a sikataqaljan.
English: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

Amis: ku culaqen ti kama, vaik aken a keciyur tjanusun a qemaljup ku ayain.
English: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

Amis: ulja sun a meqaca anan, ku kacuav anga ayain aken ni kama/ama.
English: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

Amis: pudringai a mareka uqaljaqaljay i qinaljan tua sacemel uta, macaqu tiamadj a semanaya tua seluc katua caqeljip/qezetj.
English: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

Amis: macaqu aravac ti ama a seman seluc, sidringadringay cu tua padjavatan aya ti ama, nia puqezeljan a djukap na sacemel, sa nia pudringai a pinakazuazuanan a djaladjalan.
English: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

Amis: aza saljinga ken a kiciyur ta ramaljeng a qemalju, djemedje aken a kicaquan tua seman dringay, manu inika cuacuay dremingai a paruarut a ku sinanaya a dringan tua sacemel.
English: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

Amis: pacun ti ama tua ku sipudringayan, qivu a mayatucu, maljiyan tua uri lemanav sun a cinunan aya.
English: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

Amis: tucu a meqaca anga ken, ku sevaljen a ku vetjeljatan katua panaq, sa’a vaik a kiciyur tjai ama a qemaljup.
English: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

Amis: cemikel amen a sema qinaljan, nia siqalut a nia inalap a sacemel tua nia sikataqaljan.
English: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

Amis: qivu ti ama, maleva itjen tua papuluqem nua tja vuvu, pinapusepiyan itjen tucu a qadav.
English: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

Amis: na sekavililj aken a sema gakku ta kadjaman.
English: I was late for school this morning.

Amis: inika na kemacu aken tua kabang, ta vaik aken a sema gakku.
English: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

Amis: neka nu ku kinacu a nanemaneman.
English: I didn’t bring anything with me.

Amis: nu kitulutulu amen, pacun amen a meseljang ta laqulj katua ku salasaladj.
English: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

Amis: nu siking amen, pasedjaman aken ta inpic katua siquliqulip na ku salasaladj.
English: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

Amis: qivu ti sinsi tjanuaken a mayatucu, “djamau anga paceged nu tjaivililj mayanga sekavililj!”
English: The teacher told me, “Wake up earlier next time and don’t be late again!”

Amis: ti Puljaljuyan a ku qali, aljak nua paiwan zuku auta timadju.
English: My good friend’s name is Puljaljuyan, and he is also an Paiwan child.

Amis: kitulutulu amen i Tjaljakavus a mamav.
English: We study together in the Tjaljakavus tribe.

Amis: ru vaik amen a kilangeda ta ramaljemaljeng a menilimilingan, macaqu amen aravac a penaiwanan.
English: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Paiwan proficiently.

Amis: qacaqaca sa kudrakudral aken, kedrikedri sa kuljakuljay ti Puljaljuyan.
English: I am tall and overweight, while Puljaljuyan is short and thin.

Amis: na rucikal aravac ti Puljaljuyan,kinatjengelayan timadju nua timaimanga.
English: Puljaljuyan is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

Amis: undukay tucu a qadav nua gakku,liyav a malalumalj a pinadjulu nua gakku.
English: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

Amis: izua maqaqesir, djemakadjak ta mali, mekelj, iyuki katua penanaq.
English: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

Amis: ta mekekelj a ken, sequlilj aken, pedjamuq tu qaca a ku cungal.
English: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

Amis: ljakua migacalj aken sa na mekelj sakamaya a patjaiqayav.
English: But I stood up and continued running forward.

Amis: maleva tjuruvu a caucau ta tjeljavang aken sa djaljun tua qaqacuvungan.
English: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

Amis: ini na sangasangasan ljakua namaleva ken aravac ayatua naqemacuvung aken tua malalumalj.
English: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

Amis: na vaik amen tatiav kati kama a paljilji tjai kama i Kapi.
English: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

Amis: nasekakuda a kula ni kama i kapi.
namaperunganga a qinaljivan aya timadju a pasemalav tjanuamen.
English: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

Amis: na matjani timadju a kemasi qaljiv ta seman nanguanguaq tua qaljiv.
English: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

Amis: na kemacu ti kama ta vutjulj na kung katua saviki tu sipavay tja kama i Kapi.
English: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

Amis: liav a siniqivu ni kama i Kapi a milimilingan ta maljavaljavar amen i qarengan.
English: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

Amis: nameqaca sa namesauqaljayanga sun aya ti kama i Kapi a semanzua tjanuaken ta uri vaik anga ken.
English: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

Amis: pangtjezuanga kivala a sema tjanuamen nu navenalanga su kula ku ayain ti kama i Kapi.
English: I said, “When your foot gets better, come to our house next time and visit us.”

Amis: ta 2022 a cavilj napakaigi a sihu ta maqatianga sepapuvecik a tja ngadan a kinacalisian a pitua tja mibunsiu.
English: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

Amis: nakisusu aken tua kisamuljamulja a kiqaunga tua sihu ta sepapuvecik a tja ngadan a kinacalisian a pitua tja mibunsiu a tja maqacuvucuvung i qinaljan a ti Puljaljuan.
English: I interviewed Puljaljuyan, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

Amis: na mare kicun anga men ta nu tucu a pulavalavay vaik amen a sema ta umaq nimadju a maljavaljavar
English: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

Amis: ta maljavaljavar amen pasemalavan aken ta kinasizuanan nua ngadan nimadju, sa na pakeljangi tua sikatacemekeljan nimadju katua qinaljan nimadju.
English: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

Amis: ku kivadaqan timadju tu anema sikipatjemacay ta pavalit tua ngadan,a inika nanguaq a kakudan a sikipuvecikan a pasusangas?
English: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

Amis: qivu timadju tjanuaken a mayatucu, “ayatua a tjiniukukuan inika maqati a mapasalusu a siqivuan tua ngadan nimadju, tjuruvu a caucau a ti Pu sinseng aya tjaimadju, sa napenepedjeli aravac.”
English: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Pu Xian Sheng

Amis: qivu ti Puljaljuyan, “a tja ngadan a vincikan tua tjavecik avanazua tja kangadanan,a ku ngadan sinipupatarevan ta ku qinaljan ku kinacemekeljan ta ku nasi,ulja napatja tjuruvu a caucau a pacikel tua tjaratja ngadangadan.”
English: Puljaljuyan said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

Amis: na vaik amen a semiyubay ta tiav a ti vuvu i vavayan,liav a kinacu ni vuvu a sinitalem nimadju a ljaceng,sa na seman kakanen ta nu kacalisian auta a sipavay ta timaimanga.
English: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

Amis: tjuruvu a tjengelay ta siyubay ni vuvu i vavayan, tjuruvu a veneli ta silji katua vurati, tjuruvu auta a qemayam tua sinandjamay nimadju.
English: Everyone loved my grandmother’s stall. Many people bought the chilis and sweet potato, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

Amis: maljiyan tu sanguaq a kinesa nimadju a lukuc katua djuadjuya a paday, izua nan a cinapan a vutjulj na vavuy, tjuruvu a namadjaulja ta saluman, sa nacumali, a timaimanga izua ta nia siubay.
English: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

Amis: ta kemesakesa ti vuvu i vavayan, izua ken a tjemautjautjav i ljaqediqedi a idu veliu ta nia sinitalem a tiamen a ljaceng, inika pinabusbusan ta cemel.
English: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, “The vegetables are self-grown, all-natural and organic! Come and buy now!”

Amis: veliyen a pakirimurimu a nia nemanga,qivu ti vuvu a mayatucu ayatua izua sun a napusaladj a paveli aya,
English: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, “It’s all thanks to your help.”

Amis: pakasimaza, kituluanga ken ta caquan na patjara tataleman katua kakanen na kacalisian, sa nakemeljang auta ta zelian na semiyubaubay.
English: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

Amis: maljiyan tu maleva tu mapumudingan a ken ta pacun aken tua tjenglayan ni vuvu i vavayan ta tja kakanen na sekacalisian.
English: Seeing my grandmother’s passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

Amis: aiyanga sun! na semengelit a paruarut.
English: Yeah, it's been a really long time since I've seen you.

Amis: aligu iyana nu pakakivaqu, ulja ken a pusaladj.
English: The millet is not yet harvested, I can come and help.

Amis: ki sun a pucug nu tiav?
nanguaq! neka nu ku saliman nu tiav.
English: I'm fine tomorrow! I'll be fine tomorrow.

Amis: nu maitazua kikena mangetjez anga nu maya.
English: In that case, I will definitely come.

Amis: madaqai a secevung aken tja nu sun, uri masu varung aken ta kusengelitan.
English: Luckily, I met you and made up for the thoughts of you.

Amis: ku drava cu, ti sakenge a ngadan.
English: This is my classmate, name is Sakenge.
My name is selep, please come in.

Amis: sipuita cu a sema qinaljan ni madju.
English: It's her first time at the tribe.
Where are you from? What family are you from?

Amis: se kuljaljau aken. lja rusiguan amen.
English: I'm from Gulou. We're a rusiguan family.

Amis: aica su kinamalangan nase pasaljuaya djaljepan marekakakaka itjen.
English: Your faces look alike. We're related.
It's good that we know each other.

Amis: masalusalut a tja sikataqaljan, ari vaiki a kiqepu.
English: Our tribe is having a harvest festival. Come along.

Amis: maculja aken, izua nanguaq a kanen?
English: I'm hungry. Do you have anything to eat?
There are bananas on the table.

Amis: inika venetu a veljevelj, keman aken ta kinsa.
English: I can't get enough bananas. I want to eat.

Amis: neka nu kinsa izua cinavu, ljakua galjuanan.
English: There was no rice, but there was cinavu, but there was a wait.

Amis: saliyalim aken tu kiqepu ta marekatjakaka.
nanguaq ca kaljasalutan tjumaq itjen a masantalj.
English: That's great! Everyone's back from the Harvest Festival.

Amis: ti sakenge aken, na makuda kinaqadavan i tjanumun?
English: I'm Sakenge. How's the weather over there?
It's a beautiful day. Where are you?
Sometimes it's nice when it rains.

Amis: ki uri kemuda a kinaqadavan nutiyav?
English: I wonder what the weather will be like tomorrow.

Amis: matu uri masizangal a venali aya.
English: It looks like there's a strong typhoon.

Amis: na pacun aken i ta tinse.
English: I see the TV knows it.
I hope the typhoon will not come.
So what are you doing tomorrow?

Amis: na paljilji anga sun tjai su vuvu?
English: Have you checked out your vuvu?

Amis: saka makaya sun a matja nu amen tucu?
English: Can you come to my house today?

Amis: makaya ljakua kipapamav a qadav aken. nu masukincengelj uri mirava aken taku nemanga.
English: Yes, but only for half a day. I want to organize things in the afternoon.

Amis: nu ngida anga isun a mangetjez nu tjai vililj?
English: When will you be back next?

Amis: kuivadaqai i zainu a umaq na mamazangiljan?
izua i pasa zayazaya ta qinaljan.
English: At the top of the tribe.
It won't be far. It's very close. It's all at once.
Can you show me the way?
Go buy the ingredients for the soup.

Amis: veliyu ta puk, ljamljam kata vutjulj.
English: Buy tree peas, ginger, and meat.

Amis: pavai aken numaya ta paisu vaik aken a veneli?
English: Then give me the money and I'll buy it.

Amis: tuki qacuvung i kemuda a kuzulj ?
tjara qacuvung sa kamaya, vaik aken nu maya.
English: It should be enough. Then I'll go.

Amis: aki qacuvung a su kinacu a paisu?
na seqacuvung, putjezanan tu drusa idai.

English: I'll take care of the rest.

Amis: kaka i tjivuluan izua uri mangtjez a pakaljavar nutiyav, pucug sun a kicapilj?
English: Tomorrow someone will come to my house to propose marriage, tjivuluan brother, can you attend?

Amis: djavai lja tja kaka, pinaparangezan aken tua papucekelj nutiyav i tjanaasia.
English: Sorry, I have to officiate at a wedding in Yilin Village tomorrow.

Amis: manumaya, namapuzangal amen tu icapilj sun.
English: That's a shame, would have loved for you to attend.

Amis: ulja mun a nasekanavalj sa namarasudj.
English: I hope you're all doing well.

Amis: ljakua, nu papucekelj i qadav ulja sun a mangetjez anga sakamaya.
English: But please come on your wedding day.

Amis: nanguaq sakamaya, tjaraken a mangetjez a kicapilj.
English: I'll be there against all odds.

Amis: nu mapenetj anga a qadav ku pasemalavay anga.
English: We will let you know when we have decided on a time.

Amis: maya dremaudrav. saka anema a ku pusaladjen?
English: Don't forget! What can I do to help?

Amis: nia qacuvungav anga saliman, kana mangetjez sun kipacengceng.
English: It's all right. Just come on.

Amis: macaqu sun aravac a penaiwanan? tima na temulu?
English: You speak the language well. Who taught you that?

Amis: inika na sekanavalj, ljakua rukiqaqivuan aken ta ku sikatacemekeljan i tjumaq.
English: I'm not fluent yet, but I try to talk to my family when I go home.

Amis: iya manu su sikatacemekeljan a temulutulu tja nusun kavalanga sun.
English: So you have a family that teaches you the language, how enviable.

Amis: ui, seman pazangal amen aravac a qivu ta tja kai.
English: Yes, speaking the language is very important in our family.

Amis: aparuarut? nanguaq a kisamulja aken a kitulu tja nusun.
English: Really? Then I should really learn from you.

Amis: nanguaq ljakua ini kaken a macaqu aravac.
English: It's okay! But I didn't say it very well.

Amis: tjaraken a kemasi ta tjalja madjuluan a patagilj.
English: I can start with the easiest.

Amis: izua kakituluan ta patjara kai a laqulj, tja si eseljangan a kitulu.
English: I have a book on learning ethnic languages, let's learn from each other.

Amis: nanguaq aravc a ku sinekeljangan tja nu sun tu ku salasalaj.
English: It's good that I have a friend like you.

Amis: ui! cuacuai angaken a na kisuzeliyan.
English: Yeah! I've been resting for a long time.

Amis: mangilu a remayu a ku kinacavacavan.
tja si pakinemenem kiljivakan numaya a su kinacavacavan.
English: It's important to keep an eye on your health.

Amis: kaciuri anga a kicapilj ta semantaqiljas tjay tjuvi nutiyav.
English: Come to tjuvi's great-grandchildren's birthday party tomorrow.

Amis: ui, tjaraken a vaik sakamaya a kiqepu.
English: I'll be there! I'll definitely go.

Amis: kimen a maciur anga kata ku vuvu.
English: I'm going with my vuvu too.

Amis: nanguaq, ku qali aravac ti tjuvi.
English: Okay, I'm very close friends with tjuvi.

Amis: ulja sun a kinisenayan na cemas sa su kanavenala!

English: Our family is full of children and grandchildren.

Amis: saka tima su kiniteveljan ta su kinacemekeljan?
English: So, who do you live with?
We live together as a family.

Amis: tjalju sikamasan pidalj a nu kinateveteveljan  tucu?
English: How many generations are currently living in your family?
There are five generations in our family.

Amis: izua ku matjaljaljak, marekaku aljak, ku vuvu, kata ku qaqidung.
English: There are parents, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.

Amis: saka mapida penuljat a supu na nu kinacemekeljan?
English: How many family members do you have?

Amis: matu na pavalit anga ti tjuku ta sengesengan.
English: I heard that tjuku recently changed jobs.

Amis: matu patjara rivadrek ta namapaula a kinacemekeljan a saliman.
English: It seems to be about caring for the disadvantaged families and related social service work.

Amis: kemuda sa pavalit timadju ta sengesengan?
English: Then why did he change jobs?

Amis: pasa pazurung a pakiyamav ta sikudakudaan ta rivadrekan ta i qinaljan.
English: Because he wants to take action to care for more tribes.

Amis: a tjengelay sun tusa vaquan a sengesengan, tjuku?
English: tjuku Do you like your new job?

Amis: na patjau sangas mun a tjemumalj?

English: How many of you are there?
This is the menu for your reference.

Amis: izua na kisumalji a djamai? pai, pasemalavu?
English: Do you have any special dishes you'd recommend?

Amis: izua quzang, sacemel, ciqav, anema nu katjengelayan?
English: There's shrimp, seafood, fish. What do you like?

Amis: na sasanguaq nu tjalangedain, pai kesau tu tjara masanitalj azuwa numaya.
English: Sounds delicious, so let's order one of each!

Amis: pasan djamai anan aken ta ljaceng a uta?
English: I'd like to fry some more vegetables?

Amis: izua lukuc, djaudjav kata mekui tucu.
English: Now there are sansho, groundnut leaves and bergamot.

Amis: na maka kisiyaken, uri unting  a kuvarung ljakua tjara liyav a zidusiya i djalan aya aken.
English: I took the train and wanted to drive, but I was worried about the traffic.

Amis: nu na maka utubai sun palemak atja nanguaq tjaika maqemeceng sun.
English: It would be better if you rode a motorcycle, so there would be no traffic jams.

Amis: inikaken a maka pualang ta djalan.
English: I am not familiar with the route.
How should I go to Pingtung?

Amis: maka kisiya aken? tja sarenguaq a kinai djalanan.
English: How about taking the train? The journey will be more comfortable.

Amis: cemadja ta ku sazuain a pukisiyaan?
English: Is the train station far from where I'm going?

Amis: na pavalanga sun a maka basu?
English: Have you ever ridden a bus?

Amis: iniyanake paqayam, palemak a nanguaq a paqayam aken ta maka basu.
English: I've never ridden a bus before. I'll give it a try.

Amis: nanguaq, ulja sun a na suljivatj ta su kinai djalanan.
selangedaken tu cuacuay anga a saqetjuqetju a su cekelj?
English: I hear your wife's been sick for a long time?

Amis: ta qiljas anga, ljakua paremak nu mivenalaan.
English: It's been a month, but she gets better and worse.

Amis: ru ka saqetju a qulu, samutjaq, ata tjiyalj.
English: She has frequent headaches, vomiting and stomach pains.

Amis: sini vaik anga a sema biyuing a kipa kingsa?
English: Did you go to the hospital for a checkup?

Amis: uri makapidalj a siuljai i biyuing?
English: How long will I need to be hospitalized?

Amis: saka tima uri zemang ta kakedrian?
English: So, who's going to take care of the kids?
It's just me, no one else.

Amis: ti idis aken, izua ti tjuvi?
English: I am idis, is tjuvi here?
I don't know where. He's not here.

Amis: pasemalavi anga tu na pakadingua aken?
English: Could you please tell him I called?

Amis: a kiyukai a izua? manu pasumalji aken a pakadingua?
English: Is this the church? Did I dial the wrong number?

Amis: gakku i laiyi kucung aken, uri kiqatamen tu mangetjez a mareka sineziya a semantaliduan.
English: I am here at Lai Yi Junior High School and would like to invite devotees to perform at our school.
I'm sorry, the pastor's not here.

Amis: nanguaq nu tjemaula sun ta su ngadan, pakadinguan anga sun ni madju.
English: You can leave your name and contact you.

Amis: ui, ti tjuvi aken aku dingua812-xxxx masalu.
English: Okay, this is tjuvi at 812-xxxx, thank you.

Amis: tjuku, aku pasakicaquan sun a cemavu ta vaqu?
English: Tjuku, why do you want to learn how to make millet dumplings?

Amis: tjengelai aken aravc a keman ta cinavu a vaqu.
English: Because I like millet dumplings very much.

Amis: inika pazangal a cemavu, gata pazangal a qemepu ta sicavucavu a nemanga.
English: It is not difficult to make millet dumplings, but it is a bit more complicated to prepare the ingredients.
What do I need to prepare?

Amis: mavavua itjen a kiljavilu, kiviyaq, kiqaljup.
English: Go to the fields and pick up the leaves of formic acid berries, snow copper leaves, and manzanita.

Amis: tja siputjeveng a vaqu a sepatj a zikangan. paqenetju a kivengetj nu veneli sun ta vutjulj.
English: Soak the pork for at least four hours, and remember to buy the cotton rope for wrapping the dumplings when you buy the pork.

Amis: tjara namapakaizua anga, nu namasenav anga pariyuk, nu masukingecengelj kitjen a patagilj a cemavu.
English: It should be all set, the cauldron cleaned, and we'll be ready to wrap this afternoon.

Amis: masukiljaljava aken tu semukesa ta cinavu pasakeman anga aken.
English: I can't wait to enjoy my favorite cinavu.

Amis: kama i kapitjuan, anema su kinatjengelayan a kipusaliman?
tjengelai aken a pudringai, malaing tu bisangai, tu qayaqayam, sake paljilji ta quma.
English: I like to set traps for mice and birds, and go on field trips.
What's the difference between trapping and hunting?

Amis: maretimalji! a vavui, a sizi, a takec, a venan, a lava qemaljup aya itjen.
English: Of course it is different! Mountain pigs, goats, muntjac, deer and flying squirrels must be hunted.

Amis: pida su cavilj ta patagilj sun a kicaquan ta qemaljup?
English: How old were you when you started learning to hunt?

Amis: kemasi kakedriyan aken rukiciyur aken tjai vuvu a mavavua katua qemaljup.
English: Since I was a child, I used to accompany my grandfather to work and hunt in the mountains.

Amis: tisa ljegeai a su siaya,a kama nisa tjaiping?
English: Do you mean ljegeay, father of satjaiping?

Amis: ui, a manu paqenetjanan sun tjai su vuvu!
English: Yeah, so you remember your grandfather!

Amis: paqenetj aken, nu kasi vavua ti vuvu anga, na masikuku sa kamaya nu mangetjez, a tequtequng, a qaivaveng!
English: I remember that whenever my grandfather came home from the fields, he would bring along little things for me to play with, such as unicorns and poop worms!

Amis: aika cemuljev sun tjai vuvu, a pucaquan aravac.
English: Maybe you'll pass on your grandfather's excellent wisdom.

Amis: nu tacavilj anema nu kinazikiyan a tjalja su kinatjenglayan ?
English: What is your favorite season of the year?

Amis: tjalja tjengelayan aken ta kalja zulezulan.
English: Summer is my favorite time of year.

Amis: nu kalja zulezulan maqatitjen a emavkav eman ta kiyaping.
English: Because summer is a good season for swimming and eating ice.

Amis: tjengelay aken ta kaljavevean inika ljemaljaqel sa inika zemulezul.
English: I like spring because it's not too cold or too hot.

Amis: tjalja semulapeljan nu kaljavevean a i qinaljan.
English: Fall in the Tribe is the most comfortable time of the year.

Amis: tjengelay timadju ta kalja zulezulan, aya tua cemuvuq a nanemanemanga.
English: He likes spring because it is the season when everything grows.

Amis: manu maitazua! nanguaq a kinatacaviljan a kinazikiyan a penuljat, manu?
English: That's true. It's good all year round, don't you think?
Do you plan to go home for New Year's Eve this year?

Amis: uri maciyur amen a tacekeljan a tjumaq.
English: Our whole family will go home together.

Amis: kipasainu a nu qinaljan ta kadjunangan?
English: Which way is your tribe's location?

Amis: i pasaakav i quljpapuduan ta gade, bulai aravac a nia qinaljan.
English: A beautiful tribe on top of a mountain peak in Pingtung.
So how do you plan to get back?

Amis: palemak aken a kiciur ta kinacemekeljan ni kaka.
English: Might go back with my brother's family.

Amis: kemuda nu kuini a i qinaljan tjanumun?
English: How do you celebrate New Year's Eve in your hometown?

Amis: papecevungcevung amen ta kakanen, sane kalingulingulj a keman a tacekeljan.
English: We will cook and eat together as a family.

Amis: izua na kisumalji a taliduan na i qinaljan?
English: Any special events at the tribe?
I am a rather positive person by nature.

Amis: kemasi inu a kemeljang tu rupurepuran sun?
English: From which places do you know?

Amis: ikaken a makaya pivarung ta saliman, nu izua kusengesengan kupakirimuin a qemacuvung.
English: I don't procrastinate on things. If you have something, you get it done first.

Amis: titja sarigaljuan aku kinamalangan, gata a ku kaka ti avu mamav tja nu sun a rupurepuran.
English: I'm a slow personality, but my sister is a positive personality like you.

Amis: ui? a kukaka ti iping rukalumalj, ljakua rupasedjalu aken.
English: Is that so? I'm very cheerful, but my brother is shy.

Amis: nu tjapacunan sun rupazekatjan sun auta ta timanga.
English: You also seem to be more tolerant of others.

Amis: nanguaq aravac a tatuluan na suvuvu tjanumun a mapuljat.
English: What a great way for your grandmother to homeschool.

Amis: vuvu! djavadjavai, kisun a maqati a pusaladj tjanu aken?
English: vuvu, excuse me, can you help me?

Amis: madraudrav a ku susi i tjumaq, na macaqecaq aken i sasav.
English: I left my keys at home, I forgot to bring them out, and now I'm locked out.

Amis: izua ti vuvu, ljakua maculeq anga ravac a calinga ni madju.
English: Vuvu is at home, but his ears are hard of hearing very badly.

Amis: su tineracan anga ti su vuvu?
English: Did you yell at your vuvu?

Amis: ui, gata ika lemangeda! saka uri kisedjam aken ta su tadalj, sake pakanikai a tedep!
English: Yes, but she can't hear me! I'd like to borrow a ladder and enter the house from the second floor.
Call and see if you can hear it.

Amis: sema i nuinu sun ta gakku a kitulu?
izua aken i laiyi kucung, djemet ta qinaljan.
English: I went to Lai Yi Junior High School, which is very close to the tribe.

Amis: pidanga sun a cavilj a kitulutulu ?
sika drusa cavilj aken i gakku.
anema tjalja su kinatjengelangelayan a kicaquan i gakku?
English: Which subject are you more interested in at school?

Amis: tjalja tjengelangelayan aken ta patjara semenai.
English: I'm most interested in the music department.

Amis: ui, sa uri sema inu sun tucu?
English: Okay, now where are you going?

Amis: uri mazua aken tjai vuvu a kicaquan ta sinicuayanan a senai.
English: I'm going to vuvu to learn traditional songs.

Amis: anema nu senayan a tjalja su kinatjengelayan?
English: Which ballad interests you the most?

Amis: pazangal a kitulu ta pinaiwanan a kai?
English: Is it difficult to learn Paiwanese?

Amis: pakapazangal aken a pagalju, aza masanliyav a tja kakaiyan.
English: As there are many ethnic groups, I think it is a bit difficult.

Amis: gata na penapaulingavcu a su pinukaiyan.
tima sinsi a temulutulu tjanu sun?
ti vuvu. sa nu pulavalavai kidjadjalan aken ta sinsi na siyaku a kicaquan.
English: It's Grandma, and there are holidays to learn with teachers in the community.

Amis: nu i tjumaq mun qivuivumun ta kinacalisiyanan?
English: Do you speak in your family's language?

Amis: ui, tjaliyav a kemacalisiyanamen i tjumaq.
English: Yes, I use my ethnic language more at home.

Amis: nu ruqaqivu itjen ta kinacalisiyanan, setukulj itjen a macaqu.
English: If you speak the language often, you will progress faster.

Amis: djavadjavai, pasa vaik amen a tacekeljan a kivangavang. kiinu a sedjaljep a nia sazuain?
English: Sorry, we want to go on a family vacation, which place is more suitable?

Amis: pasagaikuku mun manu tjimaza i taiwan sakamaya?
English: Do you want to travel in Taiwan or abroad?
We would like to travel abroad.

Amis: bulai tu bulai ai dripung. i secengeceng tu semuljasulja tucu.
English: The scenery in Japan is beautiful right now, and it's currently the snowy season.

Amis: nu tja langedaan, tjara nanguaq, aligu talidu a ramaljemaljeng ta sulja.
English: Sounds good, the elders might be interested in enjoying the snow.
How many of your peers are there?

Amis: uri makapidalj mun a qadav a kivangavang?
English: How many days do you expect to play?

Amis: tjalja nanguaqan a makalimalj a qadav.
nanguaq, ikamakuda. nu pasuvililj tu drusa pulavayan kimun na vaik anga.
English: Okay, no problem. After two weeks, you're ready to go.

Amis: pai, pasemalavi amen ta su pinakazuanan anga
English: Please tell us about your school experience?

Amis: ui, ti tjuku a kungadan, na kitjaula aken i kalingku ta daigakku, aku kinitulu paka ta tingnau.
English: Okay, my name is tjuku from Hualien University, and I was a computer major in college.

Amis: pida anga sun a cavilj a kipusalimaliman?
English: How long have you been working?

Amis: ta kitjaula aken i gakku masengeseng aken, tjelu anga a cavilj.
English: I have been working for three years since I graduated.

Amis: aku pavalit sun ta su saliman, izua tjananguaq?
English: Why did you change your job? Is there a better one?

Amis: gata pasaljiyalauz aken a kitavak ta sikac.
English: It is because I want to familiarize myself with the environment in the metropolitan area.

Amis: izua su sinekeljangan i maza i taihuku?
English: Do you know anyone in Taipei?

Amis: imaza vetjek na kukama ti ljavuras.

English: It's all right, as long as you think it's appropriate.

Amis: matu izua anga sudju ni tjuku.
English: Tjuku seems to be in love.

Amis: aza pakadinguangua timadju a ljemita tu qadav.
English: Because she's on the phone every day.

Amis: namakuda a kinatjengelayan nimadju a uqaljai?
English: What kind of guys does she like?

Amis: avan a na penaseqetj a kakudan a katjengelayan.
English: She likes guys who are stable.

Amis: kina sauqaljai a sudju ni tjuku?
qadjav! ljakua ku pinacunan tatiyav i pukisiaan ti tjuku.
English: I don't know! But I saw tjuku at the train station yesterday.

Amis: ini, izua na kipaljevar a qacaqaca uqalai.
English: No, there's a tall man across from her.

Amis: uri vaik aken a kicapilj, ta pucekelj ni kuljelje.
English: I'm going to a kuljelje wedding.
Are they going to do a traditional dance?

Amis: ui, uri pasenai auta ta sipapucekecekelj.
English: Yes, traditional wedding ballads should be sung as well.

Amis: na kisumalji a senai na sipucekecekelj?
English: Is a wedding song different from a regular song?

Amis: ui, izua si qilaqiladj izua si ziyaziyan.
mainu itjen a kitulu ta senai kata dremaiyan?
English: Where are we going to learn to sing and dance?

Amis: kitjavililj itjen ta vavuluvulungan nucuai anga macaqu itjen.
English: Participate in the activities with the elderly, and you will be able to do so after a long time.

Amis: izua! ari, vaiki a kicapilj ulja sun a ljemizav.
English: Yes, come on! Come along and you'll see.

Amis: nungida anga tja maljevaq i qinaljan vuvu?
English: vuvu, when is the five-year festival of our tribal people?

Amis: ki maljavar a tja sikataqaljan ta pinaka nanguaq a qadav.
English: The tribe has to have a tribal council to decide on the date.

Amis: nu pasusangas ta maljevaq anemanema tja padjuluin?
English: What preparation is needed before the Five Year Festival?

Amis: na mapusazazatj a tja saliman, kimaya taqiljas a padjuludjulu.
English: It takes about a month to follow the schedule.

Amis: a namaya tja nuamen a tjaupatagilj a maqacuvung anemazua niya valain a pusaladj？
English: What can we young people do to help?

Amis: qemepulu ta kasiv, ta zaman, kivadaqu auta ta ramaljemaljeng.
English: You can cut lumber, pick up branches, or ask a senior.
Where is the stinger area located?
At the bottom of the tribe.

Amis: uzai na vaik ti tjama i camak a lemuiluv ta puqauan, tuki izua kavayan a djumaken tu sandjuljaten.
English: He was looking for a bamboo forest with Uncle Camak to see where he could pick up a long pole for spiking.

Amis: masan pidalj a zukuan a kacalisiyan i taiwan?
English: How many ethnic groups are there in Taiwan?

Amis: tapuluq saka sepatj a maretimaljimalji a kacalisiyan.

English: What are the names of these races?

Amis: izua atayal, amis, paiwan, bunun, puyuma, drekai, cuu, saisiat, tau, sau, kavalan, teruku, sakizaya, sediq.
English: There are the Atayal, Amis, Paiwan, Bunun, Peinan, Rukai, Tsou, Saisiat, Dawu, Thao, Kavalan, Taroko, Sakia, and Sedek.
Which group has the largest number of people?

Amis: timaima pasususu ta yatjumaq kata yaingav?
English: Which ethnic groups have a social class system?

Amis: drekai kata paiwan, izua auta puyuma a pinapaparetimaljimalji a caucau ta cavilj.
English: There are the Rukai and Paiwan, and there are also the Peinan, who are categorized by age.

Amis: maljimalji ta sutjaucikel, aicu na sepualang anga aken tu namakuda kakudan na kacalisiyan.
English: Thank you for your explanation, it gives me a better understanding of the Aboriginal people.
Remember to come back and play again!
