glutinous rice dumplings wrapped in leaves

Amis: djavadjavay a mapuljat, tucu uri temulu ti sinsi ta nakakanen a pinaiwanan.
English: Hello everyone. Today I am going to teach you how to say food in Paiwanese.

Amis: nasepualang anga sun tu anemamaya ti sinsi?
English: Do you understand what the teacher says?

Amis: sinsi maqati sun a mumalj a puita, ini anan aken nasepualan.
English: I don’t understand. Can you repeat it again?

Amis: pacunu a pasa maza! kaciuri a kisupu.
English: Look here, please! Repeat after me.

Amis: mumalju anan a puita, sa papezangalu nukisupu sun.
English: Read it again. Please speak louder.

Amis: sinsi, na maadjuq a ku inpic.
English: I forgot to bring my pen.

Amis: sinsi na maadjuq a ku siquliqulip.
English: I forgot to bring my eraser.

Amis: kisedjamu a su salasaladj tua siquliqulip.
English: Please borrow erasers from your classmates.

Amis: maqati sun a pasedjam tjanuaken ta su siquliqulip?

English: Class dismissed, see you next week.

Amis: ti dremedreman aken. ni druay a aljak.
English: I am the son of drangadrang, my name is djilu.

Amis: ti giu aken. ni piya sinsi a situ.
English: I’m a student of piya, I’m giu.

Amis: ti sedjam a ngadan na ku kama.
ti sedjam a ngadan na ku kaka a uqaljay.
English: He is my brother, his name is sedjam.

Amis: ui, ti buku a ngadan nimadju.
ini, ti ljua a ngadan nimadju.

English: She’s my friend, her name is vais.

Amis: tapuluq saka drusa anga cavilj nimadju.
pida anga cavilj na su kama?
lima puluq anga cavilj na ku kama.

English: How many brothers and sisters do you have?

Amis: madrusa a ku kaka a tjavulung a uqaljay kata vavayan, madrusa ku kaka tjaljaljak a uqaljay kata vavayan.
English: I have two older siblings and two younger siblings.

Amis: izua su kaka a tjavulung a uqaljay?
neka ku kaka a tjavulung a uqaljay.

English: How many people are in your family?
There are four of us in our family.

Amis: anema sengesengan ni kama i sedjam?
English: What does your uncle do for a living?

Amis: ku kaka a tjavulung a vavayan.
izua sengesengan na su kaka a tjavulung a vavayan?
English: Does your sister have a job?
Yes, I'm from the Paiwan tribe.
Yes, she's from the Puyuma tribe.
Yes, we are all very tall.

Amis: temakesikesi anga su kaka a vavayan?
English: Does your sister go to school?

Amis: saigu a su kaka a penaiwanan?
English: Do your siblings speak the language?
Yes, they speak the ethnic language.
How many brothers and sisters do you have?
I have three brothers and sisters.

Amis: na matevelj sun kata su matjaljaljak?
English: Do you live with your parents?

Amis: ui, na matevelj aken kata ku matjaljaljak.
English: Yes, I live with my mom and dad.

Amis: na matevelj sun katia su vuvu?
English: Do you live with your grandparents?
No, I didn't live with them.

Amis: na matevelj aken kata ku matjaljaljak, izuanan a ku kaka a tjavulung a uqaljay.
English: I live with my father, mother and brother.
When will you return to the tribe?
I always go back to my tribe in the summer.
I'm a child of the Paiwan tribe.
The sun is coming out, it's very hot.
Is it going to be cold outside?

Amis: ui naljemaljeqelan, kavau ta kedremedremel a kava.
English: It's cold, so wear warm clothes.

Amis: neka nu qerepus i kalevelevan, tjevuta anga vitjuqan uta.
English: There were no clouds in the sky, and the stars came out.
The rain has just stopped and the rainbow is coming out.

Amis: namakuda a kalevelevan izua i tjanumun?

English: We're going to have a big storm here.
I have to go to school.

Amis: na ljemaljeqelan, paka liavu a kemava.
English: The weather is very cold, so wear more clothes.

Amis: paqenetju a masi ljinay, uri qemudjalj nusauni.
English: It's going to rain heavily, you have to remember to bring an umbrella.

Amis: na cemelalaq kasauni, uri qemudjalj anga.
English: It just thundered, it's going to rain.

Amis: ui, na qemudjalj kasauni, ljakua na meljay anga.
English: It just rained, and now it's stopped.

Amis: tjevetjeveng a kadjalanan, matu na qemudjalj kasauni.
English: It seems to have rained and the road is wet.

Amis: na qemudjalj? aku tjevetjeveng a su kacavacavang?
English: Is it raining? Why are you all wet?

Amis: ui paljeqaca a qudjalj i sasaw, ika aken a na masi ljinay.
English: It's raining outside, so I didn't bring an umbrella.

Amis: namavali a aken, sika saqetjuqetju a ku qulu.
English: My head is blowing in the wind, so I have a headache now.

Amis: malingac aken, qaca aravac a qadaw kasauni.
English: The sun is so big, it makes me dizzy.
I forgot to bring my pen.
I forgot to bring my chopsticks.

Amis: ari veli, inika ken a na masi qecap uta.
English: I don't have one either, let's go buy one.

Amis: kiciur sun a veneli ta inpic?
ui, uri veneli aken ta siquliqulip uta.
English: Well, I still have to buy erasers.

Amis: ari a veneli ta tja kenamain.
ini, na kenama anga aken i tjumaq.
English: No, I've already eaten at home.

Amis: namadraudrau aken a semeljec ta ku tjinaljek.
English: I forgot to steam my lunchbox.
I forgot to bring my lunchbox.
Then let's eat my lunch box together!
What are you having for lunch?

Amis: uri keman aken i gakku ta ku cengelj.
English: I want a nutritious school lunch.
What are you having for lunch?

Amis: na kemacu aken ta ku kanen, kaciuri a keman.
English: I've brought a lunchbox today, let's eat together at noon!
Let's go play basketball, shall we?

Amis: ini, liaw aravac a ku vaveciken.

English: Please help me with the broom.
Okay, here's a broomstick for you.

Amis: paalapan tjai kuliw, semuasuap anan aken.
English: I'm still sweeping the floor, you ask kuliw to help you.

Amis: saw! djuasi azua namakungay a zaleman.

English: Okay, I'll go get the cloth.

Amis: saw djuasi a azua namaqungevuljan a qezung.
English: The windows are full of dust, go wipe them.

Amis: inika aken a makadjuas, kedri aravac aken.
English: Wait a minute, I'm still sweeping the floor.
I'm going to see my teacher.
Do you want to go home later?

Amis: uri vaik amen a semenay kata ku qali.
English: I'm going to sing with my friends.

Amis: uri kemuda timadju nu qemacuvung ta vaveciken?
English: What does he do after he finishes his homework?

Amis: idu saqumaqanu izua timadju i tjumaq.
English: She’s at home, please come in.
She’s not here, what can I do for you?
Grandpa, I’m Panay, please open the door.

Amis: kuliw, ti pia aken, ari kivangavang.
English: kuliu, I’m piya, I’ve come to play with you.

Amis: ui! singlit anga tjen tjanusun, idu pangetjezu a kivala.
English: Yeah! I miss you so much. Come on, let’s chat!
Please sit down and have some tea.

Amis: idu! kanu ta veljevelj, a ku kinacu a kemsi qinaljan.
idu kani, namakakesa anga ti kina tua tja kaiven.
English: Mom has cooked dinner, come and eat!
Okay, I’ll go wash my hands.

Amis: pai! suliavu a keman, inika tjen a qaliqali.
English: Try to eat and drink as much as possible, you’re not an outsider.
I ate a lot, I’m full.

Amis: uri vaik anga aken, mangetjez anga aken nu tjaivililj.
English: I’m leaving, I’ll see you next time.

Amis: uri vaik anga aken a ma tjumaq, ljazuanga vengin.
ui, nu izua su tenget kivalau anga.
English: Okay, come to my house sometime.

Amis: djavadjavai a mapuljat, nusauni uri vaik itjen a sema qinaljan a paljilji tjaivuvu i cudjuy.
English: Hello everyone, today I’m taking you to the tribe to interview the elders.
Grandpa, we’ve come to see you.

Amis: ia! bulay angata, aku mun a macaqu a penaiwanan!
English: You guys speak Paiwanese! That’s great!

Amis: djavadjavai a mapuljat, nusauni uri vaik itjen a sema puvaquan a masengeseng.
English: Hello everyone, today I will take you to work in the millet field.

Amis: idu, uri vaik anga itjen, kaciuciuri a mapuljat, paqenetju a nu turivecan.
English: Come and line up, remember to bring your tools.

Amis: ui sinsi, na masi turivecan anga amen.
English: Yes, sir, we’ve got our tools.
Not yet, it’s still far away.
You go get the bird catcher.

Amis: ui, tiaken a venilad ta qayaqayam.
English: Okay, I’ll go and catch the birds.

Amis: djavadjavay a mapuljat, uri vaik itjen a pacun ta qemuziquzip nusauni.
English: Hello everyone, we are going to the zoo today.

Amis: cuay anga aken a kikaljavaljava, saka anema tja pakazuavan?
English: Awesome! How are we going to get there?

Amis: ljevavavu anan, veneli aken ta kipu.
English: Everyone line up, we are ready to buy tickets.

Amis: tjaljiqaca aravac ca imaza, mareka qayaqayam a i maza, qatjuvi a izua. liaw anan a mare timaljimalji a qemuziquzip kigaljuvu a pacun.
English: There are birds in the front and snakes in the back.There are many different animals, take your time.

Amis: pumayan, saw pacunu ta qayaqayam numaya.
English: It doesn’t matter, then you go and watch the birds.

Amis: kaqepui anga imaza nu pasuvililj ta cengelj a tjelu a milingan.
English: We’ll be back in an hour.

Amis: liaw a nia pinacunan a maretimaljimalji a qatjuvi kata qayaqayam.
English: I saw a lot of snakes and a lot of birds.

Amis: ari anga, uri vaik anga itjen.
English: Hurry up, we have to go.

Amis: kaljavau aken, masetu anga ku kula.
English: Wait for me, my feet are tired.
There are a lot of people swimming here.

Amis: kaimazavi a kemavekav, ljataladj a aravac zaljum izua.
English: The water is deep there, so we just swim here.
What kind of car did you take?

Amis: uri kemuda sun a sema kuikay?
English: How do you go to church?

Amis: uri cumuin aken ni kama a sema kiukay.

English: How does he usually go to school?

Amis: ini, maka ta tjiing timadju a sema gakku.
English: He took the subway to school.

Amis: kemuda a su vuvu a veneli ta ljaceng?
English: How does your grandmother go to the grocery store?

Amis: ramaljeng anga ti vuvu, ljakua maqati anan a emutubay a veneli ta ljaceng.
English: She went to the grocery store on a motorcycle.

Amis: maka hikuki sun a sema drani?
English: How are you going to get to Orchid Island?

Amis: ini, uri maka ta varukur aken a sema drani.
English: I want to take a boat to Lanyu.

Amis: saka, uri kemuda timadju a sema drani?
English: How did he get to Orchid Island?

Amis: uri maka ta hikuki timadju uta.
English: He took a plane to Orchid Island.

Amis: anema ljinevavauvan nimadju a sema takaw?
English: What bus did he take to Kaohsiung?

Amis: malingac a ljevavaw ta basu timadju, qaw! na maka ta kauty timadju a sema takaw.
English: He took the THSR to Kaohsiung.

Amis: na maka ta kisia timadju a sema valangaw?
English: Did he take a train to Taitung?

Amis: ui na maka kisiya timadju a sema valangaw.
English: Yes, he took a train to Taitung.

Amis: na maka kisia timadju a sema valangaw?
English: Did he take a train to Taitung?

Amis: ini, na maka ta hikuki timadju a sema valangaw.
English: No, he took a plane to Taitung.

Amis: inu a tjalja demutan ta siljevavavan ta basu?
English: Is there a bus stop near here?

Amis: sevecu a pasa sangas, mapacun a siljevavavan ta basu.
English: If you go straight ahead, you will see the bus stop.
Where is the nearest MRT station?

Amis: neka nu tjiin imaza, amin a haia a su ljevavavan.
English: There is no MRT station here, you can only take a taxi.

Amis: nu maka ta basu, pida milingan a tja sidjaljun i gakku?
English: How long does it take to get to the school by bus?

Amis: tapuluq saka lima a bung, djemaljun itjen.
uri pida milingan, nu ljevavaw itjen ta kauti a kemasi takaw a tjalju taiciw?
English: How long does it take to get to Taichung by THSR?

Amis: ita a milingan a tja sidjaljun.
English: I will come to Taichung in an hour.

ui, macaqu aken ta na Amis kata na sepiuma

Amis: aza iubingkiyuku a kinacadjan kata gaku demut ri ?
English: Is the post office close to the school?
Yes, it is within walking distance.

Amis: aza kakanan a kinacadjan kata tisiaba demut ri ?
English: Is the restaurant close to the station?

Amis: tjevuta ta tisiaba djemavac tu lima bung djemaljun.
English: It only takes five minutes after you walk out of the station.
I would like to visit you.

Amis: nusauny izua u kudaing neka i tjumaq, nu tjaivililj anga a qadaw.
English: I am out today. How about another day?

Amis: saka nutiaw izua su djikan? nu pasuvililj tua cengelj u kimaw sun.
English: Then, are you available tomorrow? I’ll visit you tomorrow afternoon.

Amis: dikilu, u kaljavaljavaw sun i tjumaq.
English: Sure, I will wait for you at home.

Amis: dikilu aken semeljup tua su zaing? sa kiruku aken.
English: Would you mind if  I do the voice recording? I would like to keep a record.
Would you mind if I do the video recording?

Amis: sekulung aken, ika pinarimasudj a kuvaw, maya lja!
English: No, I am plain and the warehouse hasn’t been tidied up yet.
Then I will just take photos.

Amis: masalu tjanusun gemaugaw tua ku sikivadaq.
English: Thank you for accepting the interview.
You are welcome. What would you like to know?

Amis: kivadaqaw sun ka maqacuvucuvung anan sun anema su sengsengan?
English: What do you do when you are young?

Amis: kasicuayan kinsac a ken, ljakua tucu na kitjaulanga en.
English: : I was a police officer but I am retired now.
Then, are you working at the moment?

Amis: kivadaqaw a kinaizuanan na su aljak i qinaljan tauta?
English: Do your kids live in the tribe too?

Amis: ini, a kinaizuanan na u aljak i hici.
English: No, my kids are all living in the city.

Amis: sa macidicidilj sun i tua su kinaizuanan?
English: Then, do you live by yourself?

Amis: izuanan ku qinuzip ita vatu kata qayaqayam, tiamadju matu ku taqumaqanan tauta.
English: I also keep a dog and a bird. They are my family.

Amis: na qemuzip a en tu ita ta ngiyaw uta, izua dubuc na zemang ika masepelj.
English: I have a cat too. I won’t get bored with the company of my pet.

Amis: sa kivadaq aken tjanusun tua pakata qemaljup a palisi.
English: I would like to ask you about the taboos of hunting.

Amis: ika liaw u kineljang, ljakua a ku kineljan tjara ku tevelay sun
English: I don’t know much about that, but I will tell you everything I know.

Amis: aza nimun siqaljuqaljup a kuwang a turivecan izua anema palisi?
English: Do you have any taboos about hunting weapons?

Amis: aza tja siqaljup kuwang a turivecan dikinay vavayan a cemelcel.
English: Our hunting weapons are untouchable to women.

Amis: aza vavayan dikilu kiciul a qemaljup?
English: Then, can women go hunting together?

Amis: dikinay, a vavayan inika dikilu a qemaljup tauta.
English: No, women cannot go hunting either.

Amis: buya nekanga vauwa i tjumaq, sau veliu ta vauwa.
English: buya, our home is out of rice wine, please go and buy some.

Amis: izuanan ita dalilj i kakesan. pasaladji a venely.
English: There is still one bottle left in the kitchen, so there is no need to buy one!

Amis: talanay a ita dalilj, sau veliu anan tu drusa mangetjez.
English: One bottle is not enough for me, go and buy two more back.

Amis: uli veneli aken ta vauwa, pavelively mun?
English: I am looking for rice wine. Do you have any rice wine?
Yes! How many bottles do you need?

Amis: uli venely aken tu drusa dalilj, venely anan tua talubukan a paday
English: I want two bottles and a pack of rice.
Here is the rice, what else do you need?

Amis: uli venely anan ken ta qecilu, izua nimun?
English: I want some eggs too, do you have some?

Amis: nekanga nia qecilu na sepavei anga.

English: I want to buy some clothes.
What kind of clothes do you like?

Amis: uli venely aken tua hansudi a kava.
English: I want to buy the clothes with short sleeves.

Amis: izuanan niamen a vuteqiteqilj kata cangiangia.
English: : We have white and blue ones too.

Amis: pavai a ken ta cangiangia a kava tu ita.
English: Please give me the clothes in blue.

Amis: camak na mainu sun kasauny? na vaik sun a undu?
English: camak, where have you been just now? Did you go exercising?

Amis: ini, uli vaik pusaladj ta ku vuvu vavayan pavely ta ljaceng.
English: No, I went grocery shopping for my grandma.

Amis: maitazua! izua su djikan nu qezemetj? timitja kaciul a kaiv.
English: No wonder! Are you available at night? Would you like to have a meal with me?

Amis: dikinay, uli vaik aken venely tua kava.
English: No, I want to buy some clothes.

Amis: saka kiciul aken tjanusun a vaik.
English: Then, I will go with you.

Amis: djavadjavay, kivadaqaw aicu a talekelekan a ljaceng pida pakiyaw?
English: Hello, how much is this bunch of vegetables?

Amis: a ljaceng nu ita talekelekan drusa puluq a pakiyaw.
English: The vegetables are $20 for a bunch.
How much are these sweet potatoes?

Amis: a vurasi nu ita tjingtjing tjelu puluq a pakiyaw.
English: Sweet potatoes are thirty dollars for a pound.

Amis: pavai en tu drusa talekelekan a ljaceng kata ita tjingtjing a vurasy.
English: Please give me two bunches of vegetables and a pound of sweet potatoes.

Amis: camak madraudraw a kemacu ta tingnaw ken, dikilu sun a pasedjam tjanuaken?
English: camak, I forgot to bring my pen. Can you lend me one?

Amis: neka niaken tauta, aicu ni muni.
English: I don’t have one either. This is muni’s.

Amis: dikilu pasedjam tjanuaken a palamu? djaljaw ki u pacikely tjanusun.
English: Can you lend me the pen for a second? I will return to you immediately.

Amis: masalu, pusaladji anga ken a pasemalaw tjai muni tu masalu.
English: Thank you and thank muni for me.

Amis: uli pacikel aken tua aicu a drusa sapitj.
English: I want to return these two books.

Amis: ui, uli saljinganan sun ta anema?
English: No problem and what else do you need?

Amis: tiaken uli kisedjam anan ta aicu tjelu a sapitj.
English: I would like to borrow these three books.

Amis: ui, nusikatjelu anga paqenetju a pacikel.
English: Sure and remember to return them after three days.

Amis: inianan pacikel sun ta ku siquluqulip.
English: You haven’t returned me the eraser.

Amis: aza ku siquliqulip manu mainu maulav anga.
English: Then, why is my eraser missing?
Did you lend it to camak?

Amis: ika ken kemeljang. u vaiki a kivadaq timadju.
English: I don’t know. I will go and ask her.

Amis: pasedjamay anan sun ta u siquliqulip.
English: I will lend you my eraser first.

Amis: muni, ti camak a na pasedjam tjanusun tucu a tjiaku?
English: muni, did camak lend you this coat?

Amis: ini, aicu na u kina vinelian tjanuaken.
English: No, my mom bought it for me.
camak’s coat is the same as yours.

Amis: a nimadju tjiaku qecengecengel, ika mamaw niamen quljaw.
English: His coat is black, so our colors are different.

Amis: muni, na kisedjam sun ta paisu ni camak?
English: muni, did you borrow money from camak?

Amis: izua, uli pacikeleng angata kasauny tjaimadju, ljakua madraudraw a kemacu ta paisu.
English: Yes, I was supposed to return to him today, but I forgot to bring the money.
Then, when will you return the money?
I will return to him tomorrow.

Amis: ui, u pusaladjay sun a pasemalav tjai camak.
English: Okay, I will tell camak for you.

Amis: nu djemekep tua kulavaw ayaing ta siqezetjan tua qaciljay a dringay, a djemekep tua tjikuray ayaing ta veceqel a dringay.
English: It is correct to catch mice through rangay and catch bamboo partridges through qjiulang.

Amis: manu maitucu, pasalisaliw anga ken djaljepan ika na djemameq.
English: No wonder! I am mistaken and that’s why I cannot catch any of them.

Amis: u su tuluvi anga tu kemuda cukulu ta drusa malji a dringay.
English: Then I will teach you how to set up these two traps.

Amis: ui! bulay ngata! nu maitucu uli macaqu a djemekep ta sacemel.
English: Great! I will be able to catch the prey in the future.

Amis: laladruqan anga cemel i can, sau alapu ta dramiya i kuvaw, ali semavavua.
English: The grass in the fields is too tall. Go to the warehouse to take the sickle and let’s go to the fields.

Amis: aza itua cepeng a gidigidi, nu ljitaladj sun ta kuvaw su pacuanan anga.
English: It is next to the round basket. You will see it when you enter the warehouse.

Amis: kigalju a malap, maya mapasaqetju. ladjay a dramiya.
English: Be careful and don’t get hurt. The sickle is very sharp.

Amis: a ku dringay izua i petekuteku ta kasiw.
English: My trap is under that tree.

Amis: imaza u pinizua ta pukeljang, kemeljang a ken ta u dringay tu inu.
English: I make a mark here, so I know where my trap is.

Amis: aicu a kadrau tja pasa maza i pana a kiciqaw.
English: This is a fish trap which we put beside the river for fishing.

Amis: aza izua neka tja kadrau, tiamen ayaing ta panadip a djemekep ta ciqaw.
English: We don’t have any fish traps there, so we catch fish with a fishing rod.

Amis: inianan paqayam a panadip a ken, nu tjaivililj tului anga ken wi?
English: I have never used a fishing rod before, would you mind teaching me next time?

Amis: ui! nu tjaivililj maciuli anga panadip.
English: Sure! Let’s go fishing together next time.

Amis: nu tjaivililj u tului anga sun ta seman kadrau
English: I will teach you how to make a fish trap next time.

Amis: midradrua su panadip, qadjaw izua ciqaw na makalavic! kilimu lakacu.
English: Your fishing rod is moving. Isn’t the fish on the hook? Pull it up!

Amis: galjuanan, mirarua ravac a varukur, imaza en a lemakac ta panadip, sau mazua pusaladj a malap tua ku aralj.
English: Wait, the ship is rolling heavily. I am here to pull the fishing rod and you should go there to grab me the net.

Amis: lakacu a ciqaw pasa maza tjanuaken, u pusaladjay sun a lemakac.
English: Pull the fish to my side and I will help you pull it up.

Amis: bulay angata! kasauny pulamy, aza kadrangu na mapeljuq anga.
English: Great! It is a bumper crop today with full fish baskets.

Amis: kilimu vaiki tja sipaseljavak katua mapuljat.
English: Let’s go back immediately and share it with everyone.

Amis: maya kivangavang anga, qiladju kilimu i ta qiladjan.
English: Stop playing and quickly sit in your seat.

Amis: sikalima a’adaw tucu, pulavay nu tiyav, kaciwciwli anga vayika kivangavang!
English: It’s Friday today, we have a day off tomorrow. Let’s go out and play together!
Great! Let’s go to the riverside.
What day will it be tomorrow?

Amis: sikadjelu nu tiyav, nu tiyave a makakecengelj vayikanga djen a kivangavang ta benulu!
English: Tomorrow will be Wednesday. Let’s go play ball tomorrow afternoon!

Amis: anema su kudayin nu tiyav a qadjaman?
English: What will you be doing tomorrow morning?

Amis: sikapidjulj nu tiyav, vayiq a ken sema kiyukay kati kina.
English: Tomorrow will be Sunday, I will be going to church with my mom.

Amis: pasumudjaq ken, vayiq a ken sema bingzu(aluvu).
English: I feel like vomiting. I need to go to the restroom.

Amis: sinsi, sakedju a ku djiyalj, pasa mabingzu.
English: Teacher, I have a stomachache. I need to go to the restroom.
May I go wash my hands?

Amis: uri paluwanga ta kakituluan, galjuwanan a su sivayiq.
English: It’s almost time for class to end. Wait a little longer.

Amis: sinsi, sa’edju a ku ’ulu, kivada ken nu maka kingcengelj.
English: It’s almost time for class to end. Wait a little longer.
Okay, take care and go home.

Amis: sinsi, uri kivadaq a ken nu djayvililj a sika ita qadaw, vayiq aken kipacun ta kuysang.
English: Teacher, I need to take a sick leave next Monday. I have to see a doctor.

Amis: sa’edju a djialj ni madju, i bingzu ti madju.
English: She has a stomachache. She’s in the restroom.

Amis: sinsi, sa’edju a djugerau ni kadraw, na kivada tusaa ’adaw.
English: Teacher, kadraw has a sore throat. She took a sick leave today.

Amis: awmaya ini a mangedjez ti paday?
a ku ngada ti camak, tapuluq aku cavilj.
English: My name is camak, and I’m 10 years old.
What ethnic group are you from?

Amis: aljaq a ken na paywan zuku.

English: Are all your family members indigenous?
Yes, my whole family is paywan.
Are all your family members indigenous?

Amis: ini, paywan aku kama, paylang aku kina.
English: No, my father is paywan, and my mother is Han Taiwanese.

Amis: su kama a zuwa? pidanga cavilje ni madju?
English: Is that your father? How old is he?

Amis: unem a pulu anga cavilj ni madju.
su kama a zuwa? pidanga cavilje ni madju?
English: Is that your father? How old is he?

Amis: ini, niya lamaljeng ti madju i qinalja, alu a pulu anga a cavilj ni madju.
English: No, he is an elder of our tribe. He is 80 years old.

Amis: pida anga a cavilj na su kaka djavulung?
a ku kukaka a djavulung ita sa alu pulu a cavilj.
a su kaka djavulung ta cavilj djavulung alavac djanusun?
English: Is your brother much older than you?

Amis: ita sa sepadj pulu a ku pasaqaca.
cuacuay anga ini a mapacucun, tuki sun na ljavavaw anga?
English: I haven’t seen you in a while. Have you grown taller?

Amis: ui, ita sa djelu a puluq a ku pasavavaw.
ini, pasaliv anga a su pinacunan.
ui, djelu a pulu anga djindjin a ku siqaacanga tucu.
vayike ken sema pangkungse kemim tay singsi.
English: I’m going to the office to see the teacher.

Amis: uri vayika venelic ta cemel ti madju.
English: He’s going to throw away the trash.

Amis: i ta kakavekavan ti madju, uri malalumalje ta kemavekav ti madju nusawni.
English: He’s at the swimming pool. He’s going to compete in a swimming competition later.

Amis: inuan ti paday? uri malalumalje ta mekelje ti madju nusawni.
English: Where is paday? She’s going to compete in a running competition later.

Amis: i ta kakaqepuan ti madj, ku vaykaw a djemaulj ti madj.
English: She’s in the auditorium. I’ll go call her.

Amis: kawdelji a vayiq sema ta aungduan.
English: Let’s go to the playground together.

Amis: vayikanan akn a kiveli ta cengelj, kalikimen anga sun nusawni.
English: I’ll go buy lunch first, and then I’ll meet you later.

Amis: kaciyuli a vayiq cemaculju ta bingtu!
English: Let’s carry the lunch boxes together!

Amis: kalikimu ta zuma, vayiq akn kemim djay sinsi.
English: You find someone else, I’m going to find the teacher.

Amis: kadraw uri malalumalj ta palucivan a sibuluan tu sa ’adaw?
English: Is kadraw competing in croquet today?

Amis: ini, uri malalumalj ta pakuvavaw ti madju.
English: No, he’s competing in high jump.

Amis: uri kisangka sun a malalumaljnu nu ungdukay tazua ’adaw?
English: Will you compete in the sports day?

Amis: ui lja, makaya ken a malalumalj ta mekelj.
uri kisangka sun a malalumaljnu nu ungdukay tazua qadaw?
English: Will you compete in the sports day?

Amis: makaya ken a malalumalj ta palucivan a sibuluan.
anema ta kudayin tazuwa qadaw nu ungdukay djen?
English: What will we do in the sports day?

Amis: uri malalumalj djen a malalakac ta calis.
English: We will compete in tug of war.

Amis: uri paveli ta kakanen nu ungdukay djen?
English: Will we sell food at the sports day?

Amis: ini, uri paveli djen ta djapedjapesen a bulu.
su djameqen a sangasangsan, paqulid tu djaljapalavacan!
English: Congratulations on getting first place! You’re amazing!

Amis: i djuma ti vuvu a vavayan.
izua, na taqed i umaan ti madju
English: Yes, she’s sleeping in her room.

Amis: i djuma ti vuvu a vavayan.
neka, djawvayvayiq ti madju, nu masulem i mangdjez.
English: No, she’s not. She just went out and will be back in the evening.

Amis: i vavaw a nikay ti madju, saw i vavaw kemin djay madju.
English: He’s upstairs. You can go up and find him.

Amis: ui, kadruy! cuacuay anga ini a pacun dja nusun, na talivaq sun.
English: It’s kadruy. I haven’t seen you in a while! How have you been?

Amis: nanguwanguwa lja! mangedjez ake a kizepezepan dja nu sun.
English: I’m doing great! I came to chat with you.

Amis: i ta kakesanan a seman djamadjamay ti madju, vayika ken a djemaulj djay madju.
English: He’s in the kitchen cooking. Let me go call him.

Amis: vayiq anga sema puvuyuvuyuan djemepeq ta vuyu ti madju
English: She went to the chicken coop to catch chickens.

Amis: ini a idjumaq a nu vuvu a u’aljay, i suyding ti madju, i djumaq mun a kemaljava ta sipangedjez ni madju.
English: Your grandfather is not at home. He’s in the field. Wait for him to come back.

Amis: ini a mapacun na cuacuay anga, meqacanga sun.
English: I haven’t seen you in a while. You’ve grown taller.

Amis: na maleva varung pacuna tu mangedjezanga sun.
English: It’s so good to see you.

Amis: aycu a pangudralj sinipavay dja numun, padjingu pasata pingsiyang.
English: Here’s a pineapple for you. Put it in the refrigerator.

Amis: awmay cuwacuayanga ini a mangedjez, ku djawljaw a mapuljat sa maciwli a keman.
English: It’s been a while. Let’s have a meal together.

Amis: maya ma’udjaw anga, temeqel aken ta uca sakamaya, idu sema keting djen a mazazepzep.
English: No need to bother. I’ll just have tea. Let’s sit in the living room and chat.

Amis: maljimalji ta su kiniljevakan, uri vaykanga ken.
English: Thank you for your hospitality. I have to go now.

Amis: aycu a vuyu djaw vucien, ta su kacuin sa galjuannga a keman.
English: This chicken was just freshly killed. Take it home and enjoy it slowly.

Amis: nanguwa nu tiyiav a makakingcengelj ti sun a ti aken a sicevungan?
English: Can I make an appointment with you tomorrow afternoon?

Amis: nanguwa mecevun anga djen i tatakesiyan? uri pasasing sa luingen djen.
English: How about meeting at school? We need to shoot a video.

Amis: nu mayatuzua vaiki a makakaqepuan anga, lemava aken ta ljungpaw a semazua.
English: Then let’s go to the community center. I’ll wear folk costume.

Amis: nu mavusilak a veljangaw na djuyis nguwangu alavac i ta nia qinaljan﹐ kalavau a patje mavusilak anga a veljangaw kelju anga kalim djanua ken.
English: The cherry blossoms in our tribe are beautiful when they bloom. Come find me when the flowers bloom!

Amis: nu mayatazua mudri maqaljava padje kaljavevuan, sesuay alavace.
English: That would have to wait until spring. It’s too late, isn’t it?

Amis: numaya sun nu sipalisiyan ta maljeveq bangdjezan anga.

English: Alright! I’m looking forward to it!

Amis: kivada tja nu sun﹐ awmaya nu cemikel sema qinaljan ta sivaljutan
English: May I ask why you decided to move back to the tribe?
I want to return to teach at the local school.

Amis: awmaya ini izua i lizuq a temulu
English: Why not teach in the city?

Amis: ayatua singelit aken ta ku qinaljan﹐mayanga saljinga tu pacikelan ta sikamanguan na qinaljan.
English: Because I miss my hometown and I also want to give back to the tribe.

Amis: macaqu sun a cemaqis﹐ti ma na temulu djanusun.
English: You’re very skilled at weaving, who taught you?

Amis: mavan a ku vuvu a vavayan, tjalja macaquan a cemaqis i ta nia qinaljan ti madju.
English: It was my grandmother, she is the most skilled weaver in our tribe.

Amis: awmaya izua su vinalungan a kitulu ta cemaqis?
English: How did you develop an interest in learning weaving?

Amis: ni amen a kakudanan a cemeqis, ulja paljazua za kakudanan aku vinalungan.
English: Weaving is a part of our culture, and I want to ensure its continuity.

Amis: sanguwa ta tekelen aycu a vinavan ta vaqu.
ti aken a na venava lja!
djlja macakuan sun. cuay a vinavan taycu?
English: You’re really talented. Does it take a long time to make?

Amis: ini, pinaka pitjuljan sa pakaluayi. azua si kesan sangasan za djuwadjuway a paday kesayin patjepeliulj, sa vecelelj sana pasazuay ta pikaq sa kadikadi a cengcengan sa seman lipudrupudruin sana ljenguai pasa ta djilung.
English: No, it only takes about a week. After steaming the sticky rice and white rice, we mix it with yeast powder, and then it can be stored in a jar.

Amis: izua imaza ku kamangulj kata kecang, savid aku sinitalem lja!
English: I have chili and lokiy, both grown by myself!

Amis: pida paysu nu drusa penuljat a puvelian.
！nu teveljen pusi a drusa iday sa lima pulu a paysu.
W:djengelay aken tu sa kava﹐pida paysu?
English: I like this piece of clothing. How much is it?
It's too expensive. Can't you lower the price a bit?
No, if I lower it further, I'll lose money.

Amis: ui numaya! za padjalim akn tu ita ’ecengecengel a kava.
English: Alright then, I'll take a black piece of clothing.

Amis: padjalim aken taycua a tjakit kata paliyuq.
English: I want this knife and this pot.

Amis: nu teveljen pusi a drusa quzulj﹐aicu ku kinaminan sa sinalima a qiniatian, pusaluan djala makaya cuacuay a sikipusngsenganan.
English: It's a total of 2000 dollars. I handmade these, and they are guaranteed to last a long time.

Amis: nu si siyukay ta ku aliyaliyan mangedjez a qiveli﹐ mkaya papemadjuluin tu qedri
English: I'll introduce my friend to buy. Can you give a further discount?

Amis: ui numaya!pa’eljingay sun tu alu anga sisupuan
English: Alright! I'll give you a 20% discount.

Amis: kelju pacunu! izua itung, djalupung a sipaveliveli.
English: Come and take a look! We sell clothes and hats.

Amis: nu i ta kava djelu itay sa lima puluq a paysu﹐ nu djelu ida qudraw a paysu.
English: One piece of clothing is 350 dollars, three pieces for 1000 dollars.

Amis: veneli aken tu ita skamaya﹐ lapana ken ta na va’uan.
English: I'll just buy one piece, please give me a new one.

Amis: djavadjavay﹐pasu veneli akn ta djuadjuay a kinesa sa djinaung a vudjulj.
English: Hello, I would like to buy sticky rice and braised pork with maqaw pepper.

Amis: maka pavely anga ta kinesa, izuanan a ku tjana a kingekingec, pasa veneli sun?
English: The rice is sold out. I have tana pancakes, would you like to buy them?

Amis: ui numaya! lapana ken tu ida cavuan﹐ nu djavililj veneli anga ken ta kinesa.
English: Alright, please give me one. I'll come back next time to buy rice.

Amis: ui. ku sialapan sun sa ljenguwaki pasa ta lupuq﹐ nu maytucu lima puluq a paysu.
English: Okay, I'll pack it in a bag for you. That'll be 50 dollars.

Amis: ui angata lja, cacuay aravac a ini a pacun tjanusun.

English: I hope he works out well.

Amis: san kilailaing pakata paisu katua zineliulj na mareka nia salasaladj.

Amis: padinguangua sakamaya timadju nu ljemita ta qadaw.

Amis: na valeljevelj aravac a su sudju.

Amis: akumaya neka anan a su sudju? mayanga na micaucauan sun?

Amis: tjakudain! kedri aravac a tja sepi.

Amis: aicu mavan a nia kava a pinayuanan, uri vaik aken ta nia palisian.

Amis: ui, ayatua namasan kakudanan aicu ita nia palisian.

English: When he went looking for a girlfriend, he was wearing a warrior dress and no panties.
That scarf is supposed to cover the lower half of your body.

Amis: azati vavayav amaitucu namaya uta na maqacuvucuvung anga timadju
English: It's the same with girls. As adults.
I'll give her adult earrings and a bracelet.

Amis: pai azanu pucekecekelj timadju ljinenguaq a seman tjekep sa ljiniqu aya taza qinatucu a ptjaiqayaw
English: When she got married, she was given a special bridal wreath with a silver hair chain.

Amis: namatazua sinikipukeljang tu na venacevac anan timadju tuna kemaljat anan tua kinacavacavan
English: That means she's still wearing her unmarried earrings and bracelet.

Amis: tu timadju amaitucu kavavayanan nekanan nu limipengai tjai madju ta kinacavacavan nimadju
English: Proving that she is a pure maiden who has never had a friend defile her.

Amis: qaupai nuna kitjiljivan tua qaliqali nguanguaq timadju na venacevac na kemaljat
English: She was very beautiful when she stood in front of the crowd, wearing girly earrings and a bracelet.

Amis: aza nuna pucekeljangaitjen kaamalji ana makuda tja pasanguaq
English: After we're married, we can't look any better.

Amis: nu kitjiljivan itjn tuaza qaliqali a maitucu iniang katjenana venacevac inianga katjenana kemaljat
English: We no longer wear girly earrings or bracelets when standing on someone's right or left.

Amis: iniang katjenana ljemakaraw tuaza sinan ljiniqa
English: We can't wear young wreaths anymore.

Amis: qausa qauna pucekelj anga itjen a maitucu saka seman ljakaraw a maitucu
English: So... If we're ever married, we'll make a bridal wreath.

Amis: izuangauta za sikudan tu inika maqacuvucuvung timadju
English: There are also provisions for not being a teenage bride

Amis: qinai tucu anga za sinan tjekep tjaimadju sa nekanga za imaza ljiniqa
English: The wreath is just a normal braid, without the silver chain of hair.

Amis: pai aicu paqulid a liyasaw aicu a caucau pucekecekelj aya za vavulungan
English: The old man will know that this is really a widow getting married again.

Amis: aika kemeljakeljng amaitucu a kasi tjuqalja a kasi ikakemeljang ki pucekeljang kina kemudang timadju qai
English: Maybe people from out of town don't know she's married or anything.
That's how people find out you're married.

Amis: nu zemiyaziyan tiya madju saka inianga ka ljiniqu aza nimadj a tjekep
English: When they danced the traditional dance, the wreaths were no longer braided with hair and silver chains.

Amis: namatazua za mana sicuayan a kakudan
English: The traditional norm used to be this

Amis: nu macaitjen ka tiyaw ka sikatjelu
English: If someone died in the past

Amis: neka nutha pingyang a pacual tucu neka nu varukur
English: We didn't have a freezer or a coffin like we do now.

Amis: anu macaitjin pakakirimurimuin a ngatannitjin a kembung a
English: The moment we die, we'll be bundled up on our knees with our heads hanging down.

Amis: ljanu cuaitje tatja pinacayan kudresul inika makayanga macipilj
English: It's because once we're out of breath, our bodies stiffen up and it's hard for us to squat again.

Amis: nu masemusemutj sialap angata taza qadjai sa qadjai timadju sa pudrungi
English: He grabbed a rope and wrapped it around the body in a squatting position right after he died.

Amis: aza itung nimadju a zinaura sinipakicauv tai madju ana maitucu
English: And then he covered it with his shawl.

Amis: sakanu pacun itje matu matu izua timadju a ikana macai a na matazua na tjemeqang ana kitjiljivan tja nuitjin a izuaitje a pacucun tjai madju
English: It looks like she's not dead. She's sitting next to us. We're looking at her.

Amis: qaunu uqaljai timadju ana maligu tua kinauqaljayan
na malap tua venan tua vavui tua anemanemanga na qemuziquzipang
English: I've hunted water deer, mountain hogs, some trophy hunting, and more.
He puts lilies on his head.

Amis: qauza uqaljai nu inika na malalap ta anemanema amin aza zemiyaziyan a semenasenai
English: The only other people who never got a kill were the men who sang and danced.

Amis: paljailjain taza ciljabeljb ayamen ka tjai sangas taza qudjidjilj a hana
English: Put a Christmas crocus on him.

Amis: pai mana sikeljakeljang naza qaljaqalja nu mangtjez a qiyavan a maitucu
English: So, it's obvious when an outsider comes in to pick up a hunter.

Amis: pacun kauqaljayan aicu aya pina ljailjai tusa kavaluan aya qau
English: This is a real man who wears lilies.
If you see someone wearing Christmas saffron.

Amis: uqaljai tu uqaljai timadju inika sinan pazangal nuza na paki pacaing tjai madju nu macaianga
English: It's just an ordinary man who won't be valued by those who come to console him.
If someone died in the past

Amis: nekanu kusui dri a salulum a siljikeljik tjanuitjen a pape salum
English: No lemongrass perfume to cozy up to the remains.

Amis: a mavulji aza saluman nimadju azana cuaianga i vavavan
English: To cover up and remove long-lasting odors.

Amis: qau vaik itjen a miru ljaljikan aza ljaljikang satja
English: We'll just have to pick up some mint.

Amis: satja ledeleden satja pasazuan tjai madju a pakipalingulj taza qiniladjan nimadju
English: Let's rub it around the remains.

Amis: mavulji anga za nimadju a saluman namatazua pai
English: It covers up his odor, that's all.

Amis: manu pasazuain ta saljaw timadju pai
English: Then they put the squatting body into a large ceramic pot.

Amis: qaupai nu mangtjngtjez izuang za pinadjele aru kaizuanan a pasazua taza saljaw
English: When we arrived at the cemetery, we had already prepared to place the pots in the graves.

Amis: pasa tjaladjen a saljaw sana pasatjaladjen timadju a cauvau
English: We'll put the body in the pot and then we'll put the body in the pot.

Amis: qau nuna matazua aza angalj naza saljaw ana maitucu sinika ljaivavaw naza qulu nimadju ana macai
English: But if the dead man's head is bald out of the mouth of the pot.

Amis: na semaleljeselj aravac saqetju atja varung
English: It's very pathetic. It hurts to look at it.

Amis: djepedjepen a pasatjaladj sa caqevin taza qaciljai timadju pau
English: The excess head will be pressed down with a hard squeeze and covered with a stone slab.

Amis: nu qacaqaca ravac pai ikamakaya djepedjepin aza pakamaza za angalj naza..saljaw
English: If the victim had a large bald spot, he couldn't be squeezed in from the neck up.

Amis: upuin a kipalingulj a maitucu aza nimadju aza kinaizuanan
English: They raised him with a stone alongside the pots.
Then we're ready to cover it.

Amis: nuru cemaqev anga tiamadju nu kagusaman qemauqau a kin simuluq angata
English: Before the covering, if the deceased was the head of the family, a senior would yell ten times.

Amis: aza nuru cemaqev anga tjaimadju azaru zepuljin anga timadju ta qipu pai qemauqaw a kin simuluq angata aza kagusaman
English: Only the head of the family: the moment of burying in the ground will be covered with ten shouts.

Amis: aza tjaljaljaljaljak a maitucu kinlimalj a qemauqaw
English: For the rest of the aristocracy, the only funeral service is to shout five times.

Amis: na matazua za siceveljan ka tiyaw ka sika tjelu
English: This is how burials used to be done.

Amis: na mapaula aravac atja sikacu ka tiyaw ka sikatjelu
English: We had a hard life in the past.
It's much better now. There's a coffin.

Amis: aza na macaitjin makayaitjn a pitjumaqin a taqiljas a makasimuluq
English: When someone passes away, we can leave it at home for a month or ten days.

Amis: qau izua za pingsiyang a pinitja nuitjen tja pinitjaladj timadju
English: We have a freezer to put the body in.
So I can look at him.

Amis: nuri vaikitje a tjumaqanan murivaikitjen a pacunanan pacunitjen tjaimadju na qemereng
English: When I entered the house to console him, I saw his body lying intact.
Comfortable body make-up as if you were sleeping

Amis: qemauqaung itjen ljakua nutja saqetjuannutja varung
English: We're crying, but not too much.

Amis: takudain kinuletjan anga nuana qemati tu sumucikel ta nasi nimadju
English: What can be done about God's plan to take back his life!

Amis: ikatjena sadjelung aravac azatja varung nupacunitjen tua qinerengan nimadju ana seljenguaq aravac
English: Seeing the deceased lying so comfortably, we're relieved that it won't be too difficult.

Amis: qau ika mamau ka sicuayan a savutavutain itjen a djemepedjepedjep pai qau
English: It's not like the old days when we were rushed into squatting and squatting!
What are we going to say now?
God is looking out for us.

Amis: na kipasusu a sihu angauta kidjadjalan tatja varung
ana saceqalj itjin ana suljivatj itjin
English: That we may be free from fear and peace
That's why we have this opportunity.

Amis: mananga nu malim tiyamadju tua sicuayan a kakudan
English: I don't want my people to forget their traditions and customs.
In the midst of their hard lives

Amis: ulja kipapaaqenetj anga tua tucu izuanga tjinaumaljan aza kakedriyan aya masa inayan naicu a sihu
English: The Government has to let people understand the changes and differences in the lives of young people nowadays.

Amis: manasikatucu a patjevavanu azanu bungka kemasicuai manasiayaya nusa sihu tjanuitjin
English: That's why the government is encouraging our people to bring back the traditions and customs of the past.

Amis: saka maljimalji a isasusuan maljimalji a sihu a temulu tja nuamen
English: So thank you to the senior officials and thank you to the Government.

Amis: maljimalji a kipaulaula temulu tjanuamen atua cua sengsengan anga maitucu
English: Thanks for all the hard work in teaching us everything!
Enables us to look back and forward to our traditions and culture
So I hope we can all understand

Amis: aicu aku siqaivuivu drie nu palemek nuinikanamapakatjezua
English: I may not have gone into enough detail.
This is what I've heard from my elders.

Amis: izuaku pinacunan ana seljavakananaken tua zuma
English: I also had a chance to see the lifestyle of the elders of the tribe.

Amis: manaku sikacaqu a qivu taicu ana maitucu atja sipasemalamalw a sicuayan
English: That's why I can talk about some of the cultural backgrounds I know.

Amis: saka uljatjena kemeljang tua tucu sarenguaq angaitje aravac na manguaqanga itje aravac
English: I hope we know that everyone is living in comfort and stability.

Amis: uljatjenanamalevaleva taicu a sihu ana papuvarung taicu ana maitucu
English: Let us rejoice that the government has entrusted us with a blessing.
That's all I have to say.
Thank you all for your hard work.

Amis: pai aicu na lemangdaitjen ticua sini tjaucikel ni kinai Rigeljaw
English: After we listened to Auntie Ke Jinmei's sharing

Amis: aicu atja matjaljaljak namaljaluai aravac aicu atja matjaljaljak
English: Our elders have made it very clear and we are very grateful to them.

Amis: aicu ati kina nanguaq aravac sedjaljep aravac atja kivadaqin
English: This aunty is very kind and quite suitable to ask him to share with us

Amis: tja kina tjequljan a kemasi lumamad a patje vaik itjen i maza i kacauan
English: The history of our lives from the time we are born to the time we leave the world

Amis: saka na maljaluai aravac maljimalji aravac aicu atja matjaljaljak
English: So it's very clear, thank you very much.

Amis: kinai Rigeljaw nguanguaq aravac asu sini pasemalaw
English: Auntie, your speech was very touching.

Amis: sa inianga semusu a sinicuayan a za ramaljemaljeng u pinacunan ljaʼua izuananan aza u si pacucun tu kerikeri a za niamadju a sikudakuda
English: I no longer see the elderly following traditions, but I have seen some of their patterns of living.

Amis: nu uri pakagi aya a san puvaquan izua ta sivs qiljas man kumaq tazua mavacuk
English: We'll start cultivating the millet garden in September.

Amis: nu aya nu ziu-icigac ma selaselak anga aza asaw seman kasiw sa ljamai
English: Cutting and burning of trees in November when the leaves fall

Amis: nu icigac nu ita qiljas tjemugut tjemugutanga au nu tjelu a qiljas sangac masik
English: We'll start spreading millet in January and pull it out in March.

Amis: a nu gemudem e nu makagudem a masik e ari kavau ta bulabulai aya za u kina
English: When we finished, my mother told me to put on a nice dress and go with her.

Amis: e~ʼu kina anga a na kemacu tjanuaʼen u kama anga na vai a djaljau kemudatjen u ayain e vaik itjen a emaluv taza inasikan aya
English: My father died young, and when my mother took me with her, I asked her what she was going to do, and she answered me that we were going to bless the millet that had been plucked".

Amis: vaik aʼen mazua men i vavua palisi aza u kina kemudakuda sun u ayain e~palisilisi aʼen pa veveveve aʼen semu paljipaljik aʼen e~aya e iya aya en
English: I followed, and when I got to the mountain, my mother began to worship and pray for blessings. I asked my mother what she was doing. I asked my mother what she was doing, and she replied, "I'm praying to protect it from evil spirits, so that it will grow well and get rid of the bad ones.

Amis: gemudem e a maka palisi anga za u kina a si cuayan neka nu gas vaik a qemaluvuan a kikasiw ma kikasiw anga vaik a mavavua maumaq
English: In the past, there was no gas, so mothers would collect wood from the bushes after worship and return home after collecting it.

Amis: ini cuai e~kivaqu kivaku anga tazua nu kivaqu amen a za ramaljemaljen aʼu pinacunan a sicuayan izua patez a ita qumaquma
English: Soon after that, the millet was harvested, and when I went there to see the old people harvesting, they had grain silos in the fields.

Amis: nu maka kivaqu e~seqetjen izua remasi rasirasin ivavua au nu makarasi seʼetjen a pi vavua bulabulai sa qeljevi aza tapau
English: After harvesting the millet and drying it, I put it into the storage area. The millet is dried in the mountains, and after drying it, I organize it and put it into the storage area.

Amis: zikinai a senma quma...sema qinaljan aza vaqu umalji a namakuda a tja culjan inia maqati a pasa umaqen
English: You can't take millet home, no matter how hungry you are.

Amis: avanangata tja kacuin a tja aselu tja qaselu sa tja pasa vavuain a maisu anema tja kanen nu iniatjen a maisu
English: But we can take the mortar and pestle up to the mountain to shell it. If we don't shell it, what are we going to eat?

Amis: au nu maka aya anga nu maka palisi anga qinaljan aza kinivaqu pasa qumaqu anga aza vaqu aya semaumaq amen a mapuljat tacemekecekeljan masivaqu a pasaqukaqan anga
English: After the tribe had finished worshipping the millet harvest, we were told to take the millet home, and we did, and the whole family carried the millet.

Amis: nu mantez itjumak aza kinivaqu e izuaza kisatja aya kisatja nu aya nu ita paljing malain tu izua unem a leklekan tuʼi lima leklekan
English: When Siu Sai Pan returned home, he started to collect tax, which was five or six small handfuls per household.

Amis: e~izua sasekauljan nua mamazaniljang vaivak a ki ayay malap taza vaqu sa pasazavi tua mamazangiljang
English: The servant of the traditional leader, who goes around collecting millet to send to the traditional leader.

Amis: nu maka sakuc anga inia cuacuai ivu tauta tu idu kaqepuqepu a semamaza i mamazangiljang aya.vaik itjen a maqepuqepu a taqinaljang
English: Then, soon after the millet harvest, the traditional leaders told us to go there, "All the tribesmen will gather there.

Amis: e pavayan itjen aya itjen sipavai uta aza tja kinivaqu a inalap nia madju pinapalisiyan anga au alapu anga aya zikilu anga sun a keman taza su kinivaqu aya
English: They returned the millet to us and told us to take it back. It was announced that we could eat the harvested millet

Amis: sikuda za pinaisuan nu ayatjen vavuai、avain、mivung au nu mantez anga aljaalja kemasi inuanga sipatjavan anga si pakan
English: Those are to be used to make wine and millet cakes for the guests who come to visit.

Amis: au e~inia cuacuai tu inivungan seman cavilj aya aza seman cavilj e emavai uta aza mamazangiljan
English: Soon it will be the Harvest Festival, and it is a tradition for Li Xiu to make millet cakes for the Harvest Festival.

Amis: e~pavai taza pikak aza kasususu demut anan nia madju anan pavai ta pikak pavavuain、paqavain au aza qinavai anga nu madjalju taza se mancavilj tja satjezen a pasa mamazaniljan
English: Traditional leaders distribute leavened cakes to close family members to make wine and millet cakes, which are then delivered to the traditional leaders.

Amis: azua sivaik anga penaljin taza izua maqati su alapan tu aya tjen tucuanga maqacuvucuvun aya，vavayavayan uqaljaqaljai，matazua
English: Teenagers of both genders go to the distribution.

Amis: nu ita caucau ita qavai si papavai ta kinacemekeljan au nu makaqalut anga tazua e
English: One for each family, and when they're done.

Amis: izuanga za vaquan a vulalisen ayatjen aza ti tjavulun a vulalisen uri zikilu anga mamau a secugiu anga
English: It's a bar mitzvah. Graduation, in other words.

Amis: anga ta nimazu a sengsengan i palakuan，izuanga za tjaivilivililj a semazetj ta qavai a pasazua azau semetjelud angata sa vulalisen ta namayata namapaulan
English: He graduated from Barakoon, and the bar mitzvah was an arduous process, with his descendants sending him millet cakes.

Amis: a sivitai aya tjen ljaʼua izua kukiu a kemakan tiamadju maquziquzipen nua matjaljalja
English: We say the military is very strict, but friendly military food, but they are family members sending food, in the tribe in Paracrown communal food.

Amis: valuljuin pasavavua nu macidilj malain aza acaʼacavan aza vamaljulj nu ma acuvucuvun drusa nu namaqal a kinacavacavan tjelu nu macidilj aza caucau a vulalisen macidilj aza cinsan a venaljulu imaza
English: The number of biting cats depends on the thickness of the tree. If the tree is thick, there will be two, if it is thin, there will be three. There is one whipper for each trainee.

Amis: au e~semetjelud aravac au nu maka valjulu anga aza ramaljemaljen a nu izua za tja aljak a valjuluin aya tjen
English: It's a tough process. Adults with children in their homes.

Amis: sikesa sun taza beras a vaqu tusi kaljava nu maculjuculju angan sipan taza su aljak a vinaljulu si pa aya matucu ma aya za samek nu maculjucu aza bedras
English: I'll boil it, dry it, and put it on my calves.

Amis: au inia minvalak aza vinaljuluan ui namaiatazua za niamadju a sintuludan a sicuayan sa vulalisen a u pinacunan
English: This is how hard it used to be for the elders to train the adults so that the whipped calves would not be serious. I only see one thing.

Amis: au vililjan anga a u valjau ti anga za tiamadju au e nu aya nu inalap sun taza qavai naza mamazangiljan e~amazua
English: My husband Tse Kim Lai. He's the last of his kind, if the traditional leaders don't pick you up with a rice cake.

Amis: e~amaya itjen taza inia sun a qemacuvu tjalju dralan sun sun nisun a epu au zikinai sun a makadju yu
English: How do you mean? It's a waste of a year. Your behavior can't be out of line.

Amis: nu makatju sun idan sun tu inua za uma vaiken sun kemin nazua su qalialian a nisun a a tazuanga cavilj kimen sun qaluin sun sa sun a capai pi palakuan
English: And if thou dost transgress, when the house where thou didst transgress is known, thy contemporaries, when they find thee, will carry thee to Paracoon and smoke thee.

Amis: izua kinalian i palakuan a papecunguan i vecekadan ta kasintan inia maʼevuʼevutj asapui capain sun yu a sun ta kakudanan na inaljan inia sun a kisanka a kisekaulj qi qinaljan
English: There is a pit in the center of the crown of Bara for a fire, and the fire will not be extinguished day or night, for you have violated the covenant of the tribe, and you will be stripped of your clothes, and you will not take part in the affairs of the tribe.

Amis: a liaw kakudan i qinaljan liaw a kakudan na mamazaniljan liaw a kakudan na ramaljemaljen nu kasi vavua nu kasi inu aicu
English: There are many things for the tribe, many things for the traditional leaders, many things for the elders. Whether they are coming back from the mountains or coming home from anywhere, they need to be busy with the tribe, and that is their job.

Amis: au aicu a namayatucu a inia sun a taza valjuluin nu makavaljulu izua qezetjan anga sun
English: So, if you haven't completed your adult training, tie a white towel around your head after you've been whipped by a biting cat.

Amis: qaljaqalja i qinaljan au nu inia sun a pavacak tu icininkan alapen sun sa sun a capai pasa palakuan sun naza su
English: You can go anywhere you want, or you can go to your favorite friend, but if you don't finish the year's training, I'm sorry, they'll pick you up, and they'll teach you a lesson.

Amis: tazua anga inianga e~macaqu a qivu a caucau izuanga niamadju niamadju vaik a ziu qau
English: It is a very small minority, for everywhere there is already a gospel, and they walk according to themselves.

Amis: a maitucu aza u pinacunan buksi e~tjaljimaza tasa u kinljangan taza kinaikacauanan
English: Pastor, this is all I know about my life.

Amis: masalu tjanumun a lemangdanga taza u tjaucikel amin
English: Thank you for listening to me. End of story.

Amis: a quanana nu qivaku a ramaljemaljen kivaqu umaya aya en inia en a kemeljan
English: In fact, when an old man goes to collect millet, I think he is just collecting millet, without having too much cognizance.

Amis: djaljau angata masualap a sinicuayan a kakudakudan
English: It is because traditional customs are being lost very quickly.

Amis: avan aza u pinacunan taza ramaljemaljen nu puqezelj aʼen
English: Just the elders I've met, I'm trying to remember.

Amis: nu pu ita sun a sema kavuavuan malain maqadau tjen aya izua tu aza a si adjai
English: Whenever I collect millet, I am afraid that the sun will be too hot, so I prepare about 20 pieces of rope to tie the millet, which is not too much.

Amis: a sicuai nekananan liuʼan lja au~nu kivaqu
English: In the past, there were no transportation vehicles. They were tied up and could not speak.

Amis: nu tjen tisun a laulauzan aza zayazayan avanangaza venengetj
English: If a group of five would line up in a row, the two on the far side would specialize in tying up the millet, and the two on the far side would specialize in tying up the millet.

Amis: au~tisun a ataza timazu a ehen maitazua nu aya idan anga za nu vaqu aya avan azua umaya maʼaqju.
English: The person on the far left and far right makes a humming sound to indicate that the millet in their hand can be passed over, which may be forgotten.

Amis: a inia en a kemelja ta zuma pai buksi namai tazua aza u kineljangan ta u kinaikacauwanan anga en a
English: Pastor, I don't know much about the others, I just know these.

Amis: au~neka nu pinacunan sa kemuda kemuda amin azua u sin tjaucikel a u pinacunan
English: I haven't seen all kinds, just those.

Amis: avan aza tjavavulungan tjanuamen angata aza anga liaw a pinacunan pai situ anga en izuanga
English: Those in their 80s would know more. I was in elementary school in '42 or '43, and the gospel was in the tribe.

Amis: ana tjevuta tjanuamen aza na u valjau na na tinsukiu
English: The first to come into the tribe was Catholicism, and my sister's husband was a Catholic representative.

Amis: au ti tazua timadju aza taza taza palakuan inianga tu si vangavang aza palakuan taza caucau w inalap timadju ta qavai
English: When I was 15 years old, Xie Jinlai was the last of the ladder to be trained at Balakoon, and was picked up with millet cakes.
