Amis: aw kasicuayan ika tja si ikat ja si neka tjasi ayaya amin a
English: (We didn't use it back in the day... Use it at ....)

Amis: ljaku a zuma anga aya ikaken a kemeljang anga
English: But I'm not sure about the rest

Amis: aw maka…nia kinianiaya tu nia siki paisu ui ta qaljic
English: We harvest the skin to make money.

Amis: aw a hana nia kanen.(nia kanen
hana e vangalj ui ui vangalj vangalj
English: Its flowers, eh! It's a fruit.
From the flower to its fruit.

Amis: i anema nga zua ku sitjawcikel parut
English: What was I trying to say?

Amis: anemaya tjen tazua a sikivangngavangavan mama
English: -What is the word for the part (in Paiwanese) about using a ditch tree as a toy?

Amis: ui avan azua cu a ku drawdraven a ngadan
English: Yes, but the part I don't remember is the name of it

Amis: ai azua su drinawsraw a ngadan
English: -Oh!  So it's the name you don't remember.

Amis: ui na su tinuluan anga ken
ljakua ika ken a paqenetj utauta
izua djui ma djui itjen ljakua azua rudjurudju
English: But the tender part of its leaves
Oops! This one has no young leaves.

Amis: maqati a tjasipuljaceng ta pinuljacengan a
English: Can be used to cook rice

Amis: tja san siaven san djamay maqati aicu a tjanaq

English: What do they call it in Chinese?

Amis: ai ui avan a kemeljang aken
English: Ah yes, the name I remember is Prickly Onion.

Amis: na kiyurag tucu neka zua veve
English: It's dry now. No new shoots.
(What are the new buds used for?)

Amis: nu kiaya itjen avan a rudju a tja kiayaun
English: （"To gather it is to gather the tender part of it, is it not?)

Amis: ui azua rudjurudju a tja kiayain
English: Gather the tender parts of it.

Amis: ljaku aicu a vuluvulung maqati a tja kayain sat ja drasi
English: However, you can also pick the old parts and dry them in the sun.

Amis: aw tja drasin tja rumeden avan anga azua tja rinumed anga tja sipusalulum
English: After drying in the sun, crumble it and use it as a spice.

Amis: qadjaw ka tja salum a namayatazua ni ui
English: (Wow! Doesn't the tender part of the leaf smell better?) Yes, it is.

Amis: aw aicu a uri ku sitjumalj
English: Next, I'm going to talk about...

Amis: avan cu a ljengi liyaw cu a navenangalj na pehana
English: Look, there's a lot of manzanita growing here.

Amis: aicu asaw tja seqasen tja seqasen a sicuayan sa

English: A handful is about this much. Dry it.

Amis: drasin a pi cuacuway anga nu macaianga
English: And then after some time under the sun.

Amis: nu macaiy anga tja sakuceng anga tja si tapaw
English: After drying, it will be transported for building houses.

Amis: ui lja kasicuayan a tja umaq ljinavia
English: Because in the old days, our houses were thatched.

Amis: aw nu ljemitacavilj tja pavaliden a i vavaw
English: And then every year, the upper part of the roof is replaced.

Amis: ljakua avan azua i vavaw a tja papaavalitan
English: But only the part above the roof will be replaced.

Amis: ui avan azua asaw a tja sitapatapaw
English: Yes, the leaves are used in the roofing part.

Amis: masi kasicuayan kemasi yacadja men a semakuc
English: In the old days, we had to move it from far away

Amis: avan tucuanga demud cu a imaza
English: But now it's here, so close.

Amis: kasicuayan avan nu tja si pecungucungu
English: In the old days, it was used in case of fire.

Amis: tja pendrngdrngqen satja aya avan nu tja si pecungu a patagilj
English: We cut it into sections to use as ignition material for the fire.

Amis: aw aicu a vangalj aicu a vuqavuqalja vangalj maqati a tja san suapanen
English: Then these grasses, these white flowers, can be used to make brooms.

Amis: tja vengetjen sa tja a namaya tucu uta ui tja sannuapanen
English: Bind it (the manzanita) in bundles like this, and use it to make brooms.
Tie it up in a bundle and make it into a broom.

Amis: tja sasanguaq a tja si pacunan
aicu malji a tja aitucuin tja gecesen satja axx qadid
English: Even if you fold it like this, it's very bitter, bitter.

Amis: qadid ljakua kiayan nazuma malji a pairing tjengelay
English: It's bitter, but people still pick it, and the Han Chinese like it.

Amis: aicu kiayain cu a asaw sa laljain seman uciya san tatekelen
English: Pick the leaves and boil them to make a tea and drink it as a tea.

Amis: aw matu bulay ta matu aya
English: I've heard it's good for high blood pressure.

Amis: aicu a hana neka nu aya avan cu a asaw cu a asaw maqati a aya san uciain
English: Its flowers have no effect, only its leaves can be used as tea.

Amis: izua ku linangdan izua puljaceng yu
English: I've heard of people using it in rice stews.

Amis: izua puljaceng tazua qadjaw ka puljaceng a amis
English: (Someone's using it for stewing, right?) Maybe it's the Amis.)

Amis: qadjaw avanizua a masanitalj gata naneka anga tjanuitjen
English: I don't know, but there's one I know of that we don't have here anymore.

Amis: avan azua qadid a pagalju ljakua qaca azua asaw，na kiparu samaq
English: It's a little bitter, but it's got big leaves, a little like lettuce.

Amis: avan azua na keman anga ken
ui natemekel anga ken ta uciya nucu
aw avan anga cu a ku sitjumalj
English: I'm going to tell you about this...

Amis: aicu akay kakedriadriyan aicu a namayatucu aicu
English: These are all... These are all smaller looking.

Amis: izua hemana aw azua hana niamadju akay
English: Yes, the flower is blooming. That's its flower.

Amis: aw nu tja dradruain mayatuvu azua vat ma aya ma aya tja maca
English: And then when you touch it, its seeds will be like this (radiating movement), and it will stick in your eyes.

Amis: nu masualap a hana izua za a aya nimadju vat i taladj
English: When its flowers have fallen, the seeds within them

Amis: nu tja dradruain maitucu azua aya azua vangalj
English: When you touch it, its seeds pop out like this.

Amis: aicu nama aya tucu hana aicu
English: Like this. This is its petal.

Amis: nama aya nga izua anga nama tucu name meqaca nga
English: There's already a modified variety. It's gotten bigger.

Amis: aw azua asaw mamaw tazua kaedrikedriyan

English: But it's getting bigger. This one's bigger.

Amis: matu si pa ayaya ta na i pairing aicu
English: This one was used as a potted plant in the flatlands.

Amis: aw tucu nu sema I vavua namasan camel anga
English: And then it's just a weed on the hill.

Amis: pumayan nu paqenetj sun ku sivecik anga
English: （It's okay. I'll write it down when you remember.)

Amis: ui su tinuluan aken izua ku vecik lja ljakua ikaken a paqenetj utauta
English: (You've taught me this before, and I have a record of it, but I can't remember)

Amis: ui azua timadju a qautj a kasiw nu venangalj makelu azua vangalj a masan vangulj
English: That's right, when that ditch tree grows fruits, you can use it as a gyroscope after the fruits fall off.

Amis: tjasi kivangang nu kakedriyan anan itjen
English: We used them as toys in our childhood.

Amis: tja vanguljen maitucu azua a aya
English: We can do this when the torsos are spinning that...

Amis: gata ikat ja kinacu azua aya
Ika suxx su pinukitu azua vangalj ui
English: Don't you have a gyro (fruit) in your pocket?

Amis: aw azua kasiw maqati a ayanin
English: And then it's the trunk that can

Amis: ridraridren a dremadrikitjan a mayatucu taleman ta siangku
English: You can saw it off, saw it like this, and use it to grow shiitake mushrooms.

Amis: ui azua timadju a qautj a kasiw a qapulu
ui pay dri manguaq angata ka mapaqenetj azua vangalj a qautj
English: It's really good! I can remember the name of the fruit.

Amis: aw tjapatjemazavaw anga a ku tjawcikecikel tja nu sun a yi Akay uiui
English: Well, that's the end of my part of the story.

Amis: ui aw qatjaw ki izuanan a na maatjuq kemuda cu a tja cemel a tja kasiw
English: I don't know if there's anything I've missed about the trees, grasses, and other plants in our neighborhood.
We'll talk about it next time.

Amis: ika ken a kemeljang ta ku sitjaucikel tu ki anema
English: I don't know what I'm gonna say.

Amis: kata nu azua ku vinalung pai ku tjumaljay ta ku kinakakedriyanan ki na kemuda nu a nia sikudakuda a patjemaqacuvung
English: But, in my heart of hearts, I'm going to talk about our childhood to adulthood.

Amis: ki aya dremikidrkitj cuwa uri ka ku tjawcikel
English: So I'll keep it short and sweet.

Amis: tiamen ta sicuayan puamin amen i gakku nu tjalju ta anga puamin amen i gakku
English: We used to be in school until after the end of sixth grade.

Amis: anamaya tjanuaken na izzua ku a vaik a kitulu a ljazuazua
English: At that time, I had the opportunity to go to Extended Learning (more)

Amis: ljakua avan a na sinturudjan na nia kinacemekeljan
English: But because of our family's plight (poverty)

Amis: avan a nia kinatjuruvuan a marka aljak ni kina a vinaikan amen nua nia kama
English: Because my mom had a lot of kids and my dad passed away.

Amis: e na ika ken a maqati a vaik a sema gakku a kitulu a sinalu anga ken a sema ta a
English: I couldn't go to school, so I went to Taitung Girls' High School, the junior high school I was guaranteed admission to.

Amis: ljakua tjakudai ika ken a maqati a vaik a sema gakku
English: But what can I do? I'm not allowed to go to school.

Amis: tazua na izua aravac a ku lja tiamen a puamin a i cavilj
English: At that time, I really had a good chance because I had finished school that year.

Amis: a i tiaken a na ma piliq tu a pasa i
English: I'm the one who was selected to be sent to Junior High East Girls' School in Darren Township.

Amis: ljakua matazua anga ma ki qulip aken a kitulu ulja avan a nia kinacemekeljn a malain
English: But that's how I gave up studying because of my family.

Amis: au nu mayatazua tiamen kasicuayan neka nan azua aya neka nan cu a a sagakukuin
English: That's why we didn't have a so-called junior high school when we were in school.

Amis: au nu puamin amen ita karakuda anga men a sema vavua
English: When 6th grade (school) was over, we had to go up to the mountains to work

Amis: e puamin a ken a nusauni a qadaw vaik anga aken a kalakuda a
English: I'm graduating today and I'm going to work.

Amis: kizeliuljan ta ku mareka ku kaka mareka ku salasaladj a namaculuqut a pinakaizuanan
English: Counting hours with my siblings and my classmates.

Amis: sa mazazeliuliula nga men ta karakuda mazazeliuliur mare paqeljiqeljing tua nia sengsengan
English: Then we switch jobs with each other and cooperate with each other (to accomplish) our work.

Amis: nu aya mazazeliuliulj amen a maljelima malje unem
English: We've got five or six people who switch jobs with each other.

Amis: au karakuda amen a mapadjavay a sengsengngan
English: We work. We work a lot.

Amis: au matjatji itaita a cemekeljan nu karekuda amen
English: We go (finish) the job one house at a time.

Amis: au numaitazua ta sicuayan a nia sika ciuciuran
English: That's how it used to be when we were together.

Amis: au numayatazua saka cuacuay anga amen a maciuciur a karakuda a mazazeliuliulj mapaqeljiqeljing
English: So, after a long time of switching jobs and helping each other out

Amis: izua tu izua anga za pinuqezeqezelj na nia zeliyuliyuljan a zuma
English: In the exchange of jobs, there are people of special interest.

Amis: a izua nga za piniliq tu katjengelalayan a sudju tu sudju nimadju
English: Sometimes you have to choose who you like and hopefully you can be his lover.

Amis: e aya nu remaeatjan saka namaka tjengelay makaqetjem anga mazazeliyuliyulj a mare kivalavala
English: Sometimes you just like each other, and changing jobs and visiting becomes the norm.

Amis: au tasicuayan nu mangetjez a kasi vavua a mazazeliyuliyulj maciyuciyur a
English: In the old days, when the companion who changed jobs with me came back from the mountain, I was very happy.

Amis: nu izua za nu sakivala mayata sema tja nuamen
English: If you want to play, come to our house.

Amis: tjuruvuruvu azua maciuyuciyur tjanuamen a kivala
English: A lot of people come to our house to play.
The idea of having fun together

Amis: sa nu izua za na aya tu na peniliq anga tu na tjengelay
English: And then, if there is a person who has already chosen a favorite.

Amis: izua anga za kiljangljang nimadju saka izua za pinuqezeqezeljan nimadju
English: He's already got him. He's already got someone he cares about.

Amis: ljakua ulja tjuruvu a maciuciur a kivala ika makeljang tu tima kinatjengelayan azua vavayan
English: However, since there are so many of them together, it's hard to tell which girl they like.

Amis: au nu izua kivalavala tiamadju temalidu hugadraka lja semenay
English: Sometimes they come over to the house and sing songs while they're having fun.

Amis: nu namaya ta sema tjanuamen lja kemeljan tu ru senay aken
English: For example, when (they) come to our house, they know that I sing a lot.

Amis: pai tului amen ta senay aya temulu amen nu aya nu qezemezemetj sane senay a tjuruvu
English: "Please teach us to sing!" When they suggested this, many of us taught and sang during the evening.

Amis: au nu maljiya anga vaik amen a mazazeliyuliylj
English: After sunrise, we went up the mountain (farming) and exchanged work with each other.

Amis: nu nia kakudan ka sicuayan lja
English: It's what we used to do.

Amis: kasicuayan kisikasiw anan itjen nu kemesa itjen
English: In the old days, when we ploughed, when we cooked, we chopped wood.

Amis: azua uqaljaqaljay nu izua za tjelayalayan tjanuitjen a zeliyuljan a vavayan
English: If the guys are switching jobs with each other in this group of girls who have favorites.

Amis: masikasiw sa pasazuai ta tja umaq nu izua tjengelayalayan tazua zeliyuljan a vavayan
English: The group of people who were changing jobs with each other had a girl he liked, and he would bring firewood and put it in the girl's house.

Amis: au namapaqeljin ta kasiw azua a aya a tjumaq navavayan
English: So about firewood for the girl's family is helped (a lot)

Amis: nu sematja ta macidilj a macidilj a karakuda aya nu masulem masikasiw lja
English: If the other party goes to work at the other party's house, he or she will bring firewood with him or her after the evening.

Amis: nu vaik anan a sema vavua na kemacu amen tazua quwar
English: That's why we bring hemp rope when we go to the mountains.

Amis: nu kasi vavua amen sa uri masulem anga kemikim amen tua kasiw tu nia kacuin a tjumaq
English: When we go up the mountain, after dark, we look for firewood to take home first.

Amis: qaw izua nia sivengetj ta nia kini kasiw
English: So that we have a rope to wrap the firewood with.

Amis: au nu azua ku kai anga nu izua na tjengelayan na zua uqaljaqaljay
English: As I said, if a guy has a favorite person.
The firewood will be moved to the girl's house.
That's how it was, when they switched jobs.

Amis: au nu remaketjan izua za aya nu izua za nasasudjusudju sa uri marepucekelj anga
English: Sometimes, love has reached the stage of marriage.

Amis: nu aya nu ika rupasikasiw azua uqaljay tu zua uri lja uri pucekeljan
English: If marriage has been discussed and the boy does not always give firewood (to the woman)

Amis: au nu mayatazua anema itjen lja azua masikasiw pakeljang tui na tjengelay
English: So, what can I say? Giving firewood is an important thing. It's a way of letting the other person know that they love you.

Amis: au azua ika pasikasiw remuin nu cuay anga
English: "He didn't bring any firewood." That's what they used to call him sometimes.

Amis: ika rupasikasiw aku tjakatjengelayan namayatazua aya nu cuay anga azua uri marepucekelj
English: "He doesn't always bring firewood." Why should we like a man like that, who's going to get married in time?

Amis: au avan nu sika aya nazua masikasiw na kasicuayan
English: So, this is the (importance of) firewood delivery at that time

Amis: au nu mayatazua mazazeliyuliyulj nu ita qadaw saka ika nama ciyuciyur tiamadju
English: A day of exchanging hours with each other like this, when they're not together.

Amis: nu kasicuayan nu tjamazuazua ta gadu a quma na macidjlj
English: In the old days, if another man's farm was a little past the hill of

Amis: masasenasenay a mayatazua a a uzai mun i zua i avan nu sika
English: They sing to each other like that, you're on the opposite side of the mountain, that's why they have this song.

Amis: izua senay a aya ui uri maitazuazua a ku valung
English: With a song like this, yeah, I do.

Amis: naluan ai nane lja ui naluan na lja i a na ya u
inuan anga nu ayaya men ai lja manu i ljeval mun a i lja ai nu a i
English: We were just wondering where you guys were right now. Turns out you're just across the hill.

Amis: aya itjen semenay ta tja izuazua a tja salasaladj ui
English: And so we harmonized with our companions on the opposite side of the mountain.

Amis: au aya lemangeda azua tja a tjarayurayuan
English: Our friends across the mountain have heard our song.

Amis: tja aya tja sudjusudju temevela nu remaketj
a sitevelan niamadju semenay avan azua a aya
azua tjaisangas a ku senay azua si ayaya
English: The song that I sang in the previous paragraph stated that

Amis: i kina sema inu azua ku zazeliyuljan nelja aya azua valung niamadju
English: I don't know where my fellow workers have gone. They think so.

Amis: manu uzai mun i ljevaljeval aya izua mun a nia pacucunan aya ui
English: So you're on the other side of the hill. We're looking right at you.

Amis: i aya za aya a semenasenay au azua i temevela
English: They answered us from the opposite side of the mountain.

Amis: idu ui idu kengcengelju nia nu sini pazekatj aya
English: Come on, come on, come on. Please, come to lunch. We have reservations for you.

Amis: a a siayaya idu kencengelju e liyaw a nia kinsa a nia pinazekatj tja nu sun aya
English: They rapped: Come on! Come and have lunch! We cooked a lot and reserved a lot for you.

Amis: aza a tjara azua tiamadju masasenay a matazua
English: They were on opposite sides of the mountain, and they sang to each other.

Amis: au ui aya tasicuayan malji ce~madja masasenasenay nu ika na maciuciur mazazeliyuliyulj
English: That's why I used to sing to each other even if we didn't exchange hours together and even if we were far away.

Amis: ui ljaki ika tjen a kemeljang tu tja kinljang a quma tjayau
English: Yes, even if we don't know, we know that (their) farmland

Amis: nu izai nu izai nu izua tja kinljang a quma tu
English: There's some of it out there. There's some farmland that we knew about.

Amis: au nu remaketjan tja sasenayan tu nu i vavua tjen uta a aya
English: There are times when we sing in the mountains

Amis: nu tjakudan a semenay nu tja pacunan a tja salasaladj i aya ljevaljeval ay tazua i
English: If the companion on the opposite side of the mountain is within our sight, we are accustomed to sing

Amis: ui semenay pakata senay a si sirukaikai aya maitazua
English: And then we deliver what we have to say through singing, that's all.

Amis: au nu masulem anga masasenay uta
English: We sang to each other in the evening.
If it's dark and you're still on the mountain.

Amis: au uri masulem anga uri semaumaq anga
English: It's getting dark. We're going home.

Amis: au semenay utauta naluan a ne lja ai na lu an i ya na ya
u ailja elualumedan namen ne ai nu ai
naluan ai nanelja liningan anga ti luljingasen ai lja uari nudja ai lju seljilja ainu ai aya
English: The sun is going down, so get on your way home.

Amis: ui lja zua tjara tiamadju nu masasenasenay
English: So when they were singing to each other on the opposite side of the mountain.

Amis: au e maitazua sa nu aya temevela i tjaizuazua
English: That's how it works. You ask a question here, you answer it there.

Amis: nu lemangeda tazua senay na tjaimaza temevela zua tjaizuazua
English: This side heard the song, and the other side answered.

Amis: naluan ainelja nu tjaisangas mun ai lja i pasu emaljavau amen ne ai nu ai
English: If you get there first, please wait for us.

Amis: aya temevela a i i ta gadu
English: That's how the other side of the mountain will respond.

Amis: au a siayaya nu sema zua ta uri ucevungan niamadju
English: They sang, "If we go to the place where they meet".
If you arrive first, please wait for us.

Amis: ljatjen a maciuciur i tjen a kemasi zua aya a siayaya ta matazua
English: Let's get together from that (place), talking about from there (start)

Amis: ki maciur a semaumaq ui nu sema tazua mecevucevung
English: (Going home together) Yes, that's it. Meet me at the crossroads.

Amis: azua e saka zua tjaivililj anga tua zua avan anga zazua a...e...vawa
English: And then after that, the wine.
It's a wine carrier for the wedding.

Amis: saka vanazua a...sidraiyaiyan nua maraka maqacuvucuvung
English: It's also the wedding wine that young people drink when they dance around.
After we give each other our clan uniforms.

Amis: saka azua uqaljay sisan i...buk tua e...maqatiy a cinuru
English: The woman can help the man make a blouse made of different fabrics.

Amis: azua nekanan a qataqata sicuayan ui
English: Because in the oldest days, there was no beadwork.

Amis: mayatazua sicuayan azua namauramanan saka ljakua sisan kacing sisan tjevet
English: That's how it was done in the old days, when we were poorer, but we made sure to make pants and warriors.

Amis: mayatazua sakavan a vayar mayatazua patjezuain
English: In addition to those and the shawl, it's a complete costume.

Amis: e...azua piqulu ta vavayan ta uqaljay e...ta sicuayan azua mauramanan nekanan a namayatazua
English: The woman and the man will give each other headdresses because they were poor and had no headdresses for a long time.

Amis: nekanan a namayatazua zua kaljaurauramananan a paruarut a sicuayan a nekanu anema nu anema
English: It's because in the past, we were really short of material goods.

Amis: min a mamazangiljan nu cemaicaing ta nanguanguaq a pagalju azua maveseveseng
English: Only traditional leaders wear better clothing and it's exclusive.

Amis: nua mamazangiljan tu namakuda namakeljang tu namakuda sisitusitungan nua tjaljaljaljaljak namayatazua
English: There is a difference between a traditional leader's patented costume and that of a commoner.

Amis: saka nu makaya tuazua e sema zua anga tjen tua semevalj
English: The next step is to talk about the etiquette of the marriage ceremony.
The rituals of being carried in marriage

Amis: nu uri semevalj anga e...aza iuazuaza dridri a inadai
English: Entering into the marriage ceremony with a suckling pig as a proclamation
The second pig is a big one.

Amis: ita kudrakudral azua kudrakudral a silisilisi azua
English: A big pig was used as a wedding gift.

Amis: sisa qaljiu azua dridri sa buiqi salinipelip azua ta kaljuljud
English: Wrap the piglet in a head covering and stab it with a knife to bleed.

Amis: nu neka kaljuljud lipelipen tua ljava
English: If you don't have a headpiece, wrap it in a pretty flowery cloth.

Amis: a...saka azua ti sanu e...papirava tuazua ti...e... uri patjedjalanen
English: And then there's the elder who's in charge of decorating the bride.
